This is a very famous and a very influential book. This was not the first time I checked the book out of the library but I now know much more about antidepressants and the related issues than I did when I first became familiar with Kramer's book. What I found on my quick survey of the book this time amazed me. This is not a book supported by research. It is a book of stories. The stories
column2: one after the other
column3: are about Kramer's patients (Kramer is a psychiatrist) and how taking Prozac dramatically transformed lives overnight. Consider these four examples. 1. Sam: "Sam not only recovered from his depression
column4: he declared himself better than well. He felt unencumbered
column5: more vitally alive
column6: less pessimistic. Now he could complete projects in one draft
column7: whereas before he sketched and sketched again. His memory was more reliable
column8: his concentration keener. His memory was more reliable
column9: his concentration keener. Every aspect of his work went more smoothly. He appeared more poised
column10: more thoughtful
column11: less distracted. He was able to speak at professional gatherings without notes.(Page x.) 2. Sally: After four months on Prozac
column12: she looked brighter
column13: calmer
column14: self-assured
column15: in control of herself. The most important effect of the medication
column16: Sally felt was that it cleared her head...After ten months...she negotiated a small promotion and pay raise at a time when the bank was cutting back staff...More remarkable was the change to her private life. She started going to dances...(Page 147.) 3. William M: The patient's low self-esteem
column17: which had been present since his earliest childhood
column18: began to disappear...On medication William M. experienced a sense of self-worth superior to any he had felt before. (Page 203.) 4. Ms. B: For the first time in her memory she felt perfectly relaxed and happy sitting at home reading books or listening to music and felt less of the free-floating anxiety that was previously quelled by going out...Off Prozac
column19: Ms. B. bar-hopped in search of men. Prozac moderated her sense of aloneness and allowed her to enjoy a variety of social settings. Dozens of other examples could be cited. The point is
column20: this is essentially the book. It is a book which convinces the reader of the almost magic power of Prozac by sharing stories like these. What is disturbing is that I now know the truth. Research investigations have found that the power of antidepressants has increased dramatically. They are now more effective because our belief in the power of a pill to cure social shyness
column21: anxiety
column22: depression
column23: and a bad temper has increased dramatically. We have come to believe
column24: as Kramer puts it
column25: "biology is destiny" (page xiv). No where does Kramer explain that the longest of the clinical trial used to get approval of Prozac to market was only 8 weeks long. No where does he share that a tranquilizer was given to study subjects and the other tricks used to make the effectiveness of the drug appear greater than it really is. The dangers of long-term use (diabetes
column26: Parkinson's disease
column27: permanent muscle jerking
column28: etc.) are never discussed. (Of course
column29: these problems were still unknown when Kramer wrote.) See Timothy Scott's wonderful
column30: and unlike Kramer's book
column31: carefully documented book America Fooled: The Truth About Antidepressants
column32: Antipsychotics
column33: and How We've Been Fooled to find the dangers as well as what does bring good mental health. Yes
column34: this book has been influential. Thus
column35: Kramer bears some of the responsibilty for the myth surrounding antidepressants. (They do not work as well as exercise even--numerous studies.) It's funny how
column36: as our knowledge grows
column37: a great book beomes a harmful book
column38: but it is just that.

column1: "Deadline"
column2: while a compelling story that painted an interesting picture of heaven and hell
column3: seemed like one big political infomercial. Alcorn's obvious goal here is not to keep you on the edge of your seat
column4: but to indoctrinate you with a tidal wave of conservative politics and viewpoints. First of all
column5: the story gives off the idea that in order to be a good Christian and get into Heaven you must be a Republican (and not just any republican
column6: but a cookie-cutter extremist one at that) and disregard anything the least bit liberal or progressive. I found that detail to be nothing but judgmental and stereotypical. The "liberal" characters
column7: in particular
column8: were pretty much the archetypal Christianity-hating
column9: moral relativists that the Political Right labels them as. Though I understand this story is not for the "politically-correct" there were some parts in it that I found were just plain ridiculous (the image Alcorn paints of Planned Parenthood and public schools seemed a little out-of-left field
column10: if I do say so myself). Alcorn's writing style is another thing I'd like to address. He puts in too much unnecessary details and information. He could have easily edited out almost one-eighth of the story and it wouldn't have changed at all. It dragged on for too long
column11: not to mention that the ending was a bit weak for such a blunt story. While "Deadline" does make you think about certain issues
column12: I would not recommend it unless you have a staunch conservative viewpoint. If you don't
column13: stay away from it at all costs.

column1: In his book The Resurrection of Christ: A Historical Inquiry
column2: Gerd Ludemann examines the question of the resurrection by employing historical-critical methods.  Briefly put
column3: this approach assumes that what is recorded in the New Testament
column4: especially with regard to the divinity of Jesus
column5: is largely the result of mythmaking by those who would benefit from elevating him to god-status.  Additionally
column6: it presumes that the fields of modern science and psychology
column7: along with their underlying metaphysics
column8: should inform inquiries and shape the methods used to investigate past events.  The methodology also requires adherence to Enlightenment period philosophies.  Finally
column9: it tends to reduce historical events and the motives of people primarily to power struggles.  Under this framework
column10: Ludemann analyzes the resurrection accounts found in the New Testament and also some non-Canonical books.  Following this
column11: he characterizes the early Christians' faith in the resurrection as a self-deception.  He justifies this result with a historical reconstruction complete with psychoanalyses of Peter and Paul.  Ludemann concludes that we can no longer be Christians because Jesus of Nazareth did not rise from the dead and that the largest religion on earth is based on a fraud.  He explains
column12: "For two thousand years an abiding faith in Jesus' resurrection has displayed enormous power
column13: but because of its utter groundlessness we must now acknowledge that it has all along been a worldwide historical hoax" (190).  Professor Ludemann's loose and circuitous arguments regarding the scriptures leave ample room for dissection and pointing out flaws in logic and exegesis
column14: but space does not permit.  Instead
column15: I will focus on particular concluding remarks to illuminate the incoherence that results from his untenable presuppositions and method and the inessential and superfluous nature of his resolve.  To begin
column16: Ludemann accepts the fact that no resurrection implies human existence is meaningless.  While he should be following the path of Nietzsche
column17: he espouses hope that virtues can somehow recover meaning.  He petitions
column18: "We strive to create meaning in our lives by living in humility
column19: wisdom
column20: and love" (210).  But why should we live by these virtues to create meaning in our lives?  Suppose some people find meaning in narcissism and selfishness
column21: or perhaps just benign apathy.  Shouldn't they be free to live by those values instead?  Ludemann may say yes
column22: but it seems the author wants to use the imprimatur of Christian virtues to bolster his life philosophy while denying the supernatural God that gave the founder of those virtues his authority and power.  If Jesus taught that we should love others
column23: but his resurrection is a myth and deception as Ludemann teaches
column24: then ultimately the meaning Christians strive to create is groundless and therefore futile.  The professor also admonishes that "belief" somehow points to a weakness in humanity
column25: and implies that it is not appropriate in our scientific age (204-05).  But immediately after disparaging belief
column26: he champions his own.  He dogmatically informs us that he is persuaded to "Live in a house built on a solid foundation rather than a priestly domicile suspended in the sky" (205).  Presumably
column27: this "solid foundation" refers to beliefs that can be constructed only by human intellect.  He further asserts
column28: "Like Bertrand Russell
column29: I believe that when I die my body will rot
column30: and my selfhood will vanish" (210).  Having discarded orthodox Christian belief
column31: he trusts in human intellect
column32: naturalism
column33: and nihilism instead.  The author merely exchanges one belief system for another.  Does he not see his own inconsistency?  Ludemann finally concludes
column34: "Henceforth
column35: I am no longer cowed by the notion that death is a punishment for my sin.  Nor do I hope for a resurrection...Indeed
column36: accepting my perishability gives rise to a truer Easter vision.  Now freed from the undertow of fear and in defiance of the absurd
column37: I can join myself to all humanity by striving in all things to give the best that is in me
column38: and to dedicate my efforts to the welfare of my fellow-voyagers" (210).  In this final assertion of naturalistic dogma
column39: he aspires to greatness in assisting his fellow human beings.  However
column40: he seems to think that his newfound freedom from the absurdity of a God who would raise Jesus from the dead
column41: is what serves as the impetus for his altruistic ambitions.  But this statement of belief is independent of his polemic and consequently his argument loses all force.  I have tried to show
column42: in limited space
column43: that Gerd Ludemann's naturalistic assumptions produce incongruities and self-contradictory reasoning.  Assuming there is no supernatural realm requires him to conjure up fantasies to circumvent the plain meaning and simple message of an ancient text.  In point of fact
column44: I don't think professor Ludemann
column45: in his quietest moments
column46: really wants to live
column47: or die
column48: with his convictions.  The first Christians willingly died for their testimony to seeing Jesus alive again after his crucifixion.  We even know from Josephus that James
column49: the brother of Jesus
column50: was executed for his beliefs.  If Christ wasn't raised
column51: why did all of them die for what they knew to be a lie

column1: I can't speak with authority about other deseg cases
column2: but I AM knowledgeable about the St. Louis case
column3: having spent four years on the St. Louis Board of Education (1989 - 1993.).  Simply put
column4: deseg has destroyed the St. Louis Public Schools (SLPSs)
column5: which were arguably
column6: the best large public school system in the nation prior to deseg
column7: when they were segregated and run by white Lutherans.  Today
column8: after 26 years of deseg
column9: the SLPSs are probably no more than one year from losing their state accreditation and being taken over by the state of Missouri. Let's consider some facts rather than the disinformation of dilettantes and poseurs such as Kozol:   COSTS  Deseg has cost the State of Missouri about $8 Billion between the Kansas City and St. Louis cases. The bill in K.C. totaled about $3.5 Billion when it finally ended
column10: while the St. Louis case has almost certainly passed the $4 Billion mark. (These statistics are scrupulously hidden by the leftist news media.) What have we realized from this expenditure?  First of all
column11: state money diverted to these two deseg cases was stolen from every school district in Missouri not participating in a deseg case. Small
column12: rural school districts routinely spend between $4
column14: 500 per pupil each year. In St. Louis
column15: the per-pupil expenditure has been as high as $11
column16: 711: Yet
column17: those rural
column18: so-called "out-state" districts do a far better job of educating and graduating students
column19: despite having half the resources. (I'm sure in Kozol's mind they are merely "goyim
column20: and deserve no better...)  Ironically, while less affluent out-state" districts were robbed of state funding by deseg
column21: the wealthier school districts in St. Louis County experienced a massive WINDFALL from deseg: Since they are reimbursed by the state the AVERAGE per-pupil cost for each city transfer
column22: (rather than their "marginal" cost
column23: ) wealthy districts such as Clayton
column24: Ladue and Parkway benefited from a massive infusion of new revenues
column25: although these school districts have traditionally out-spent almost every other Missouri district by a factor of three or more. (For example
column26: Clayton currently spends about $15
column27: 000 per pupil per year.)   ACHIEVEMENT  In the SLPSs
column28: half the students test at the 20th percentile or lower on nationally standardized tests. This stat would be even worse
column29: except that (I am told) the "LD" (or "learning disabled") kids do not take the standardized tests. There are legions of LD kids...  In a rare moment of wisdom and sobriety
column30: a federal judge sitting on our deseg case ordered a test of its efficacy in the early 1990s. That study
column31: called the "Lissitz Study" revealed that city students (i.e.
column32: black students) bused to predominately white county school districts improved less academically than did every other category of student in the SLPS. That is
column33: they improved less than students in all-black
column34: the "naturally"-integrated
column35: and "magnet" schools.  When the Educational Testing Service still "normed" the SATs between 400 and 1600
column36: the average SLPS student had a combined SAT of 760. Worse yet
column37: these were the best and most motivated students
column38: with further educational aspirations
column39: who "self-selected" themselves to take the SATs and were therefore
column40: a highly "skewed" sample relative to the average SLPS student.    Deseg is almost universally motivated by the laughable paradigm that
column41: if we throw enough money at our inner-city schools
column42: black kids will achieve at a level commensurate with white kids. Now that even William Coleman has repudiated his own research on this subject
column43: ("The Coleman Report
column44: cited in Brown v. Board
column45: ) Kozol and deseg's other defenders could spend their time far more productively by studying the lessons of The Bell Curve" in order to understand academic disparities between the races.  VESTED INTERESTS  It has been remarked that the defenders of deseg will never relent until the last white kid has been driven from the system. This is because the NAACP Legal Defense Fund is a "co-plaintiff" in most (if not ALL) U.S. deseg cases
column46: and is periodically distributed "legal expenses" by the federal courts. These are a very important source of revenue to the NAACP
column47: which has experienced declining membership and numerous financial scandals over the last several decades.  Similarly
column48: deseg has meant a great deal more than the mindless expenditure of billions to bus students around. One of the most injurious elements of the St. Louis deseg plan has been a massive affirmative-action program for administrators and teachers. The SLPSs now employ more functionally illiterate individuals than the N.B.A.
column49: and have become nothing less than an employment agency for lazy and incompetent blacks with political connections.   Essentially
column50: the same black women who
column51: 30 or 40 years ago were employed in middle-class households as "domestic" help
column52: are now SLPS teachers and administrators. ("I is a teacher.") How anyone who never really absorbed a high school education could be presumed able to teach mystifies all but Kozol and deseg's other defenders. If teachers and administrators in the SLPSs were required to take the S.A.T.s
column53: more than half would test significantly below average: We know this because they have already demonstrated the fact!  Approximately half of all SLPS teachers and about 60% of its administrators attended Harris-Stowe State Teacher's College
column54: which has the second lowest academic standards of any institution of "higher learning" in Missouri. Last time I called their admissions office
column55: I was told that Harris-Stowe accepted applicants with a combined SAT of 780. It should come as no surprise that recent measures of SLPS student SATs do not differ significantly from those of many of their teachers.   HYPOCRISY  A truly fascinating phenomenon I have observed is that there seem to be few defenders of deseg among those whose kids actually participated in such a program. It doesn't take a parent long to understand that deseg isn't so wonderful when your kid gets rolled for his lunch money every day
column56: or your daughter gets beaten up because she won't date outside her race.   Now Kozol may not have kids
column57: but I'll just bet that if he does
column58: they did not participate in any voluntary deseg programs
column59: if any were available where he resides. (The Jews are mustard for this sort of thing
column60: as long as they are merely allowed to posture and it doesn't actually cost them anything...)  I once had the rare opportunity to sit next to Dr. Susan Uchitelle
column61: the  Jewish woman who headed the St. Louis Deseg's "Voluntary Inter-district Coordinating Council" throughout the 1980s and 1990s. (She was paid $60
column62: 000 per year
column63: but from what I could discern
column64: her sole responsibility seemed to be running interference with the news media
column65: so the rubes out there wouldn't get the wrong idea about the joys and benefits of deseg whenever there was a stabbing
column68: or race riot.)  I considered it an "opportunity" because I was able to ask her a question that no one had ever had the impertinence to ask of her before: "Have any of your children participated in the voluntary transfer program?" (That is
column70: who would have been "poster children" for the county-to-city deseg program
column71: allowed to transfer from their all-white county schools in order to be voluntarily bused to inner-city schools?)   What do you think was the answer
column72: oh gentle reader? Your response to this question may have far-reaching implications for your understanding of the world around you and some varieties of its inhabitants
column73: such as Jonathan Kozol...   (I'll give you a hint: Susan Uchitelle's attitude toward deseg is very much like Leona Helmsley's attitude toward taxes...)

column1: . either you like this book or you dont  i dont  --   it exceeded my  BS  tolerance level  imho too much of this is a total crock full of words   if this were condensed to a magazine article it might be worth slogging through  i wonder -  was this once  a magazine article that got put on steroids to pump it up to fill a book?  read it at the library if you must dont buy it  .
I think if you've lived life under a rock
column2: watched a lot of soap operas
column3: and enjoyed life playing out in neat formulas
column4: this book will appeal to you.    It makes me angry to read this book; not because it's fiction (and I'll call it completely fictitious garbage)
column5: but because James Frey tried to pass it off as nonfiction!  He writes this book with an underlying tone "I'm better than all of you."  Not because he thinks AA is BS
column6: but because this theme runs throughout his book
column7: in so many situations
column8: that after awhile it becomes laughable!  He prances around feeling vindicated for all of his actions and everyone else is just a plain a-hole
column9: except his tough guy "friends."  I ask you
column10: if Leonard has such a reputation... where's his protection?  People would be after him in such a vulnerable (read: no security) place like rehab.     I think if you sat back and read this book you as the reader could discern its BS by feeling its predictability.  It reminds me of a comic book where the tough guy is actually the hero who comes in to save the little people
column11: yeah
column12: he's got problems
column13: but he'll prevail because he's James Frey!  No thank you.  I absolutely hated this book
column14: but I read it so I at least deserve credit for trying.

column1: At first glance
column2: Michael Alan Weiner seems like an improbable candidate to be America's angriest
column3: most vicious conservative radio host. Born 60 years ago in the Bronx
column4: Weiner has lived in Northern California for most of his adult life
column5: making a living as an herbalist and nutritionist. He communed with Fijian traditional healers
column6: got married in a rain forest and studied ethno-medicine at the University of California at Berkeley. He swam naked with Allen Ginsberg
column7: dreamed of being the next Lenny Bruce and wrote a rambling novel about a half-mad alter ego. His son's middle name is Goldencloud. For years
column8: he made a name cranking out a pile of books on alternative medicine
column9: recommending bizarre remedies such as using vitamin C to stop AIDS and kicking cocaine with coffee enemas.   These days
column10: Weiner's more interested in purging the body politic. Using the pseudonym Michael Savage
column11: he's launched a one-man mission to save America from its enemies at home and abroad
column12: which on any given day includes liberals
column13: gays
column14: academics
column15: the homeless
column16: the Clintons
column17: immigrants
column18: feminists
column19: CNN
column20: the American Civil Liberties Union
column21: Muslims and other minorities. Broadcasting three hours a day
column22: five afternoons a week
column23: from a rented studio in downtown San Francisco
column24: he gives voice to the right wing's darkest fantasies. He muses about launching preemptive nuclear strikes on the Middle East ("I wish to God the hatches were open and the missiles were flying!")
column25: suggests gunning down illegal immigrants ("If we had a government
column26: we'd blow them out of the desert with airplanes!")
column27: dreams of dispatching with "commies
column28: pinkos and perverts" and other undesirables ("I say round them up and hang 'em high!") and even paraphrases a remark attributed to Nazi leader Hermann Goering ("When I hear someone's in the civil rights business
column29: I oil up my AR-15!")   Woe be unto those who label him racist
column30: sexist or homophobic -- or even worse
column31: threaten his livelihood. When an Oregon group started a boycott of his advertisers last summer
column32: he became downright apoplectic. "I'm more powerful than you are
column33: you little hateful nothings!" he screeched
column34: before intoning darkly in his trademark New-Yawk accent: "I'm gonna warn you again: If you harm me -- and I pray that no harm comes to you -- but I can't guarantee that it won't." Just last week
column35: Savage fumed about the "brownshirt groups" who dare to criticize him: "You stinking rats who hide in the sewers! ... You think I'm going to roll over like a pussy? You're wrong!"   Such vitriolic ranting is over the top
column36: even by the ever-declining standards of talk-radio decorum. Yet
column37: in this time of war fever and hyperpatriotism
column38: inflammatory rhetoric draws conservative ditto-heads and liberal rubberneckers alike
column39: and that translates into big ratings. Since launching "The Savage Nation" on San Francisco's KSFO 560 AM more than eight years ago
column40: Savage has gone from being just another right-winger with a big mouth
column41: a hyperinflated ego and a sizable chip on his shoulder to becoming the nation's fifth most-popular talk-radio personality
column42: a host with enough leverage to land Vice President Dick Cheney as a guest. His book
column43: "The Savage Nation: Saving America From the Liberal Assault on Our Borders
column44: Language and Culture
column45: has been perched at the top of the New York Times bestseller list for over a month, and now he's slated to get his own program on MSNBC.   Michael Weiner's long and circuitous road has taken him from being a scientist and entrepreneur, through stints as a hipster, novelist and aspiring comedian, to becoming the personification of straight white male rage. Today he likes to play up his unconventional career path, to an extent. He's the kind of guy who never lets anyone forget he has a Ph.D. His Web site reminds visitors that he is a World Famous Herbal Expert" and the author of 18 books. But just as his gap-toothed grin has been replaced by a row of airbrushed pearly whites on the front cover of his new book
column46: he gives his audience a whitewashed version of his past. The real story is far more interesting
column47: not just for its ironies and contradictions
column48: but for the often disturbing clues it provides about the man now so well known as Michael Savage. He's gone through at least one political makeover. He's turned on old friends
column49: or they've turned on him. If his semi-autobiographical novel is any guide to his own life
column50: he's keeping a few skeletons in his closet.   In the end
column51: the picture that emerges from his books
column52: from interviews with past and current associates
column53: and from his radio show is that "The Savage Nation" is just the latest undertaking of a man who's spent his life trying to get the world to notice him.   Savage's office said he was too busy preparing for his TV show to be interviewed for this article. Earlier interview requests by phone and e-mail prompted an irritated phone call from a woman named Janet
column54: who announced that Savage would not speak with me. Asked if she was his wife -- who happens to be named Janet -- she said she was not. "I am not affiliated with him
column55: she insisted. I'm just a fan." After a few minutes of testy back and forth
column56: she suggested that it would be unfortunate if my e-mail address and phone number were somehow posted across the Internet.   Savage has come a long way since he emceed school assemblies at P.S. 42 in the Bronx. His father
column57: a Russian Jewish immigrant
column58: made a living selling antique bronzes on Orchard Street. An imposing figure who died of a heart attack in the early 1970s
column59: he is the frequent subject of his son's on-air stories. Speaking at a convention sponsored by the trade magazine Radio & Records in March 2001
column60: Savage recalled getting his first lesson in politics -- and cynicism -- from his dad. "[H]e explained politics to me very clearly. He said
column61: 'You see
column62: this is how the world works ... In this beautiful country of ours there are two bands of thieves: the Republicans and the Democrats.'"   Though Savage waxes nostalgic about such father-and-son moments
column63: it appears that his parents were no Ozzie and Harriet. "I was raised on neglect
column66: he writes in The Savage Nation." But growing up with little parental approval or praise was a good thing
column68: that's why I'm driven the way I am."   Savage
column69: who now decries "propaganda about America being the Land of Immigrants
column70: isn't ashamed of his own immigrant parents. However, his Jewish upbringing is strictly taboo. And he often makes Joseph Lieberman, Barbra Streisand and Larry King the butt of stale ethnic jokes. Brad Kava, radio columnist for the San Jose Mercury News and a longtime Savage critic, thinks Savage's ambivalence toward Jews is a misguided attempt to pander to conservative Christians. He's Jewish
column71: but he always acts like he's Christian
column72: he says. In his book The Savage Nation
column73: for example, he complains of an anti-Christian bias in America. When Kava, who is Jewish, outed" Savage several years ago
column74: Savage reported him to the Anti-Defamation League. Dr. Robert F. Cathcart
column75: a longtime friend of the talk-show star
column76: speculated in a telephone interview that Savage says little about his background so that he appears more "neutral" when he discusses Israel or religious topics.   Everyone who has ever known Michael Weiner seems to agree that he has always been a big talker. One of his classmates from Jamaica High School in Queens
column78: recalls him as a garrulous character: "He was on the short side
column79: and he was intense -- a fast talker
column80: and always hatching some scheme or other." "The fellow I knew was a natural comic and as reliable as a clock
column81: remembers another classmate, who says the teenage Weiner was non-political." His yearbook page notes his participation in the Chemistry Lab Squad
column85: politics and firearms.   Weiner was also something of a dreamer
column86: and he hoped to follow in the footsteps of his hero
column87: the naturalist Charles Darwin. After getting a biology degree from Queens College
column88: he went as far west -- and as far from home -- as possible
column91: where he earned master's degrees in anthropology and botany from the University of Hawaii. Throughout the late 1960s and early 1970s
column93: Fiji and other South Pacific island nations to study traditional herbal medicine. His new wife
column97: often accompanied him on his travels. Local healers warmly welcomed him
column98: and he became passionately convinced that their expertise could be used to cure modern ailments. Thus began a quest to salvage-- not savage-- this "ethnic wisdom" before Western influences destroyed it. His research on the sedative kava kava and other Fijian medicinal plants served as the basis for his doctoral work at U.C. Berkeley. His 1978 dissertation
column99: on file in the U.C. Berkeley library
column100: shows his degree was in nutritional ethnomedicine. However
column101: the bio in the back of Savage's book and on his Web site says it was in epidemiology and nutrition science.   In 1974
column102: Weiner moved to the San Francisco Bay Area. His family first settled in Fairfax
column103: a sleepy town in Marin County that Michael Savage would lambaste three decades later as "un-Fairfax
column104: hometown of Taliban Rat Boy" John Walker Lindh. From there
column105: he started making trips into San Francisco to hang around the North Beach literary scene. According to Stephen Schwartz
column106: who was then a left-wing activist and writer
column107: Weiner carried an unusual letter of introduction. "He had met Allen Ginsberg in Fiji
column108: he recalls. He had this photograph of himself swimming naked with Ginsberg." Poet and biographer Neeli Cherkovski says Ginsberg and Lawrence Ferlinghetti
column109: the owner of City Lights Bookstore
column110: introduced him to Savage in 1976. "All I knew was that he was this hip guy who'd been traveling in the South Seas
column111: finding ways to use tropical plants to help end diseases
column112: he recalls. The two became friends. We had a lot of fun times. He's very smart
column114: says Cherkovski, who is now writer-in-residence at San Francisco's New College. Weiner told Cherkovski that he dreamed of becoming a stand-up comic in the mold of Lenny Bruce and they talked of doing a comedy routine together.   But he didn't make the big splash he had hoped for. Schwartz says Weiner's increasingly bizarre behavior eventually alienated him from the North Beach crowd. After he had been there a while
column115: his personality began to change. He became much more aggressive. He would collar you and demand that you eat with him
column117: he says. According to Schwartz, Weiner openly carried a gun and made public scenes when he ran into his former friends and acquaintances. He would come into Cafe Trieste and start yelling at me that I was a nobody and he was a somebody."   Today
column118: Savage still has few kind words for his old lefty literary friends. In "The Savage Nation
column119: he writes off City Lights as that once-famous communist bookstore" and rips into an unnamed beat poet
column120: calling him "latrine slime." "Now he just screams at us in the streets
column121: sighs Ferlinghetti, who once went to Hawaii with Weiner and his family. He views Weiner's reincarnation as Michael Savage as total opportunism
column122: the crowning achievement of someone who was always looking to make a fast buck" and "always trying to think up new schemes to get famous."   Weiner did have a knack for combining the promise of herbal medicine with good old-fashioned hucksterism. From his home
column123: he started vanity projects such as the Fund for Ethnic Medicine and the Alzheimer's Research Institute
column124: which he plugged on his book jackets and in letters to the New York Times. He concocted feel-good beverages like Tea of Life and Herbal-Seltzer and sold a line of herbal supplements from a Web site called Herbs That Heal. Visitors to the now-defunct site were welcomed with photographs of Weiner collecting herbs in the South Pacific
column125: soulfully soaking in the culture of what Michael Savage belittles as the "turd world." The 1992 edition of "The Herbal Bible
column126: published by his wife's imprint, Quantum Books, modestly noted that its author was credited with starting the herbal revolution."   He was also a prolific writer
column127: churning out 18 titles in 20 years. "[D]on't assume for a minute that they were junk books and marginally published
column128: he snaps in The Savage Nation." "They weren't. They were top of the line. They were the Rolls-Royce of the field." "Earth Medicine -- Earth Foods" and "Weiner's Herbal" are well-respected references and are still cited widely on herbal and homeopathic Web sites. Most of his books
column129: with their glorified lists of plants and their properties
column130: are about as dry as a handful of powdered dogwood root (which
column132: makes a good tonic for treating fevers). But buried in the details is a sprinkling of flaky affirmations and kooky assertions.   For example
column133: in "Plant a Tree: a Guide to Regreening America
column134: Weiner wrote dreamily about our plant allies" and suggested that every state appoint its own "tree czar." "Dictators seem to like trees
column135: he ruminated. Who knows what a benevolent
column136: nature-loving tyrant might do for the retreeing of America?" In "The Way of the Skeptical Nutritionist
column137: he ventured that a person's ideal diet should be determined by his or her ethnicity. Getting Off Cocaine: 30 Days to Freedom" promised blow addicts "an alternative plan for getting 'high' -- legally and naturally!" The treatment involved ingesting a daily cocktail of Sudafed
column140: as well as self-administering the occasional coffee enema. "Use a good quality coffee
column141: Weiner advised. Not decaffeinated or instant."   Michael Savage's homophobic rants against what he calls "anal rights" were foreshadowed by the 1986 book "Maximum Immunity." In it
column142: Weiner glommed onto some of the wilder ideas about AIDS that were circulating at the time. He called for mandatory nationwide AIDS testing and suggested using massive doses of vitamin C to slow down and even reverse the disease's progress. When he was done suggesting cures
column143: he looked for scapegoats. He demanded that gays "accept the blame" for the rise of AIDS
column147: and use street drugs are not likely to respond to reason."   "Maximum Immunity" also hinted that its author was dealing with some heavy issues of his own. In one passage
column148: Weiner wrote about his decision to take up jogging so that he might avoid his father's untimely fate. Everything went well until he started hearing things. "An inner 'voice' began to demand
column149: 'Stop ... I can't take this anymore.'" he wrote. Fearing a "nervous collapse
column150: Weiner traded his running shoes for a bike and soothed his jangled nerves by curling up on the sofa with a mug of passionflower herbal tea and ingesting megadoses" of vitamins. Feeling much better
column151: he concluded: "I learned to calm the inner debate that had threatened to drown me in madness!"   Such extreme mood swings are regular occurrences on "The Savage Nation." Even the phrase "I can't take this anymore!" (usually shouted at full volume) has become a Savage catchphrase. James Hilliard
column152: who produced "The Savage Nation" at KSFO for nearly three years in the late 1990s
column153: says that talk radio provided Savage with an outlet for his unpredictable temperament. As he recalls
column154: "The show was really driven by Michael's mood. At times
column158: and then be a maniac on the air."   This maniacal tendency
column159: and the roiling emotions that fueled it
column161: Michael Weiner's first and only book of fiction, published in 1983. A collection of confessional, stream-of-consciousness stories, it follows the exploits of Samuel Trueblood, who just happens to be a 40-ish New York Jew, an herbalist and writer with a tumultuous personal life, a substantial assortment of inner demons and a bit of a Napoleon complex. I am physically not tall
column162: but my eyes burn with fire
column163: he states. Two black fires of Hell." Trueblood narrates a series of misadventures
column164: from procuring an illegal backroom abortion for his fiance to beating the stuffing out of an abusive cop.   Trueblood describes his life as one long search for inner peace. He blames much of his discontent on his "childhood beneath tyranny
column165: during which he was cowed by his bullying father. Trueblood describes how his father mocked him with brutal jokes and chides
column167: are you Sam?' the little man would say each time the boy dared wear a colorful shirt or flashy trousers." Unable to shake his dead father's disapproving influence
column168: the adult Samuel is tortured by feelings of weakness and inadequacy. "I am filled with fears
column169: he admits, nearly all the time feeling I am about to become totally insane."   Even after moving to mellow Marin County
column170: becoming a successful herbalist and starting a family
column171: Trueblood remains plagued by his "underlying sadness." Not even trusty passionfruit tea can bring him off this bummer. In one passage
column172: he almost loses it in front of his wife and two young children:   "Inner voice screaming at me for years
column175: telling me to do mad things. Every form of relief tried
column182: etc. Almost uncontrollable now. Impulses to stab children
column186: Trueblood seeks solace in chasing skirts. (Though he admits to being drawn to "masculine beauty
column187: he confides that I choose to override my desires for men when they swell in me
column188: waiting out the passions like a storm
column189: below decks.") While his wife stays home with the kids
column190: he beds a young "cockswell" with a "dykish haircut" and skin "[s]ofter than that Northern Indian prostitute in Fiji whose covering was as soft as that of my own penis." And so it goes for another 50 pages.   No doubt the anti-abortion
column192: pro-family Michael Savage would disapprove of such a perverted excuse for literature
column193: with all its gratuitous references to illegal abortions
column194: repressed homosexuality and shameless philandering. But it's impossible not to notice the similarity between Trueblood
column197: a man whose "inner voice" precipitated an existential crisis over jogging. Neeli Cherkovski says that the chapter in "Vital Signs" about Trueblood's father is based on Weiner's own life
column198: recalling that he went with the author back to the Bronx to see the site of his father's store. But Cherkovski won't speculate about the rest. "I think he [Weiner] is a person who had a lot of wild experiences
column199: Cherkovski says. He tested a lot of waters." Even the book's dedication
column201: suggests that he wasn't making everything up: "Who would listen to such tales and live with he who lived them but she
column202: the unshakably faithful Janet."   For most of the 1970s and 1980s
column203: Weiner focused on curing people's illnesses
column205: I was the revered herbal doctor
column206: he recollected at the Radio & Records convention. I was Mr. Nice Guy Nutritionist. Nobody knew my politics. I was talking about healing and I'd go to health food conventions and I'd give speeches about vitamins and herbs. Nobody ever saw this as controversial ... They liked me!"   But beneath the surface
column207: Weiner was becoming more and more conservative. Stephen Schwartz
column208: who went from being a self-described Trotskyite to neoconservative and is now senior policy analyst at the Foundation for the Defense of Democracies
column209: says that Weiner was a "typical left liberal" in the 1970s. Neeli Cherkovski
column211: notes that Weiner was not homophobic when they first met. However
column212: he says Weiner's shift rightward coincided with his increasing aversion to gay activism. Robert Cathcart
column213: who's been close to Weiner since the mid-1980s
column214: says he's always known his friend as an outspoken conservative
column215: at least in private.   Since Weiner's conservative leanings took a hard right turn
column216: he's complained that he was held back because of his race
column217: gender and political beliefs. He currently gripes that no institute of higher education would hire him
column218: despite his qualifications. "I discovered I could not gain a professorship even after applying many times
column219: he writes in The Savage Nation." "My crime? I was a white male." The rsum he has presented over the years tells another story. On air
column220: he's mentioned that he was once affiliated with Harvard. On the back of his books
column221: he has boasted of being a faculty member at U.C. Santa Cruz
column222: a visiting scholar at the Hebrew University School of Pharmacy and a senior research fellow at the University of Heath Sciences at Chicago Medical School. He's also claimed to have done "important research" for the National Cancer Institute at the National Institutes of Health. Not bad for someone who's been blacklisted from the ivory tower.   The last straw apparently came in 1994
column223: when publishers rejected Weiner's latest manuscript
column225: which contended that infectious diseases such as T.B. were being brought into the U.S. by Southeast Asian immigrants. Fed up, Weiner rented a recording studio in Sausalito and produced a mock talk show with his wife and a couple of buddies playing callers. Michael Savage was born.   In his new job, Savage employed all the self-promotional tricks he had picked up while going from Charles Darwin wannabe to world-famous herbal expert. In early 1996, he applied to become dean of the U.C. Berkeley Graduate School of Journalism. Unable to appreciate the journalistic qualities of Savage's radio program or his 18 books, his alma mater denied him an interview, instead hiring China scholar and journalist Orville Schell. Savage sued Berkeley with the help of a conservative legal fund started by David Horowitz (who wrote approvingly of the case in Salon), accusing it of discriminating against a conservative in favor of a man he has called a front for the communist Chinese mafia." The case never went to trial. During the run-up to the 2000 election
column226: Savage laid claim to the phrase "compassionate conservative
column227: and said he planned to sue George W. Bush for intellectual property theft. Like many of Savage's threats of imminent litigation, this one soon faded away. But sure enough, he had self-published a book called The Compassionate Conservative Speaks" in 1995 and
column229: had trademarked the term in 1998.   Even Savage's two kids were swept up in his relentless drive for publicity. His Web site advertised Rockstar
column230: a liver-cleansing beverage marketed by his son that enables its drinkers to "party like a rock star." Last spring
column231: Savage told his listeners about a third-grade teacher in San Diego
column233: who had saved a child from choking
column234: and demanded that the state school superintendent give her an official commendation. "If she was a minority teacher and picked up a paper clip on the floor
column235: then a commendation would be in order
column236: he sniped. He neglected to mention that the hero teacher
column237: Rebecca Lin Yops, was in fact his daughter, who had changed her last name after her recent marriage.   Armed with his natural loquaciousness and a kill button, Savage's love affair with the sound of his own voice deepened. Obsequious fans obliged him by calling him Doctor Savage
column238: prompting him to expound his theories on how gays and immigrants spread disease and were corrupting the nation. It's the greatest revenge there is
column240: he crowed in The Compassionate Conservative Speaks." And as his rhetoric became ever more grandiose and outrageous
column241: his ratings -- and political clout -- grew. "The Savage Nation" became the Bay Area's No. 1 drive-time radio program. Savage lunched with Democratic San Francisco Mayor Willie Brown and started landing big-name conservative guests such as Benjamin Netanyahu and Vice President Dick Cheney
column243: apparently unaware of the show's usual host-centered format
column244: commended Savage for "providing a forum where we can have a good discussion."   Looking for a way to leverage his newfound influence
column245: Savage founded the Paul Revere Society
column246: a political club whose goals have included the imprisonment of antiwar activists for sedition
column247: loyalty oaths for immigrants and the eventual establishment of "a haven for compassionate conservatives" called "Revere-Town." A fee of $40 gets new members a Savage Nation baseball cap and an anti-affirmative action pamphlet called "The Death of the White Male." There's also the promise that one day they might get to meet the founder and executive director in person. But given Savage's reclusiveness
column248: they may have to wait a while. The group's last major event took place in November 2000
column249: when it held its fifth annual "Compassionate Conservative Convention" in San Rafael
column250: not far from Savage's home. Since then
column251: Savage made himself available to fans only at dinner parties
column252: and only after they forked over more than a hundred bucks. Meanwhile
column253: according to papers filed with the IRS
column254: this nonprofit "educational organization" took in over $150
column255: 000 in donations in 2001 and expects to take in $250
column256: 000 this year.   The success of "The Savage Nation" and its spinoffs is the culmination of a lifelong quest for attention
column257: fame and money. And that raises the question of whether Michael Savage is just a persona created to milk conservatives and taunt liberals. Robert Cathcart thinks his old friend intentionally exaggerates his politics and personality to get a rise out of his audience. "It's showmanship
column258: he says. He makes enemies of everybody. He doesn't believe half the stuff he says. On air
column260: but he quiets down at home." Former "Savage Nation" producer James Hilliard concurs. "I think Michael does have an excellent sense of putting on a show
column261: he says. I think he learned or was told at an early point that this is an entertainment medium
column262: and he thought of himself as an entertainer."   However
column263: as Savage rips into another hapless caller or gets exercised about the latest liberal atrocity
column264: it often feels like he's crossed the line between public shtick and personal catharsis. On the air
column266: truly living up to the warning of "psychological nudity" advertised at the beginning of every show. This is what makes "The Savage Nation" so simultaneously maddening and fascinating -- as Savage heads over the brink one more time
column267: you have to wonder whether someday he'll go over for good. Cathcart and Hilliard are right when they say the show is not just about politics. But it's not just about entertainment
column268: either. It is about one man grappling with his ambitions and fears while America listens. For Michael Weiner
column269: talk radio is the ultimate talking cure.

column1: If you own cats
column2: and are interested enough in cats to actually buy and read this book
column3: the only things that will strike you as new ideas are Newkirk's dogmatic beliefs about the welfare of our feline friends.  As a long-time vegetarian
column4: bordering vegan
column5: I have little problem with the suggestion that cats can be mostly vegetarian. However
column6: a strict vegetarian diet isn't best for *most* cats
column7: and can cause - in some cats
column8: particularly males - struvite crystals in the bladder which are excreted
column9: painfully
column10: in their urine. This is because a plant diet does not have the acidity that a meat diet has - not because of a deficiency in protein
column11: fat
column12: or nutrients - as some reviewers suggest. Specially formulated
column13: highly acidic brewer's yeast can help in this area
column14: but a fail-safe method is to incorporate small amounts of meat
column15: and do a heck of a lot of research. For example
column16: our cats are pesco-vegetarians
column17: and thrive on a diet of Evolution dry kibble - with small amounts of salmon or tuna every few days.   My biggest problem with Newkirk's take on cats is that they should be kept 100% indoors
column18: and the assertion that death (is that the 250th thing you can do to make your cat adore you?) is a preferable alternative to allowing a cat to roam outdoors. I imagine Newkirk doesn't have children
column19: and this is a lucky thing
column20: because she would likely lock them in a padded cell for fear that they might stub their toe. Or maybe she'd just kindly euthanize them? Eeks. Not all cats are happy being indoor cats
column21: and one has to decide if the possibility of death
column22: perhaps in painful circumstances
column23: is worth the risk when this is the cat's inclination and the only way some cats are truly happy.   Of course this doctrine comes from an animal rights group that has been noted for euthanising 85% of the animals it takes in - a far greater number than many public animal shelters (San Francisco Chronicle
column24: June 23
column25: 2005). And that
column26: honestly
column27: is my biggest gripe with this book
column28: and with PETA in general. Hypocrisy of this sort - PETA is riddled with it - leaves me feeling we have the wrong group representing the rights of companion and farm animals
column29: and that ultimately Newkirk's poorly researched
column30: dogmatic ideas leave us all (animals rights activists) looking like a bunch of nuts

column1: This book was very bizarre. It was recommended by a friend who said it was her favorite book of all time. I honestly couldn't wait until it was over and I almost stopped reading before page 50. A soulless
column2: scentless perfumer in 18th century France becomes a serial killer in order to extract the unique scents of his victims and create the ultimate perfume. The point of the book (if there is one at all) is that human beings are nothing more than easily manipulated animals
column3: victims of our own instincts and physical desires
column4: and that our arrogance of anthropological superiority is an illusion.

column1: I have not read this book but I am a real life Eunuch. I had my testicles surgically removed. In an Interview on Salon.com the author says "Castration does not get rid of the sexual drive
column2: get rid of erections or any amount of sexual activity." WRONG!!!  How would he know any way? He is NOT a Eunuch. He has had a vasectomy but that is totally different. I can speak from experience; when a man becomes a eunuch his sex drive drops to absolute zero. I had a very strong sex drive prior to castration but it is now completely gone. The only way for a Eunuch to regain his sex drive is to take some form of testosterone replacement. I have never heard of any real life Eunuch who was not on testosterone replacement therapy that had a sex drive. Don't waste your time on this book; the author obviously didn't do enough
column3: if any research. If you want to learn about Eunuchs then search the web. There are a lot of us out there
column4: and our numbers are growing

column1: Yesterday I helped my 10th grade sister with Politics and the English Language by George Orwell. I explained to her why Mr. Orwell says a double negative is bad English.   I highly recommend all the contributors to this book begin with the basics of writing in the English language. Strunk & White is a good read and not too long and I also recommend Mr. Orwell's essay to elucidate exactly why not not is not not not good English.   The most aggravating aspect of this book however isn't the piss poor English. I have school books for my MA in publishing I am supposedly to learn from that are full of grammatical and spelling errors every other page. It happens. I can deal with that.   No
column2: the worst part of this book are the factual errors that just make me want to throw the book out the window in a fit of rage at the sheer lack of research put into it.   Don't believe me? On page 626
column3: the author predicts that in possibly five years technology may be available that will prohibit users from making photocopies of protected material and that this technology may be commercially viable in seven to ten years.   If the author did the slightest amount of research
column4: he would know the technology is already widely used and has been for nearly a decade. The article on wikipedia about the EURion constellation can provide you all the details.  You know I'm really trying to give the book a fair chance. It is a textbook after all
column5: and I am trying
column6: I really am
column7: but I continually question the intelligence of the authors and their competence in the field they are supposed to be experts in every other paragraph.   Don't buy this book. And if you need it for school
column8: photocopy the parts you can stomach to read.

column1: Finishing this book was a lesson in patience. Don't bother with this waste of paper
column2: there are many other fine writers of christian leaning--g.k.chesterton and t.s.eliot come to mind--who can write without egregious fallacies. First
column3: RavZac asserts that his book counters the 'steady barrage of scholarly attack' which 'has been foisted upon religion' in general
column4: and on christianity in particular (p xiv). Paradoxically
column5: he then goes on to quote Kant's assurance(as representative of modern antitheistic thought)(p9) that spirituality is not threatened by Kant's antitheistic philosophies
column6: and also acknowledges that modern thought has been a natural evolution of human history (p6). Second
column7: RavZac continually correlates societal ills with modern intellectualism (p xiv
column8: xvii
column11: et al)
column12: and actually asserts causality between the two (p xvii
column15: he states that 'every generation raises the issue of life's essence' and discusses the long history of humanity's existential angst. If dissatisfaction with life is universal in all times and places
column16: and if the history of humanity is the history of pleasure as well as pain
column17: then where does RavZac get off when he tries to pin it all on modern intellectualism and philosophy? Finally
column18: he states 'that all philosophizing on life's purpose is ultimately two conclusions
column19: Does God exist? and What is his character?'(p8) He may hold such a view
column20: however he seems to be ignoring a vast record of philosophy that does not presuppose a theistic view
column21: let alone the monotheistic variant. RavZac is atrociously unrigorous in his sophomoric attempt at conversing with the great philosophers.  The foregoing should show that one needn't get very far into his book before being stumbled at his profusion of ineptitude. The entire writing has so borrowed pseudo-biblical language as to be cloying
column22: and RavZac thoroughly conveys his paranoid rhetoric by overutilizing key words such as 'warned
column23: aberrant
column24: terrifying
column25: unbridled
column26: unleashed
column27: attacks
column28: machinations
column29: trickery'
column30: etc. ad nauseum. In short
column31: this book is the religious version of political paranoia as discussed in Richard Hofstadter's THE PARANOID STYLE IN AMERICAN POLITICS
column32: 11/64.  There are no redeeming features of this writing
column33: save for giving the lucid reader abundant opportunities to identify logical fallacies and monitoring the addled ramblings of today's christian writers.

column9: but they don't make up for the poor quality of the rest of the text.  I regret spending money on this book
column10: and I really regret losing the time I wasted reading it.  7MAY06 - I've added to this review after receiving a few not helpful votes
column11: because
column12: in part
column13: I was concerned that my original review was too terse.  My opinion about this novel has not changed.  This is a series of stories about the life and adventures of Lazarus Long
column14: a man who has lived thousands of years and experienced
column15: effectively
column16: multiple lives.  That is
column17: he has loved
column18: married
column19: and 'built a life' several times.  He has now grown weary of the tedium of life and is contemplating suicide.  The novel consists of dialogue with some of his living decendants as he tells the story of his life.  Stories
column20: really.  Each major section in the book is a vignette in LLs life.  In theory
column21: this was a very good idea for a sci-fi novel
column22: but in practice
column23: this novel is simply tripe.  There are several things that I really dislike about this novel and would not recommend it to anyone.  Like much of Heinlein's later writings
column24: this novel explores alternate family relationship (i.e. a code for incest).  As I mentioned above
column25: one of the vignettes involves LL travelling back in time to bed his mother.  Another relates a `complex' (i.e. sexual) relationship between brother and sister.  Additionally
column26: most of the novel is dialogue between the characters
column27: there isn't much action.  I generally view this as a strength
column28: not a weakness
column29: but in this case the dialogue can be classified only as mindless banter loaded with sexual inuendo and overtone.  The characters on Beverly Hills 90210 had better lines.  If you are looking for a good science fiction novel
column30: this is NOT IT.  This is really a novel about alternate family relationships with some sci-fi elements (e.g. longevity and time travel) in the plot.  There are some who may find this type of novel compelling
column31: but from my perspective
column32: the author of `Starship Troopers' and `The Puppet Masters' fell a long way when he published this novel.  The Notebooks of Lazarus Long
column33: a collection of witty saying interspersed throughout the book are great.  Judging from the other reviews
column34: there are many who find this novel appealling.  Just be warned that this novel is very different than Heinlein's earlier classics.  There may be Time Enough for Love
column35: but most people don't have enough time in their life to waste on this silliness

column1: The book jacket for "The Ruins" offers a can't-miss premise:  a group of post-grad American tourists at play in Mexico jump at the chance for a little adventure among Mayan ruins but find but then find themselves in unimaginable danger.  It's the stuff of great Summer thrillers ready to be taken to the beach.  But 319 pages later
column2: the reader is left to wonder whether or not the publisher put the wrong book in the jacket.    Almost immediately
column3: you'll notice that Smith's writing is as dense as the jungles that make the setting.  However
column4: despite the endless stream of words
column5: his descriptions are often threadbare.  Plus
column6: there are no chapter breaks
column7: which eventually pushes the pace until it feels like an assignment to continue.    Next
column8: the characters themselves begin to fall flat.  There are only really two couples to keep track of
column9: and yet it's difficult for the first third of the book to distinguish them.  There is little to keep you interested in what they're doing or why they might be doing it.  Smith's attempts at developing these four as characters come in fits and spurts.  This seems obviously haphazard and hurried - the author is jamming in backstory whenever needed to explain characters' actions as if he were patching leaks in a dam.  By the end of the book
column10: the foursome seems to be as disinterested in each other as the reader is in them.    And for the readers who are hoping to discover something of interest in the setting such as Mayan mythology or archeological lore
column11: forget it.  Aside from language barriers with the locals
column12: there is no reason why this fantastical story couldn't have been set in the wilds of the Rocky Mountains
column13: the Saharan desert
column14: or anywhere else.  The danger posed has nothing to do with Mexico
column15: archeology or mythology at all.    Ah yes
column16: the danger posed.  Well
column17: I can't say much at all because anyone could give away the entire book with one line of explanation - that's how thin the plot is.  The numerous other reviews that fault this as a short story masquerading as a novel are exactly right.  Suffice it to say that when you do realize what the danger is (and you'll realize it well before any of the well-educated characters do)
column18: it's a real eye-roller
column19: as if to say "I read this many pages for THIS?".  By the time the story concludes
column20: it's more irritating than suspenseful.  The characters take so long to blithely undertake any course of action at all that you'll start rooting against them.  Eventually scenes of gore start piling up in an obvious and lazy attempt to interject some action
column21: but even aside from being misdirected
column22: it's too little too late.    This book could have been an adventure
column23: a supernatural thriller
column24: a survival tale
column25: or a horror screenplay.  It could have even taken the high road as an examination on people's reactions to situations of extreme stress:  some take the lead
column26: even enjoying the challenge
column27: while others whither into a shell of hopelessness.  But none of the possibilities ever come to fruition in this disappointing effort.

Readers interested in Benny Morris should read Israeli historian Yehoshua Porath's "War and Remembrance" in the summer 2002 issue of Azure. Porath adds to the Oct. 1995 and April 1990 discussions by Robert Satloff and Shabtai Teveth in Middle Eastern Studies and to Efraim Karsh's  excellent book
column2: Fabricating Israeli History. Don't read this book without looking at these critiques.   Why? Morris et al tell readers they have written "new" history of Israel
column3: considering the entire previous historical record as if it were solely propaganda for the Zionist cause. Here
column4: Morris considers Jewish conduct in the 1947 and 1948
column5: and why the Arabs fled.   Morris claims to be the first person to have looked at Israeli archives on the Dalet Plan
column6: a plan to move populations in certain areas. Nevertheless
column7: other scholars show that Morris and his peers in this book misrepresent themselves and the facts.   Firstly
column8: Yigael Alon and Israel Galili
column9: in The Book of the Palmah
column10: gave Walid Khalidi material to argue in 1959 that the Dalet Plan was "the master plan of the Zionists" to expell Palestinians wholesale. Furthermore
column11: the 1973 History of the Hagana (by Uri Millstein) included the entire Dalet Plan text. Official or not
column12: these 1959 and 1973 Israeli Jewish histories
column13: very shortly after the the 1948 war
column14: did not hide what happened
column15: as Morris claims here.  Morris also writes that Arab government archives were closed to his research and and to other historians writing on the Israeli-Arab conflict before him. He writes that he relied on Israeli and Western archives. But Porath
column16: Karsh
column17: Satloff and Teveth all show that this is not the case.   Furthermore
column18: Morris did no research at the Hagannah archives or those of the IDF
column19: a fact underlined by Efraim Karsh in 2002
column20: and one which he admits in a more recent book (The War for Palestine). Morris now writes that in the mid 1980s both those archives were closed to all researchers after all. He writes
column21: he was limited to few first-hand military materials
column22: indicating that there is no "new" research here at all.   Morris' charge that Israel carried out a deliberate and systematic expulsion of the Palestinian Arabs isn't even remotely substantiated by extensive research done since the mid 1980s. On the contrary
column23: Morris takes material very selectively
column24: from Israeli archive fringes and makes what Porath terms "outrageoulsy false claims"-- that Israel's victory resulted from "an imperialist conspiracy or an overwhelming advantage in manpower and arms."   Indeed
column25: Morris writes here that Arabs left Israel because of many factors
column26: their departure was not the fault of the Jewish people alone. Then
column27: he contradicts himself
column28: giving those who hate Israel grounds to blame Israel for the exodus
column29: without considering the other circumstances.   This book also details a so-called "massacre" in 1948 of Arabs at the village of Deir Yassin
column30: but not enough to mention that the incident was actually a battle--in which most Arabs killed (like those in Jenin in March and April 2002) were armed.   Finally
column31: Morris does not note (by comparison) other massacres in 1948--of Jews
column32: by Arabs. On December 30
column34: for example
column35: Arabs murdered some 50 Jewish co-workers at the Haifa refinery. On April 13
column37: they massacred over 80 Jewish doctors
column38: nurses and Hebrew University workers on Mount Scopus in Jerusalem.   Additionally
column39: nearly all of the 131 people who surrendered at the Etzion Bloc were also murdered by Palestinian Arabs. Only two survived.  These latter Arab massacres of Jews do not fit the blame that Morris seeks to lay at Jewish feet. Nor does the fact that Jews did not afterwards flee
column40: as occurred on the Arab side following the battle at Deir Yassin. So Morris omits them.   I also find it disturbing that the book nowhere mentions the equal refugee claim of 1 million Jewish refugees from 22 Arab nations
column41: who were expelled with nothing but the shirts on their backs
column42: and rebuilt their lives in Israel
column43: the U.S.
column44: and Europe.   The number of Jewish refugees was actually larger than that of Arab refugees (counting only those who fled
column45: not their descendants). Honest history would have noted these parallels as well as the entire context of the war.   --Alyssa A. Lappe

column8: but others who don't share the neo-con ideology will likely find many distractions

column1: My 3 boys (ages 4
column2: 7 and 9) love their lightsabers so the idea of a spring activated version was too hard to pass up.  Imagine the disappointment when the fragile spring/force action is only good for about 3 tries and then it falls apart with no way to get inside and fix it.  We have 3 of them (Darth Vader
column3: Obi-wan and Luke Skywalker). Vader was done before 9am Christmas morning. The other two are hanging on by a thread and now the boys have to be "very gentle" when they load the saber. Stick with the original light up sabers and forget the force action.

column1: Here's the news:less than half the forces on the allied side on D Day were from the  U.S. Would you guess that from reading Ambrose's book? - nope. The vast bulk of the volume is devoted to the U.S. experience. It seems Ambrose thinks the British
column2: Canadians etc were just there to make up the numbers.  It's just not acceptable for a historian to devote the bulk of what purports to be an account of that day to one national contingent and then call it 'D Day' . To perpetrate that is petty and appallingly parochial.  Worse: it's offensive to the memories of ALL those who fought and died for democracy. The American sacrifice was real and  doesn't need this sort of thing to keep its memory green.  Robin Neillands and John Keegan have both written much better
column3: fairer accounts.  If Ambrose had called the book 'the American contribution to D-Day' no one could have complained. As it is
column4: it has no claim to our serious consideration as history.

column1: I had the same problem described by R. Nielsen.  The gauge would not take a new reading after I pressed the release valve to let air out.  It only took a new reading if it was removed from the tire completely and reconnected.  I called the manufacturer
column2: who told me that it sounded like a problem and that I should return the gauge to them for a replacement.  I returned it to Amazon as defective and got a new one with the same problem.  I contacted the manufacturer again and they again asked me to send the gauge in for a replacement.  I have sent the gauge to the manufacturer at my expense.  The second replacement also had the problem.  Customer service told me that they had sent the second replacement from the wrong batch/crate.  Six weeks later (November 27th) I received a properly functioning gauge.  So it seems that a properly manufactured example of this gauge really does work properly.  There was just a very large run of defective ones.  At this point
column3: I would give this item 3 stars: 4 for performance and price
column4: minus one for the hassle involved in getting one that isn't defective.  If yours is defective
column5: you should contact Accutire customer service and let them know: 973-402-4240.

Nothing in this book added up well as it concluded. Baldacci let me down on this one
I really had a problem with this book.  This is my first encounter with Feist's work
column2: and I'm finding it difficult to give him a second chance.  From reading other reviews
column3: it seems that people who have read previous works by Feist derive some enjoyment from the world this book is written in
column4: as well as the presence of some familiar characters.  Since I lacked this prior knowledge about Midkemia and its inhabitants
column5: I was left to judge the book purely for the quality of the fiction
column6: and I found it to be uninspiring.    Talon is an incredibly shallow character.  His thoughts and actions are polarized and always single faceted.  If at any time during a book you can describe the complete emotional state of the main character in one word
column7: the author is probably doing something wrong.  While this is bad
column8: it is not disastrous; except when you consider that Feist conveys Talon's emotions to us in a totally uninteresting way.  I believe the addage is
column9: "show
column10: don't tell."  It didn't seem like any of Talon's emotions were real because they were conveyed in such a mind-numbing manner.  It seemed to me that Talon was forced along by the plot rather than guided by his emotions.  Furthermore
column11: Talon's transformation from mountain boy to noble swordsman extraordinaire was unbelievable to the point of being ridiculous.  How Feist can expect us to swallow this garbage while he skips over years of Talon's training and culturing is truly remarkable.  I do not have a problem with Feist's plot idea of turning a country bumpkin into a hero (it is a hallmark fantasy plot)
column12: but you have to make the reader believe it.  A few chapters of magic school
column13: snippets of verbal training

column1: A daring young atomic scientist teams up with three high school seniors to attempt the first-ever rocket trip to the moon -- that's the premise of Heinlein's Rocket Ship Galileo.  Readers who aren't immediately turned off by the story's wild improbabilities and dated subject matter may find this book an entertaining adventure.  To begin with
column2: Heinlein's story is well paced and solidly constructed for once
column3: a pleasant change from the episodic hodgepodges he created in his later years.  He skillfully introduces elements of conflict at an early stage of the story
column4: (as sinister forces seem to be trying to prevent the voyage from taking place) and he even manages to build some suspense
column5: an effect Heinlein is not usually noted for.  His descriptions of the mechanics of the moon rocket and its voyage are both convincing and interesting
column6: despite being badly dated.  One real letdown is the characters
column7: who are curiously undeveloped
column8: even for science fiction.  The three boys themselves are virtually interchangeable
column9: and Doctor Cargraves isn't much more distinctive.  If some attempt had been made to give these young men their own individual personalities
column10: the readers might find them easier to identify with.  As it is
column11: it's hard to really care about these characters
column12: even when something horrible happens to them.  The really big problem
column13: though
column14: is that this book really hasn't aged very well. For example
column15: Heinlein tries to show us how a moon rocket was outfitted and launched privately
column16: by one scientist and his youthful helpers
column17: working on a shoestring budget
column18: after a few months of labor; when after all
column19: any schoolchild knows that it took NASA and the U.S. government billions of dollars
column20: working with hundreds of the finest minds on the planet for nearly a decade
column21: to accomplish the real thing.  Once our heroes reach the moon
column22: the story gets even more improbable
column23: as they find that the moon is already inhabited.  Naturally
column24: Heinlein wrote this novel for younger readers
column25: and it was published at a time when space travel seemed utterly impossible.  As such
column26: it was written for the tastes of the times
column27: and times have changed dramatically.  For instance
column28: the only women in this book are the boys' mothers
column29: who have very little to say about anything important.  The villains are cartoonish stereotypes
column30: who are summarily dispatched without any show of remorse.  Although the book is reasonably well-written overall
column31: and older readers may take some nostalgic pleasure in its simplicity and naivet
column32: today's young readers may want something more wildly speculative than a moon landing.  On average
column33: if you're old enough to remember Sputnik
column34: you can be forgiven for loving this book; but if Neil Armstrong is just another boring guy you heard about in school
column35: you probably won't be too impressed by Rocket Ship Galileo

column2: useful format

column5: the method the author recommends is that essentially *all* meaningful
column6: complex (or
column7: as the author prefers "boring") content be removed from the presentation. Presentations then become nothing more than catchy headlines and colorful graphics. All content should be in the presenter's notes (not typically to be provided). This is juvenile and useless and frankly reflects a complete lack of understanding of how presentations are made in a complex business environment.
