column2: and have found them to be uniformly excellent -- except for this one.  An experienced climber
column3: backpacker and hiker
column4: I recently completed a loop hike described in this book (Needle Mountains
column5: Winnemuche Wilderness in Colorado).  Surprisingly
column6: my hiking companion and I found the time estimates given for each section of the hike to be laughably incorrect (i.e.
column7: at least 50% too short in duration).  I then checked time estimates given for other hikes I have done in past and found the same problem (e.g.
column8: backpacking into the Cirque of Towers in the Wind River Range from the Big Sandy trailhead takes 6 hours -- pure rubbish).  I am now quite suspicious of the book's accuracy
column9: and wonder whether anyone who wrote the book actually undertook the described hikes.  I was also quite annoyed with the gratuitously sniffy descriptions sprinkled throughout the text
column10: such as "the poor food and urban sprawl characteristic of the Rocky Mountain region" -- remember
column11: however
column12: that the book's authors are British.  Save your money for better books written by local writers/hikers who actually know the trails.  Tom Woods Lyons
column13: Colorad

column1: If you want to get introduced to the radical conservative concept in plain english you can probably read the book. The book
column2: quite disappointingly
column3: doesn't present logical arguments which is quite putting off for a rational reader. I'll quote an example from Chapter 9 (Why Government Is The Problem):   "It is one thing for the government to provide the basic necessities of life to the "truly needy
column4: people, a group that would include the poor, the sick and the disabled. It is another thing for government to take resources from one middle-class family and give them to another middle-class family. This happens when, for example, the government builds a mass transit system. People who prefer to drive cars must prefer to pay for the transportation preferences of the people who prefer to take the subway.  Now from above argument it seems that people driving cars are doing some kind of charitable favour to people taking the subway. But how about people riding in subways paying for the freeways/highways other people drive their vehicles on.  And similarily all over the book the arguments are pretty loose and unappealing. Another example in chapter 14 (Why Professors Are So Left-Wing):   "Conservatives tend to go to business because they care more about money; liberals tend to into the academy because they care more about power".  I am not sure if I understand the above argument but it seems illogical for people to join academia if they are hungry for power - don't know if there is a "How to become a US Senator for Dummies" but I don't think it would recommend becoming a faculty member in an Ivy League school if one is looking for a seat in Congress.

column1: I had heard that this film was "really funny" and "worth watching".  I'm not a big Adam Sandler fan but I am a fan of Kate Beckinsale and Christopher Walken.  I was sorely disappointed with this film.  The audience can't relate to the main character at first because he is just down right irritating.  I was hoping that the gags would get funnier but they didn't.  I also found most of the film rather depressing as we watch the main characters life being slowly destroyed around him.  Overall Click was ok
column2: Kate Beckinsale looked beautiful as usual but even that was not enough to save it.  I would NOT recommend buying this film.

column1: I have three qualms with this book:   1. The characters become so painfully annoying over the course of it's 175 pages that
column2: by the time the story has completely unfolded
column3: we just don't care about what happens or might happen to them.   2. The book takes the moral highground. This is perhaps it's greatest flaw; the narrator
column4: David
column5: is painfully opinionated on all that surrounds him. I know this is something that can never be completely avoided in a first-person narrative
column6: but it could have been handled with a lot more grace than what Larry Watson has done here.   3. The story is uninteresting. Not meaning to belittle Larry Watson's talent as a writer
column7: because he certainly has a knack for descriptions of people and place
column8: but we simply don't care about the majority of the events that unfold.   Read something else; save yourself from boredom and disconnection.

column1: This 1987 thriller focuses on Norman Johnson
column2: a psychologist who specializes in large disasters like plane crashes.  As the novel opens he is being taken to an undisclosed site by the US Navy.  Johnson learns that the crash site is located 1000 feet under the South Pacific and the craft is some sort of a space craft.  He was been included because of work he did sometime before organizing a first contact team for a previous administration
column3: an assignment that Johnson would just as soon forget.  Once the team is taken to the Navy deep sea facility and begins to study the craft Johnson begins to find disturbing circumstances - that the Navy commander has been less than honest with both the team and his superiors and that the craft itself bears a remarkable similiarity to current human technology
column4: labels and directions are even written in English
column5: leading the team to question just how alien this technology really is.  The suspense continues to build as the undersea facility loses their support ships above due to inclement weather and then conditions in the facility itself begins to turn hostile.  This novel is quite predictable
column6: just a few pages into the story it is obvious to anyone who has ever seen a disaster movie that there will be no comforting support ships nearby
column7: that the undersea environment will become threatening
column8: there will be many deaths
column9: there will be sexual tension between the hero and someone else and so on.  While there is some slight redemption in the last few pages this book is a big disappointment
column10: Crichton is capable of so much more.  If you are a fan read it but be forewarned
column11: if you are unfamiliar with his work begin with anything but this.

column1: I can't judge the Tai Chi but the Yoga in this video was not well done.  The producers hired attractive women with gorgeous bodies and large breasts--but no Yoga skills.  Director:  John McTiernan Cast:  John Travolta, Connie Nielsen, Samuel L. Jackson, Timothy Daly, Giovanni Ribisi, Brian Van Holt, Taye Diggs, Dash Mihok, Christian de la Fuente, Roselyn Sanchez, Harry Connick Jr. Running Time:  98 minutes Rated R for violence and language.  John McTiernan's (the mastermind behind Die Hard") "Basic" opens up in a rain-drenched Panama jungle at night on an Army training mission headed by Sergeant West (Samuel L. Jackson). Flash forward to the next day. An Army chopper picks up two men from the training mission
column18: one injured and one very much alive. The injured man
column19: Kendall (Giovanni Ribisi)
column20: is sent to a hospital
column21: and the alive man
column22: Dunbar (Brian Van Holt) is sent in for questioning by the very sexy and very Southern Osborne (Connie Nielsen). Dunbar refuses to speak to anyone except a Ranger. So in comes Ranger Tom Hardy (John Travolta) to piece together the events surrounding the death of Sgt. West and his team.  Most of the film takes place at night
column23: during a rainy hurricane
column24: and adds to the nonexistent plot. What is so intriguing is that the plot isn't really there
column25: but the writer tries to manifest one
column26: and we feel as if we are staring at some nonexistant
column27: material wad of words and flashbacks and images thrown together in a blender
column28: the writer hoping for it to come out smelling of roses.    The writer of "Basic"
column29: James Vanderbilt (whose screen crudentials consist of "Darkness Falls")
column30: has so many twists and turns that the film is impossible to keep up with. It becomes hard to seperate present from past and what's real from what's not. So many revelations happen that the audience will feel they are in the middle of the writer's mind
column31: as he comes up with new ideas and tries to squeeze them in time after time after time. There is a limit to how many times you can use "surprise" revelation endings. Vanderbilt uses three of four in a row
column32: piled on top of each other
column33: time after time after time. Just as we think the plot twists are done
column34: and we start to smile because we think we might finally understand the basis of the plot
column35: something else happens
column36: and we zoom in suspensefully on John Travolta's face as he
column37: along with the audience
column38: realizes something.  The performances of Basic's cast are a mixed bag: Travolta is watchable as usual
column39: and he brings a believable sense of self-assured cool to Hardy
column40: but he is frustratingly unable to contain his hammy instincts. The quality of a Travolta performance appears to be inversely proportional to the volume of his voice.  When he's quiet
column41: he's very good; when he yells
column42: he quickly becomes a cartoon. This movie has enough credibility problems; it doesn't need a cartoon hero.  If Travolta is mixed news
column43: Connie Nielsen is plain bad. It's not so much that she can't seem to make heads or tails of the convoluted story - heck
column44: no one can. But she seems less to be stymied than just exceptionally stupid. The scenes that are supposed to establish romantic tension between her and Travolta fall laughably flat. To top it off
column45: she is saddled with some Hollywood nimrod's notion of a Southern accent
column46: which blinks on and off like a turn signal. The smaller roles
column47: though
column48: fare much better. Van Holt as the prisoner does especially well
column49: flavoring his defiance with feral intelligence. There is also nice work by Taye Diggs as the unit's misfit and Tim Daly (where has he been since "Wings" folded?) as the base commander. The most memorable
column50: though (and you sort of knew this already) is Jackson. He has the lunatic drill instructor bit down pat
column51: and delivers it with relish. His is the one character in Basic who is supposed to be larger than life
column52: in part because he is seen in flashback
column53: which means that we are seeing not the man himself
column54: but other people's impressions of him. In his commando sweater and poncho thrown over one shoulder like a warlord's cape
column55: he looks twenty feet tall and invincible. Still
column56: one of Jackson's great talents is his ability to project nuance and smarts to even the most unsubtle characters. His Sgt. West is the shadow leaning over the whole incident
column57: and the movie would have been smart to take more advantage of that.  The real disappointment in the supporting cast is the normally talented Giovanni Ribisi as the wounded survivor
column58: a hospital-ward weirdo who is supposed to seem mysterious but mostly comes off as jokey and annoying. Ribisi seems to have shoplifted his performance from Gary Oldman in "Hannibal"
column59: down to his marble-mouthed line deliveries.  Though "Basic" is shabbily conceived
column60: it is at least presented well by John McTiernan
column61: who manages to wring what tension may be had from the loopy script. The movie is lacking in the action set-pieces McTiernan usually employs
column62: but he nails the atmosphere just right. The use of weather to convey emotion is certainly overdone
column63: but it is still effective when done right
column64: as it is here. The pounding
column66: shadow-tinged interior lighting gives the movie the feel of an approaching end
column67: a kind of despairing resignation to horrible things. It's a shame that the drama can't keep up with its own visual metaphor.  It has its merits
column68: but strains your suspension of disbelief beyond the breaking point
column69: and washes its credibility away like bloodstains in a rainstorm.

column1: This fluffy take on the human element of DoCoMo's success will not teach you anything about the wireless industry in Japan or the U.S. and hardly poses as a model or case study for anything related to strategy or how to "become a global force". Check out the market cap for DoCoMo in the last year and a half and look at the value and return in their overseas' investments and you will see why DoCoMo is a typical example of floundering
column2: conservative Japanese management styles that aren't taking the world like a tsunami
column3: but trickling in with little or no impact. Global competitors look at DoCoMo's business model as something to emulate
column4: but their weak strategy and feet dragging business style make them a bloated telecom giant wasting away shareholder value. This books talks nothing of that and merely goes on and on about the success of i-mode
column5: which would be relatively interesting if you hadn't read about it ten times in Business Week or Forbes Magazine in the last two years. NOTE: We used DoCoMo as a case study in my Japanese business school and despite all sorts of flowery talk about the creation and success of i-Mode
column6: nearly every member of the class was critical of this company's overall global strategy

column1: Most people buy a UPS
column2: plug it in and never test it to make sure it works. I tested this device a number of times to make sure the software would at least shutdown the computer after an outage. I set it to shutdown Windows after 1 minute. Only the computer and a few small phone accessories are attached to it.   After power was cut
column3: it held the computer up and allowed it to shut down. Then I restored power to the UPS. AFter about 30 seconds
column4: it beeped
column5: clicked
column6: and temporarily DROPPED power to the computer while it was rebooting! So when it switches back from battery power it causes power to be interrupted. That is unacceptable. A UPS should never drop power to the attached devices after power is restored to it.

column1: OK
column2: so I'm a Zhang Ziyi fan.   Not a huge fan
column3: but enough that
column4: one day
column5: out of sheer boredom
column6: I decided to get this movie while surfing through Amazon.com.  The best part about this movie is that Zhang Ziyi is in it.  And that's it.  This is not one of her better movies
column7: definitely.  The plot is not that difficult to figure out.  What is hard to figure out is how and why things happen the way they do in the movie
column8: since nothing much makes sense.  What the filmmakers have tried to do here is disguise an incoherent and unrealistic plot as film noir
column9: by using dense layers of atmosphere.    The story starts in 1928 in Manchuria
column10: with Zhang's character
column11: Cynthia
column12: at the end of a love affair with a Japanese man
column13: Itami
column14: who is heading back to Japan.   Zhang appears in classic schoolgirl dress with pigtails.  In the next scene
column15: her brother
column16: who is involved in some sort of newspaper or anti-Japanese organization
column17: gets murdered by a pro-Japanese terrorist. Tears from Zhang Ziyi in both scenes.     Cut to 1931
column18: in Shanghai.  We meet Szeto
column19: and his girlfriend Yiling.  Like an old war movie cliché
column20: this brief scene of their happiness together is meant only to set up Yiling's tragic death in the next scene.  Szeto leaves on a brief trip
column21: and then on his return
column22: as he hurriedly leaves the train
column23: he accidentally grabs the jacket of a Purple Butterfly operative (presumably a professional brought in to perform the assassination of the Japanese agent Yamamoto).  Mistaken for the real assassin by the other Purple Butterfly members waiting at the train station
column24: they hand Szeto a briefcase containing info on Yamamoto and his organization
column25: and then chaos and shooting breaks out.  The original assassin
column26: realizing that Szeto has taken his jacket
column27: chases after him
column28: and is mistaken for an enemy by the other Purple Butterfly operatives
column29: who kill him.  Szeto is packed into a car by the Purple Butterfly operatives as they make their escape.  Yiling
column30: who has gone to the train station to meet her boyfriend
column31: chases after Szeto
column32: and is shot by Cynthia
column33: who has been watching the scene unfold.  Cynthia shoots some other people also
column34: all to help cover the escape of the Purple Butterfly operatives who have Szeto in the car.  Just three years later
column35: Cynthia has become a seasoned Purple Butterfly operative
column36: with the look of a mature young woman.    Confused?  Baffled? That's only the first quarter of the movie!  Like I said
column37: it's not hard to figure out what is happening in the movie.  What's harder to figure out is how and why things happen the way they do.  How does a schoolgirl get from Manchuria to Shanghai and in just three years is involved in killing people in public places?  Just what the heck is the Purple Butterfly organization?  Their goals and methods seem to be more along the lines of a quasi-governmental death squad rather than a resistance/liberation/terrorist organization.  But the movie states later on explicitly that they are not affiliated with the government or any other organization.  Why arrange to have this meeting and hand-off of a crucial mission assignment in a crowded
column38: chaotic train station?  Why have the only form of identification be this non-descript suit with a Purple Butterfly over the left chest?  It seems almost to be a parody of spy movie clichés to have this sort of Mission Impossible style mission assignment go wrong like this.    The rest of the movie goes along similar lines.  The pacing of the movie is excruciatingly slow.  There is very little dialogue in this movie.  Much of the movie is filled up by long tracking shots of people walking from point A to point B to point C
column39: as well as long close-up shots of their facial expressions.  I'm guessing that these boring interludes are meant to convey some sort of a Deep Meaning.   I got more deep meaning out of this movie
column40: in a much shorter time
column41: by watching it in Fast Forward mode.  8x speed was about right - I could still read the subtitles at that speed.     A few other comments:    A particularly odd feature of this movie that I noticed was that the three main male characters have this ectomorph body type that just isn't seen much anymore in either Western movies or in the Chinese martial arts movies
column42: where the male actors are built more sturdily.   These are REALLY skinny guys
column43: with some seriously narrow shoulders.  In a number of shots
column44: their heads look to be much larger than their torsos
column45: making them look like bobble-head dolls.    The final scenes are from classic film clips of war atrocities and other carnage inflicted on the Chinese civilian population by the Japanese invaders.  This is heavy duty stuff
column46: and remains an unsettled issue in Asia to this day
column47: a source of deep anger among the Chinese people
column48: and continuous denial by the Japanese.  It's too important of a subject to be casually tossed in at the end of such a lightweight and confused movie as this one.

column1: Why would a skid row alcoholic CHOOSE to live (and eventually die) in that condition?  Why would an otherwise caring mother CHOOSE to abandon/sell/prostitute her kids for drug money?  Why would a decent
column2: hardworking father CHOOSE to gamble away his life's work and his family's security?    Would anyone voluntarily engage in any behavior that is so clearly self-destructive?  Would anyone in complete control of their faculties promise a child or spouse
column3: with complete sincerity
column4: never to indulge again only to let them down again later that very same day?  No!    It's not as simple as Schaler would have you believe
column5: or as simple as the minds of the reviewers who agree with him.  Many with FIRST HAND experience trying to quit any addicive behavior have fallen time and time again
column6: only to eventually find their liberation in AA.  It's insanity to assert that an alcoholic in the throes of their addiction would choose to wake up malnourished
column7: with violent shakes
column8: a pounding head
column9: a failing liver
column10: and soaked in two or three of their own bodily fluids.  And do it over and over again knowing full well the inevitable and devastating consequences.  At the very least
column11: any MD will tell you that once physical dependence is achieved serious or even fatal consequences will arise if a substance like alcohol is withdrawn.  Doesn't sound to me like the addict has much of a choice in that situation.  Aside from one or two (very  hostile) reviewers here
column12: it appears that those who agree with this author really have no first hand experience with the issue.  I could easily say that cancer was not painful
column13: but I guess I would defer to those who have suffered with the disease.  Talk with people who've been there and experienced this first hand before you buy what this guy is trying to pass off as fact.

column1: A perusal of this book reminds me of a UK television show on which James "The Amazing" Randi
column2: pretending to be a "medium
column3: brilliantly and devastingly showed just how easy it is to be fooled by those who claim to talk to our dead relatives for us.  It seems that the need to believe, the craving to hang on and not let go, is powerful enough to bypass logic and rational thinking in our poor benighted species.  I would urge anyone considering laying out their hard-earned money to this or other mediums" to do a little research into the "cold reading" trick and how it works.  There are many ways to deal with grief and loss that do not involve superstition
column4: credulity or hefty amounts of cash.

column1: Skepticism  can be healthy
column2: but this book is an error-filled celebration of hollow
column3: misleading cynicism delivered with a surprising level of shallowness and lack of detail.  Sure this book points out some "legitimate" frauds and hoaxes
column4: but it does a lot of damage and leads people astray by suggesting that a lot of things are frauds and hoaxes that are not. It seems that Mr. Randi concludes that anything and everything he doesn't understand or have proof of is a fraud or hoax. One example: acupuncture.  Never mind that thousands
column5: if not millions of people have been helped and healed by acupuncture
column6: but even the American Medical Association has concluded that it is a legitimate medical therapy. But Randi includes it in his list of frauds and hoaxes.   There are many other examples where Randi errs and misleads
column7: or simply does not understand and chooses to cast aspersions (p on) what he is woefully ignorant about. In some cases he cites individuals who have supposedly exposed frauds or disproven claims and theories
column8: but the reader is left with little or no details to assess the claims of the "fraud buster."    In other cases
column9: a supernatural feat is presumed to have been disproven simply because someone else has managed to appear to replicate the supernatural feat by using sleight-of-hand or other trickery.    Not everything that is real and true can or needs to be proven by science or  proven to Mr. Randi. (A large portion of the history of science
column10: in fact
column11: is a history of proving that what science once concluded was unreal or unprovable is in fact real.)  If you accept on face value  everything that Mr. Randi wants you to accept
column12: your life will be much poorer for it.   This book will provide great reassurance for people who don't want to believe in anything other than their egos. As stated above
column13: this book is a great example of where skepticism has fallen victim to cynicism and that makes this book more harmful than helpful.  To a great extent
column14: I am very surprised and sorry to conclude
column15: this book itself is a fraud

column1: Let me say at the outset that I am not a macroevolutionist.  However
column2: Morris' simplistic caricature of biologists ("Darwin's theory of evolution is universally accepted among biologists"
column3: p3) is far from the only factor that makes this a disappointing book.  Morris is simplistic and repetitive
column4: and in addition to the typo's already mentioned by other reviewers)
column5: there are several examples of outright contradictions and misinformation that leave me scratching my head.  On page 21
column6: Morris states that "carbon-nitrogen dating...can rarely be used to determine the ages of rocks in geological formations."  In fact
column7: it cannot be used to date rocks at all
column8: only organic materials.  On page 25
column9: Morris states that "The solar system is full of such [organic] chemicals
column10: including amino acids-the components of proteins..."  I am not an organic chemist
column11: but to my knowledge none of the amino acids found in the proteins of living things have been found anywhere else in the solar system.  If they have
column12: it would certainly be in very limited places and quantities
column13: not littered about the whole solar system
column14: as Morris implies.  In addition
column15: only 6 pages later
column16: Morris states:  "Localized areas rich in organic chemicals are found in the fossil record.  These chemicals must have been produced by microbes of some kind."  Gee
column17: I thought you just said that the solar system was full of them!  On pages 33-34
column18: Morris states:  "It should not be imagined that they [the mammals] survived because they were somehow better adapted than the dinosaurs."  This statement directly contradicts the principle of natural selection
column19: which is the guiding light for evolution and is even accepted in a general sense by creationists.  On page 44
column20: Morris attempts to defend evolution by saying:  "Although many different kinds of genetic codes are theoretically possible
column21: all organisms use the same one."  He uses this as an argument for macroevolution.  However
column22: the logic behind it is fallacious
column23: for the following reason:  genetic code can be (and is) viewed as a language.  As a creationist
column24: it is perfectly reasonable to me that the Grand Author of Life would use the same language to code the information in all living things
column25: just as most earthly authors write all of their works in a single language.    On page 45
column26: under the heading:  Evolution is a Fact"
column27: Morris states:  "The idea that life on Earth has been evolving for 3.5 billion years is not a theory.  It is the only possible interpretation of the numerous different kinds of evidence that scientists have been discovering for well over a century."  Thank you
column28: Reverend Morris
column29: Pastor of the Darwinian Orthodox Church.  However
column30: on page 62
column31: Morris states:  "If scientific ideas ever became dogmatic
column32: then no new discoveries could be made."  If ever a contradiction existed
column33: surely this is it.    On pages 56-57
column34: Morris gives the beginning of a reasonably plausible explanation for the evolution of an eye
column35: until he says:  "Finally
column36: full
column37: complex eyes develop"
column38: thereby skipping the most problematic part:  the 20+ step biochemical process that occurs in complex eyes from the time that light strikes the retina until an impulse is sent to the brain.  (See Darwin's Black Box
column39: by Michael Behe
column40: if you want a fair discussion of the difficulties that the human eye poses for the theory of macroevolution).    I could go on and on
column41: but I will conclude by adding that I could forgive most of the evolutionary dogma (which is
column42: after all
column43: almost universal in books written by evolutionists) were the book not incredibly redundant
column44: error-filled
column45: and simplistic.  I got a little bit out of the part about evolutionary psychology
column46: but that it about it.

column44: and extras are rarely mentioned in credits.  But let me tell you an "inside story" on the making of this film:  We were shooting in a nightclub on the Sunset Strip.  The extras were divided into three camps: union
column45: nonunion
column46: and Modesto extras.  Union extras earn the most
column47: especially once overtime kicks in
column48: so they were wrapped after eight hours (they were only hired in the first place to fill a union quota).  This was during my nonunion days (I'm in SAG now)
column49: so I put in a full 14 hours
column50: after which we were paid in cash and wrapped.  The Modesto extras were still working when we left.  Now what
column51: you may ask
column52: is a Modesto extra?  I also wondered
column53: and so I asked one.  I was told they were from an acting class in Modesto
column54: California.  They had been bussed in to work on the film as part of a "class assignment."  In other words
column55: they were PAYING to come to work.  There's not a whole lot to learn about being an extra.  It's neither glamourous nor difficult.  And nonunion extra jobs for twentysomethings are VERY EASY to come by.  The lampposts in Los Angeles are covered with flyers seeking cattle
column56: ehr
column57: extras.  I did it for the cash
column58: and because if you do it often enough
column59: you increase your chances of getting into the union (which I did
column60: after some 13 grueling months).  NEVER PAY for the "chance" to be an extra
column61: not in Los Angeles.  I made the mistake of volunteering to be an extra a few times
column62: but wised up after a few months.  My guess is the producers of Embrace of the Vampire paid this acting teacher to bus down some cattle

column3: when a person writes a book whose predictions turn out to be completely wrong.  (Less wonderful when people keep buying his nonsense!)  A review of this book can be very brief -- just two points need be made:  1. There wasn't a great depression in the 1990s (to the posters who say there was a "recession" in the early 90s
column4: I say: the unemployment rate in the US during the real Great Depression was 25% at its peak.  It never cracked 6.5% in the 1990s.  A mild recession does not a depression make
column5: nor does it justify the title or apocalyptic tone of this book.)  2. Had the US adopted Batra's recommended policies -- dramatic increases in trade restrictions
column6: etc. -- there WOULD have been a depression.  One of the central causes of the real Great Depression was the Smoot-Hawley Tariff
column7: which increased tariffs dramatically.  Batra proposed similar measures in this book.  In other words
column8: in order to prevent a depression that never came
column9: Batra argued that we ought to adopt measures that caused an actual depression in the past

column1: A history of California
column2: from the founding years through to Gov. Schwarzenegger
column3: was always an ambitious undertaking
column4: one fraught with difficulties
column5: starting with how to approach it. A large
column6: diverse state with a complex history
column7: there are only a few options:  compile an encyclopedia
column8: focus on a few defining events
column9: or create lists.  Unfortunately
column10: Starr takes the last approach
column11: keeping the book to a short 350 pages
column12: but filling those pages with one or two sentences on every event and every major figure in California history.  Unfortunately
column13: while comprehensive
column14: the disjointed style and lack of detail on any topic make for painful reading.  Nearly every paragraph deserves its own book or at least its own chapter. The San Francisco earthquake of 1906 rates 3 paragraphs.    Here's one example taken at semi-random:  "The previous evening
column15: a drunken miner had tried to break into Josefa's cabin
column16: where she was living with her common-law husband
column17: also a Mexican.  Upbraided by Josefa the next day for his conduce
column18: the miner called her a whore.  Enraged
column19: she stabbed him to death."  This was the most interesting passage on the page I opened at random
column20: but it certainly needs to be its own story.  As a novel or movie
column21: this event could succeed in illustrating life during that period in California history
column22: but as half a paragraph
column23: it's just more event in a long list of things that happened.  When Starr turns to arts and literature
column24: the effect is even worse
column25: pages packed with names of artists and writers.  Starr seemed to feel the need to include every writer who ever even visited San Francisco.  Further
column26: parentheticals in nearly every sentence and a reliance on passive voice make the book feel as if it was dictated by a PBS narrator. Though cleared of footnotes and written in large text on small pages to appeal to a general audience
column27: Starr is clearly a historian rather than a writer. Possibly this would have been a more interesting book had it been written by a journalist or novelist rather than an academic
column28: though I expect that a journalist or novelist would realized that this undertaking was impossible and would instead have focused on one particular person or event.  In the end
column29: I felt that I learned more about California history by reading a book focused on a particular theme - for example
column30: Dennis McDougal's Privileged Son
column31: which in the process of telling the history of the LA Times through multiple generations of the founding Chandler family
column32: goes a good job telling the history of Los Angeles itself.  Overall
column33: this book is far too dry to recommend it to someone looking for an overview of California history
column34: and too cursory for anyone looking to learn anything about one particular time or place.

column1: This scope is not a good starter scope for anyone interested in astronomy.  Here's why:  1.  The objective is too small
column2: only 60 mm
column3: 2.36 inches
column4: so it is too small to bring in the light necessary for even a beginning look at the universe.  I suppose it is adequate for the moon
column5: but that is it.  The planets will appear as very small disks.  One will be able to see Saturn's rings
column6: but the image will be very small.  Forget it for deep sky objects
column7: clusters
column8: galaxies
column9: etc.    2.  The mount is an altazimuth
column10: which will not follow the celestial object in the sky.  The earth is rotating
column11: and anyone focusing on a star or moon will quickly find the object drifting out of the field of vision.  A better mount is an equatorial mount which makes it much easier to track objects.    3.  The 4mm eyepiece is too powerful for this scope.  The observer will find it hard to look through (very small eye opening)
column12: and will in most cases cause blurred images.  The 20 mm eyepiece is the only functional eyepiece.  The barlow is a 3x
column13: which again is too poweerful for this scope.    4.  The mount will vibrate when touched
column14: which will cause the image in the eyepiece to "shiver"
column15: which is very frustrating.    Even for the low price
column16: don't be enticed by this scope; it has too many flaws. Save your money for a larger scope with a better mount.    Jim "Konedog" Koenig
column17: astronomy buf

column1: First
column2: I should say that I haven't yet heard any of the Oasis records made after this one. Like most people I got into Oasis (as well as Blur) during the Definitely Maybe/Morning Glory years. When I heard "Be Here Now" I couldn't help wondering if the band had lost its edge. I liked The Master Plan a lot
column3: but as it was more a loose collection of B-sides than an album in its own right
column4: I didn't read it as indicative of a specific musical direction.   By the time I bought a cassette of SOTSOG during an April 2000 trip to the UK
column5: my Britpop tastes had moved on to Stereophonics
column6: Belle & Sebastian and Badly Drawn Boy. I listened to that cassette in my rental car all during the trip. I wasn't crazy about it. I really liked a couple songs
column7: but when I got back to the US I put the tape away and rarely ever listened to it until a few weeks ago.  So
column8: my take on SOTSOG:  Noel Gallagher has always written trite lyrics
column9: but the triteness was forgivable because his songs had great hooks and were loud and noisy and made you want to jump around. SOTSOG shows that when Noel goes mellow
column10: his lyrics quickly go from innocuous to annoying - and these songs generally aren't hooky enough to compensate.   Letting Liam join the songwriting guild was not a smart remedial step; at this stage
column11: Liam's simply a juvenile songwriter. I don't oppose the mellowing of Oasis
column12: but if they are going to turn the noise down they're going to have to ratchet up the hook quotient or come up with some more sophisticated lyrics. Noel's mellow tunes on The Master Plan ("Going Nowhere"
column13: "The Masterplan") came closer to achieving this balance.  That said
column14: the album has a few highlights. The Celtic raga-hymn "Who Feels Love" is one of the band's best songs
column15: ever; since the CD-single of this song is more expensive than SOTSOG
column16: the album is worth buying for this one song alone. Also
column17: "Go Let It Out" is pretty much vintage Oasis
column18: bright and crisp.  I like where Noel Gallagher is going. I'm interested to see if Oasis' post-SOTSOG output is better

column1: The most seemingly innovative part of Bruegmann's book is his attempt to create a history of sprawl.  His basic argument runs as follows: something vaguely resembling sprawl happened in ancient Rome and 18th-century Europe
column2: therefore sprawl will forever be with us
column3: therefore sprawl is unstoppable.  Bruegmann's argument fails because is that it totally ignores differences of degree. There is an enormous difference between   (1) a region where sprawl is just one lifestyle option among many and you can live an auto-free life in a city or a streetcar suburb (e.g. most of the United States in the 1920s
column4: the NYC region today
column5: and much of the rest of the world today)  and  (2) a place where buses stop running at rush hour and you need a car to be a functional member of society (e.g. some Sun Belt cities and most small towns).    It seems to me that situation (1) is indeed normal in an affluent society; situation (2) requires decades of bad public policies.     Moreover
column6: Bruegmann makes concessions that eviscerate his argument.  On the one hand
column7: he implies that sprawl is inevitable in an affluent society.  On the other
column8: he admits that many metro areas have grown more compact in recent decades
column9: and that cities are beginning to gentrify.  (I suspect that he was not quite sure whether he wanted to be balanced or to write a pro-sprawl polemic; sometimes he leans in one direction
column10: other times not).  His attempt to deny government's involvement in sprawl is sometimes a bit silly.  In response to the argument that government-funded highways spread sprawl by making it easier to live in suburbs
column11: he responds: "federal spending today goes more heavily per capita to central cities than to suburbs
column12: primarily because of the enormous price tag of social security payments
column13: which go primarily to an older population that remains disproportionately in the central cities."    First of all
column14: this "analysis" is factually questionable: many cities actually have a slightly smaller over-65 population than their suburbs.  (For example
column15: in Chicago
column16: where Bruegmann lives
column17: 10.3% of city residents are over 65
column18: as opposed to 11.3% of all metro residents).   Second
column19: highways affect where people live by making suburbs more convenient
column20: while social security benefits benefit a suburban retiree as much as an urban retiree. (I suspect that they are most useful for whoever lives in a low cost of living area where your money goes farther- which means cities in some parts of the United States
column21: suburbs in others).  Worst of all are the constant attacks against anyone who dares criticize the sprawl machine.  He constantly attacks sprawl critics as "elites."  This sort of "argument" exemplifies the ad hominem fallacy- attacking the person instead of the argument.    His attacks are as hypocritical as they are illogical; he brags about avante-garde architects who see "the spatial and ecological richness" of sprawl
column22: and ignores the fact that a "road lobby" of construction companies and real estate interests generously funds politicians who favor suburban development and sprawl-generating expressways. It seems to me that these media star architects or large corporations are just as much of an "elite" as the environmentalists Bruegmann villifies.  Bruegmann's substantive discussion of the vices of sprawl is
column23: by contrast
column24: occasionally useful.  Where the data is uncertain
column25: he (occasionally) says so; for example
column26: he correctly suggests that there is no way to know whether more compact development would reduce fuel consumption enough to affect global warming
column27: or how much of an effect sprawl has on taxes and spending.    But even in this part of the book
column28: Bruegmann sometimes cannot resist the temptation to overreach: for example
column29: he writes that "cause of [auto-induced air] pollution was neither sprawl nor the automobile itself
column30: but
column31: rather
column32: the inefficient fuel source it used."  Of course
column33: the "inefficient fuel source" only pollutes if it is actually placed in an automobile
column34: and if the automobile is actually driven- both of which happen more often under sprawl.

column1: Sure there are other movies that have butchered their source material beyond recognition
column2: but it's not even the butchering that's the problem. The problem comes when the director hits all the marks and completely misses the point of the book. Jan de Bont decided to take the atmospheric Haunting of Hill House and turn it into a carnival ride and give an easy explanation to the haunting. DePalma went and decided to tone down the racism in Bonfire of the Vanities. But those weird decisions to miss the point pale in comparison to Shlessinger's choice of turning a vicious novel into sentimental slop.  From the opening sequence with the tinkling piano music to the ending with Faye sighing at Tod's stupid rose
column3: this movie sets out to jerk tears and make the viewer feel bad. Even if there wasn't a great book to be killing
column4: this would be a terrible movie. But with Day of the Locust as a source material
column5: the awfulness of this movie borders on the criminal. One imagines the book done right by a Quentin Tarantino or a Todd Solondz.  Where the book is fast
column6: the movie is slow. Tod Hackett is supposed to be a fat cynical observer but Shlessinger decided to cast an anonymous pretty boy in his role. The casting choice is decidedly better with Donald Sutherland as Homer Simpson
column7: but Sutherland is emoting way too much pain for the humor to come through. Every time you see him you want to kill yourself and his abuse at the hands of Faye goes on forever.  The riot scene that ends the movie becomes a Night of the Living Dead ripoff and the whole thing just drags on. Furthermore
column8: the key sequence of the book (Tod imitating the police sirens) gets lost and Tod just cries and gnashes his teeth or something.  This is a terrible movie. The original book deserves much better

column1: The information is inaccurate according to historical records.  I would suggest reading "A Ghost Hunter's Guidebook" (Third Edition) by Troy Taylor and "So There I Was... More Confessions of Ghost Hunters" by Troy Taylor and Len Adams for more information on The Myrtles.  You can also do a search on the internet for the article "The Legends
column2: Lore and Lies of The Myrtles Plantation".  Or
column3: if you're ever in St. Francisville
column4: you can go to the courthouse and the historical society and check through the records yourself.  For instance
column5: Winter was indeed murdered on the front porch by an unknown assailant but after being shot
column6: he immediately fell down and died.  His bloody trip through the house never took place -- information that was easily found in historical records.  There is also no evidence to say that Judge Woodruff ever carried on affairs with his slaves.  Although the house is genuinely haunted
column7: which can be attested to by generations of owners
column8: guests
column9: and ghost hunters
column10: it is not haunted for any of the reasons that have been claimed in the publicity surrounding the house.  As has been said more than once - "when the legend is better than the truth
column11: print the legend".  This is an adage that has been closely followed by the Myrtles
column12: misleading hundreds of ghost hunters and enthusiasts over the years.  I do not discount paranormal activity at The Myrtles - just the legends that surround them.  Although
column13: some of the events in this book are not quite true to the nature of ghosts (read Troy Taylor's "A Ghost Hunter's Guidebook" (Third Edition) for more information on that).  I am compelled to say that the story about black kids having classes with black teachers and white kids having classes with white teachers and that there was a black lunch and a white lunch in school (when Ms. Kermeen bought The Myrtles) is not true.  I was in high school in Louisiana at the time Kermeen bought The Myrtles.  Black and white kids went to the same classes
column14: were taught by both black and white teachers
column15: and they all ate lunch together - and had been doing so since before I started school.  In 1980
column16: the federal government would not have allowed this separation to occur no matter what the local residents' feelings were on the subject.  My mother was a teacher in Louisiana at the time of integration.  By federal mandate
column17: black students and teachers and white students and teachers had to be combined - and it had to be as equal as possible.  This was not a choice and this happened way before 1980.  I am currently a teacher in the Louisiana public school system so I do know a bit about its history and the federal regulations governing the public school system.  This separation would absolutely never have occurred.  This story was too much like The Amityville Horror...more of a "Hollywood" type ghost story than a "true" ghost story.  It's a waste of money and it insults your intelligence.  This quote is from a booklet about The Myrtles: "James and Frances Kermeen Meyers passed through St. Francisville in the 1980s on a riverboat cruise and while visiting purchased the Myrtles. The Meyers ownership coincided neatly with the then-current fad of "Murder Mystery Weekends" in which local historians and surviving family members say that history was rewritten in a manner they consider "disgraceful"."  If you're interested in true ghost stories
column18: read books by Troy Taylor.  He's written quite a few

column1: I was very disappointed with this film.  I had hoped to learn about the "Birth of a Nation" and "prenatal" life in the region.  But the entire film is about postnatal fighting.  The film is appropriate for people who find fighting to be glorious - for people who like to keep score of battles and casualties like some kind of sports game.  This ugly film depicted the entire society as being barbaric.  In fact it sanctified the barbarism as being something heroic.  Surely the beautiful people and the rich culture of this region deserve more than this.  Surely the viewers deserve more than this History Channel pandering.

column1: As much as I try not to generalize from limited data
column2: I must make the following observation: sportswriters should stick to writing books about things they know
column3: i.e.
column4: sports. Sportswriters should NOT try to write about technical subjects like spaceflight. The prime example of a book that should never have been written is "For All Mankind
column5: by sportswriter Harry Hurt--the hands-down, all-time, worst-written, least accurate, most-full-of-breathtaking-technical errors spaceflight book ever. Too Far From Home
column6: by Chris Jones (also a sportswriter), is not nearly as bad, but it is still clear that the author doesn't understand some of the things he wrote about.  By the time I was 50 pages into Too Far From Home
column7: I was reeling from Mr. Jones' jarring, bizarre and oversimplified descriptions of spaceflight technology. Here are a few examples. He portrays NASA's early spacecraft as corrugated-tin capsules held together by hardware-store screws." What an injustice to the nationwide team of dedicated engineers and technicians who built what were
column8: at the time
column9: state-of-the-art vehicles. How about this one: during the final few seconds before a shuttle launch
column10: "the three main engines began gimbeling [sic]
column11: testing their directional thrust...throwing off a little push with each pull of the trigger..." Huh? What trigger? Who's pulling a trigger? It's a pre-programmed computer-controlled sequence. Here's another one. Just as the shuttle enters orbit: "...a loud clang signaled that the external fuel tank had been blown loose and begun to come apart..." Jones seems to think that the ET blows up as soon as it separates from the Orbiter. It doesn't--it stays intact until it re-enters atmosphere and burns up (mostly) half a world away from its release point.  Jones also apparently doesn't know much about airplanes. He describes air-to-air combat exercises in which missiles "punch holes through" the wings of drone aircraft
column12: "maybe spilling a few gallons of hydraulic fluid." A hole in a wing is much more likely to release fuel
column13: not hydraulic fluid
column14: since that's where an airplane's fuel tanks usually are. Describing test pilot Ken Bowersox's "twin-engine beater" personal airplane
column15: Jones says that the intrepid soon-to-be-astronaut "push[ed] his flying heap higher still
column16: sometimes high enough to catch a glimpse of the curvature of the earth." There's no airplane except for the likes of the SR-71 that can fly high enough for its pilot to see the curvature of the earth. NO private plane can do so.   I was also taken aback by Jones' interminable use of off-the-wall similes to express concepts in ways that many readers might relate to
column17: but that greatly sacrifice accuracy in the process. For example
column18: I sincerely doubt that shuttle crewmembers seated in the mid-deck during launch think of themselves as "...hiding out like stowaways
column19: like kids sneaking into a drive-in by getting locked in the trunk of a car." Locker-room and sports metaphors abound
column20: which I found tiresome after a while
column21: as I did his insistence on assigning motivations that he could not possibly know to virtually every person he writes about.  There is
column22: of course
column23: more to "Too Far From Home" than spaceflight hardware
column24: and some readers will probably enjoy the human-interest stories. But in a field such as spaceflight
column25: in which technology reigns supreme
column26: an author should at least get the technology right. Jones often does not. I have to wonder why
column27: and for whom
column28: he wrote it. Space geeks will find it maddeningly simplified and sorely lacking in technical understanding
column29: and need not bother reading it. I had to force myself to finish it. Casual readers may like its fast-paced
column30: easygoing style
column31: and may gain a little understanding of some aspects of spaceflight--but that understanding will likely echo the author's flawed knowledge. My recommendation to all readers is to give "Too Far From Home" a pass. There are many far superior spaceflight books available. I give it two stars just because it IS marginally better than "For All Mankind

John Rechy wrote a book that had a pronounced place in my adolescent life
column2: "City of Night
column3: in which he dealt frankly with homosexual male sexuality in the context of cruising and street sex, and I remember it as a vividly erotic piece of work.  It was with high hopes that I approached The Coming of the Night
column4:
in which he follows a number of characters through one day in Los Angeles puncuated by the fearsome Santa Ana winds, which charge and pump up all the players' sexual drives.  First problem:  too many characters developed too thinly.  Second problem:  for a book that deals almost exclusively with sex, it's not very hot.  Third problem:  Rechy attempts to portray the gay world at the moment AIDS explodes unbeknownst to his motley cast of men and, in order to do so, he resorts to the kind of lurid and weary detailing of s&m, gang bangs and porno shoots that was handled much more credibly in the pulp fiction of the 50s and 60s.  It's wonderful that Rechy is still writing and publishing; I would like to see him break some new ground next time around.  Dealing with life post-AIDS would be a fascinating area to see him work with. Only for the fans

column1: Restall's conclusions add nothing to what Tzvetan Todorov has already said in The Conquest of America-which Seven Myths gets wrong in its dismissal of Todorov's crucial point about the role of writing in the Conquest.  Merely being able to put information down on paper isn't the issue.  What Todorov means is much more complex
column2: and is grounded in evidence from anthropology to neuroscience (e.g.
column3: Ong
column4: Goody
column5: Havelock
column6: Panksepp).  First
column7: with written words fixed in front of you
column8: you can re-read
column9: check for inconsistencies
column10: compare to other accounts to assess accuracy and consider alternatives
column11: even elaborate.  You
column12: in fact
column13: practice thinking skills you have little opportunity to develop unless literate.  Restall also sees no reason to prefer an alphabetic system over
column14: say
column15: Aztec pictographs that interpreters used to recall memorized speeches embodying the culture.  But only with an alphabet can you unambiguously set down every single thing a person can think; and only then can an idea be fully worked out and fully critiqued.  Evidence shows that the way you think when you internalize an alphabetic written language is significantly more abstract
column16: analytical
column17: and adaptable than when you rely primarily on speech.  Second
column18: as Restall claims
column19: "disease
column20: native disunity
column21: Spanish steel
column22: and the culture of war
column23: are causes of the Aztec defeat, but, as Todorov rightly argues, they are only the immediate causes.  Underlying them is the ability to productively command signs (whether words or behaviors)-an ability that hinges on writing.  It's because the Spaniards had an extensive body of written knowledge that they had steel.  It's because of Cortés' writing-based innovative thinking that he could exploit information about the native" situation to win allies.  It's because of the Aztecs' speech-based tradition-dominated thinking that they didn't see the Spaniards as a dangerous new breed of enemy that needed to be dispatched-long before smallpox arrived with a later expedition-and didn't effectively adapt battle conventions to fight this new
column24: unpredictable enemy.  Aztec society
column25: as Todorov emphasizes
column26: was NOT inferior to Spanish society in any absolute way.  The Aztecs clearly had a complex and highly successful culture.  But
column27: at that moment in history
column28: faced with a new kind of enemy shaped by written language
column29: they did not successfully compete.  Restall uncritically dismisses Todorov's argument instead of getting it straight

column1: I was looking for a real thriller
column2: and thought I would try one by David Baldacci. I had read a very favourable review a while back
column3: and I have also seen and enjoyed the movie version of Absolute Power.  After reading reviews at Amazon
column4: I picked Last Man Standing. However
column5: I was really disappointed. For me it wasn't thrilling at all. Several times I had to force myself to pick it up again to continue reading. For me
column6: a good thriller is a book you can't stop reading
column7: even if it's getting late and you really
column8: really should try to get some sleep instead of continue reading.  Examples of great thrillers I have read are: The Firm by John Grisham
column9: The Day After Tomorrow by Allan Folsom (nothing to do with the weather-related movie of the same name) and Angels and Demons by Dan Brown.  But Last Man Standing was quite the opposite. Sure it had its moments where it got exciting for a while (the final shoot-out for example)
column10: but those times were quite rare.  I've been trying to figure out why I didn't like it
column11: but I can't say I know why. I do think that a lot of what happens in the book is quite far-fetched (especially the reason the hero Web London froze during the ambush) and that the characters are pretty one-dimensional
column12: but that's not enough of a reason. Both The Day After Tomorrow and Angels and Demons have plenty of far-fetch twists and one-dimensional characters
column13: but they were still exciting reads. I can't come up with a definite answer as to why I didn't like Last Man Standing - I simply just didn't care for it.  Writing a negative review like this will probably earn me a few unhelpful votes
column14: but I think it is important to also review books you didn't like. Otherwise you risk getting an unbalanced view. However
column15: I do admit that it is much more fun to review books you really liked.  But to finish
column16: if you are looking for a good thriller
column17: skip this one and try one of the other three I mentioned above.

column3: hence the suicide attempt). I am not saying that the work is rubbish - there is no "ugly" shot in either "Ran" or "Kag" - merely that there are more "authentically Japanese" films out there to choose from.

column1: I have read both Losing the Race and Authentically Black (the former is the better of the two).  I felt Authentically Black just reinforced the points that McWhorter made in LTR and that perhaps the book was an effort to capitalize off of the success of LTR. I certainly agree with many of McWhorter's pts.  There is an overemphasis on victimazation in Black America.  We often don't value the achievements we have accomplished and we often don't know about those achievements at all.  There are things that we can do for ourselves such as valuing education and intellectual curiosity.  However
column2: what Mr. McWhorter fails to acknowledge is that there is still institutional racism in America and that whites have an obligation to to put an end to to it since they are the ones that benefit from it.  The success of black people and all people of color is a two way street although McWhorter seems to think that it is a one way street.  I would recommend the book to get an idea of conservative black ideology but I think this book picks too much at black people's problems and not enough at possible solutions

column1: Harvard psychologist Howard Gardner's book on the art of changing minds and affecting opinions has an appealing pull. Written by a qualified professional in the field
column2: the book is another output of the impressive Harvard Business School Press. The book advances the view that there are seven
column3: what it calls
column4: "layers" or "levers" that affect a change of opinion. These factors
column5: whose titles all begin with `re' are: -Reason -Research -Resonance -Resistances -Real World Events -Resources And Rewards and -Representational Redescriptions   Gardner subsequently proceeds to elaborate on each of the factors within contexts such as an institution
column6: among a population
column7: up close or as relate's to one's own mind.   So far
column8: so good
column9: many would say; alas the reader is compelled to add `so what?' to the phrase. Changing Minds is indeed the work of a qualified professional
column10: but the reader is neither provided evidence nor shown the techniques and history behind the author's conclusions. Furthermore
column11: being the work of a researcher in an academic setting
column12: readers should not expect practical instructions or employable techniques. Rather
column13: Changing Minds concentrates on the mechanics and psychological hypothesis. In this manner
column14: the book is very much a scholastic paper. Finally
column15: there is scant evidence that the author employs his own teachings. Little proof
column16: research or reason is offered here to be convincing or allay any of the readers' resistances. Similarly dismissed is the need for charts
column17: sub-titles
column18: illustrations
column19: indented or highlighted points or synopses.   Furthermore
column20: and more ominously
column21: the author makes several practical mistakes in the way he reads or interprets the world rendering some of his data and experiences suspect. He claims that schools are agents of change and serve to instill different opinions in youngsters. Those are his opinions and not supported by any empirical data. He does not provide any supporting data either. In fact
column22: the contrary is true. Schools are designed to breed uniformity and teach adherence
column23: obedience and group activity. Barely a student will pass physics class were he to challenge a prevalent theory. A law student will probably find himself choosing a new major should he differ with prescribed laws. Similarly
column24: imagine a student disagreeing with the outcome of World War II
column25: an astrology student disputing the form of nova stars or
column26: at an elementary level
column27: a high school student butting heads with his classmates and instructors. Another error is the assumption that events have lead to fundamental change even in thought process of political leaders. Let me quote from the book. While Gardner cites the example of George W Bush following September 11
column29: many scholars and historians have shown that far from changing his mind
column30: the US president instead leveraged the event to more resolutely drive his pre-existing agenda. Much of what transpired following the events of the day were the accelerations of the American president and his officials' overt and covert ideas and strategies. Gardner terms the new Bush
column31: a "multilateralist"! Uncomfortably
column32: 132 sovereign countries and a lack of support from the United Nations would disagree. Moreover
column33: despite such fierce opposition
column34: Bush proceeded with his plans nonetheless. Further down the pages
column35: the author condemns Stalin's pact with Hitler as "cronyism." He conveniently forgets or omits the allies' earlier pact with Hitler or the West's subsequent treaty with the "extremely paranoid" Stalin. In short
column36: being a tenured academic Gardner himself seems most susceptible to institutional tunnel vision and in need of constructive cognitive dissonance.   Lacking the appeal of practicality
column37: the burden of proof or applicable relevance set in actual events Changing Minds: The Art And Science Of Changing Our Own And Other People's Minds is solely of interest to researchers in need of alternate sources on the topic.  Gardner does not provide any empirical basis for his opinions
column38: which also deviate from the title and stated scope of the book

column1: Anti-corporate Cassandras grind axes to sparse audiences these days.  In O'Boyle's piddling attempt to make us outraged at GE
column2: he destroys his own credibility.  By attempting to pin every social ill of the late 20th  century on Jack Welch-- a good
column3: if ruthless CEO-- his ideological ship  spins wildly out of control.  Downsizing is his fault. (Hello
column4: organizations are becoming streamlined all over the developed world)  Media  sensationalism is his fault. (Welch personally delights in the bottom  dwelling content of Dateline NBC) Anybody who has ever worked for a  corporation
column5: especially one as big as GE
column6: knows a few things that should  make readers way of O'Boyle's hokey cause and effect analysis: 1. The CEO  does not micromanage his or her company-- thousands of important decisions  are made under a CEOs jurisdiction every day. 2. Corporations are not  social utopias
column7: and shouldn't be.  People get fired sometimes.  But people  are also given opportunities to do interesting work.  And competition is  good. 3. If there is a ubitiquitous problem in society
column8: e.g. families are  no longer as stable
column9: a corporation
column10: which is sample unit of social  organization
column11: will usually reflect
column12: or possibly be linked more directly to  that problem.  However
column13: small minds confuse this with causality
column14: not  understanding the methodological pitfall of ad hoc ergo propter hoc.  For  example- families break up more
column15: partially because people don't balance  work and family very well. Lots of people work for corporations.   Corporations caused the decline of the American family. Read the book--  O'Boyle is guilty of not understanding these truths and more

column1: It seems to me that this book was written for jazz walking bass only. It is also not very helpful because there are hardly any exercises to practice the theory being presented. It is easy to say things like: "Use passing tones between chord tones"
column2: or :"Try to stay away from always playing the root on beat one". A short 2 bar example following is not of much help either. The other problem I had with this course was the author attempting to make the student "see all the chord tones of each chord throughout the entire fingerboard". Again this may be possible with correct exercises
column3: otherwise only experts with many years of playing exprience would be capable of that.  I was learning from "Walking Bass Lines" by Ed Friedland at the time and I must admit that this is a much better manual and explains the same material followed by simple and developmental exercises. You will get so much more out of this book than FBH.  All in all this manual is for pros that most likely already know all the material. (refresher course maybe?) But if you are learning bass you won't get very far before you dump this into your closet.

column1: Being a fan of such authors as J.R.R. Tolkien
column2: H.G. Wells
column3: and C.S. Lewis
column4: I figured I'd try and broaden my horizons by reading a book about the American West
column5: a sort of historical fiction that might be entertaining. I did some research and Cormac McCarthy seemed to be the author to start with.  He got very good reviews (from this site and professional critics).  I find it amazing that he received such great reviews... this book failed to impress me in the slightest bit.  The book seemed to fly away from the plot for a while and suddenly
column6: unexpectedly return to it.  I have never read a book like that before.  After completing this book I had found out more about the life of a prostitute than I ever wanted to know and also I received a free lesson in swearing.  I understand that it was custom in the West to swear
column7: and dealings with prostitutes was common
column8: but I think McCarthy went over the top.  This made it uninteresting and redundant.  Then there was the fact that he rarely used punctuation other than periods
column9: question marks
column10: and exclamation marks.  I did not see a single quotation mark and the word "and" was excessevely overused due to the exclusion of commas.  Dialogue was at times hard to follow and seemingly run-on sentences were monotonous.  After reading this book I also felt ignorant being uneducated in the Spanish language.  Much of the dialogue I could not understand in the least bit.  There were entire conversations written exclusively in Spanish at times when it seemed relevant.  I felt like I missed a lot of important information in the story. I did find that at time McCarthy did use some beautifully crafted language but the formerly mentioned factors left a very bad impression on me.  I don't suppose I'll ever read a book by Cormac McCarthy again

column1: Gary Zukav states in his introduction "I had never studied physics. In fact I didn't like science and I had no mathematical aptitude.  On Opra (TV) he admitted that he does not have a TV which may explain his lack of contemporary physics let alone any depth.  I noticed that some reviewers refer to the "New Physics" is that like "New Age" or voodoo physics?   90% of the matter must be missing from this book. Or else how can he take physics out of context and make such fantastic leaps to religions parallels that he knows little of. He even twists the religion around to serve some unknown purpose.   Many people say they did not understand physics until this book; Surprises
column2: you still do not. You now know what Zukav wished physics was. Take anti-mater for instants that does not mean the opposite of mater. And the relationship between particles has no correlation with the relationship of dogs and cats.  At least get it straight before mixing it up. Try reading some of these: "The Ascent of Man by Jacob Bronowski". The book available everywhere the DVD's available from the UK.  "The Upanishads" by Eknath Easwaran (Editor)
column3: Michael N. Nagler (Photographer)  Or just about any mainstream material on physics and religion.  Then if you still want to mix worlds into one read someone saner: "The Tao of Physics: An Exploration of the Parallels between Modern Physics and Eastern Mysticism" by Fritjof Capra.  Also on the fringe but not as radical as Zukav is a series called "What the Bleep." (both in books and on video)

column1: I understand the appeal of having the convenience of a spout on a bottle of oil
column2: but be aware that the spout will allow air into the bottle. You may think air only gets in when you pour oil out
column3: but that's not true. Any time the temperature rises
column4: the air in the bottle expands and some escapes through the spout. When the temperature drops
column5: air enters the spout. This is true of even small changes in temperature such as you experience in a kitchen. If you don't use the oil pretty quickly this constant exchange of air will expose the oil to oxygen and that will cause the oil to go rancid.  If you use cheap olive oil (and pretty much all grocery store olive oil is cheap oil -- even the extra virgin) you may not notice as much since cheap oils tend to be more bitter than good olive oils
column6: but it will still happen. I would never put olive oil in a bottle with a spout again. (I learned this lesson the hard way.)  A better option
column7: though less elegant
column8: is to use a bottle with a pour spout and cap
column9: or find a pour spout that has a cap to seal it

column1: I am ashamed to say I read this entire book. I kept hoping it would get better but it didn't. It is filled with typos and poor organization of thoughts and topics. Clarkson actually spells Mel Gibson's name wrong several times throughout the book
column2: and refers to Lethal Weapon director Richard Donner as "Dormer" for several pages! He jumps back and forth from one movie production to another making it difficult to follow. Lastly
column3: he relies on the accounts of people who had met Mel Gibson at one time but who had either a personal or professional conflict with him. In the retelling of these conflicts and what went down
column4: we hear one point of view only - and generally that is the view of someone who is harboring bitterness and resentment towards Gibson
column5: so their accounts are slanted and untrustworthy. The best part of the book is the end for two reasons: Clarkson finally gets to Gibson's most recent project
column6: The Passion of the Christ. The subtitle and the picture on the back of the book gives the impression this project will be a major focus of the book
column7: but after 300 pages of reading
column8: I was still waiting for the subject to come up. I have to say I felt that this was the only well written part of the whole book - thoughtful and interesting. The second reason the end is the best part of the book is that it was finally over. I'm sorry to be so blunt
column9: but I can't help it. I highly recommend reading the book about the making of the Passion of the Christ - you can learn a lot about Gibson there - but I cannot recommend this biography

The installation of this printer went very well.  However
column2: after installing the printer my computer began running EXTREMELY slow.  I checked and it was using 100% of the CPU.  I stopped all the processes associated with this printer and my speed returned to normal.  I contacted HP and they said it is a known problem and they are working on it (that was six months ago).  They still are working on it.  HP's solution is to install the print driver only (so you cannot use the scan or fax feature) until they write new software for this printer.  They should have recalled the printer since it doesn't work properly.  DO NOT PURCHASE THIS PRINTER!!!

column1: So much for revealing the "secrets" of Cabales Escrima. Unfortunatly this book is quite the opposite. Wiley misquotes Angel on the back cover. The author shares 8 "secrets" of financial success in this book.  Secret #1 Never pay off your mortgage because interest is tax-deductible. And if you investment your money in stocks (instead of pre-paying your mortgage) you will earn greater interest than what you're paying on your mortgage. WRONG. This "secret" has been wrong for almost five years now -- and would cost you plenty. The stock market is not a panacea. Besides
column2: tax-deductibility is a non-issue for low-income retirees.  Secret #2 Don't diversify your retirement money -- put it all in stocks. WRONG. A mixture of stocks AND bonds is appropriate for almost everyone's retirement account. This author apparently knows nothing about portfolio theory and efficient frontiers. And this "secret" would have severely hurt anyone who is approaching retirement and kept their IRAs at 100% stocks during the bursting bubble & subsequent bear market.   Secret #3 Most of your wealth will come from investments of less than $1000. Sure it's good to start early
column3: but the premise here is WRONG. The most money anyone makes in interest is in your last few years of holding an investment. In other words
column4: most of your wealth comes at the end - when compounding interest is most strong. Imagine a small deposit to a mutual fund. Ten percent interest in your first year will be near-nothing. Ten percent interest on your investment in the fourtieth year is likely to be a number with six or seven figures. Thus most of your wealth will come from investments worth well more than $1
column5: 000.  Secret #4 You should rarely move from one investment to another. WRONG. While I agree with buy and hold
column6: blindly following buy-and-hold advice will get you in trouble. Severely underperforming investments need to be harvested. And rebalancing (to keep your appropriate mix of stocks & bonds) should be performed yearly.   Secret #5 Don't measure your success against the Dow or S&P. WRONG and STUPID. You have no way of guaging the performance of your mutual funds or other investments unless you use a yardstick such as the S&P Dow or Wilshire. Perhaps the author knows the investments he sells are lemons
column7: so he wants to discredit benchmarking. Sad.  Secret #6 Devote less than 3 hours per month to your finances. And budgeting is stupid. WRONG. 3 hours is an arbitrary number and some people will take longer
column8: others less. Big deal. And budgeting is a *great* idea for those people who don't save enough.  Secret #7 Involve your kids in financial planning. OK
column9: this one is right
column10: but to teach your kids these "secrets" is WRONG and will doom them for life.   Secret #8 Don't pay attention to the financial media. WRONG. If you read this book then never pick up a legitimate piece of financial journalism again (WSJ
column11: Barrons
column12: Money
column13: Andrew Tobias) you're screwed.   This book ranks among the worst of the financial planning books I've read.    Want good advice? Try "Personal Finance for Dummies" by Tyson or "The Only Investment Guide You'll Ever Need" by Tobias. Or simply go to vanguard.com and read their planning & advice section -- it's free

As a reader I felt completely outside the story; an uncaring observer of a poorly described scenario.  The attempts to tug at my heartstrings were laughable.  I've been more moved by the appearance of colorful weeds on my lawn.  The only reason I read the whole thing was that my neighbor recommended it and loaned it to me.  Do not waste your time.    I must say though that this novel was inspirational.  If this crap can make the best seller list
column10: it gives me hope that my original fiction might get published
