column1: I'm fascinated by the rave reviews for this text. I used it for a community college stats course and once I was in the classroom with it
column2: I became aware that I had some problems. It is true that it's written in a friendly style and has plenty of exercises
column3: but I found it to be poor preparation for my students who will be going on to higher levels of statistics in behavioral science courses.  I found myself explaining
column4: more times than I wish to recall
column5: how formulas look different in other statistics books
column6: and I was disconcerted at the lack of use of symbols that one usually sees in beginning statistics courses. Simple terms most commonly used in statistics were not introduced at all
column7: and most statistical tests were not mentioned. Many students found it to be cumbersome and a bit overwhelming.   It's my own fault
column8: really. I did not spend enough time perusing texts. And my familiarity with statistics prevented me
column9: when looking it over
column10: from realizing how much was really missing. I realized that my students would enter bachelor's programs lacking some very basic information that is always used in statistics for the behavioral sciences. Most of my students plan to earn graduate degrees; I had to spend quite a bit of time preparing notes for them as well as lectures explaining formulas
column11: symbols
column12: and terminology that "some of" their higher courses might use. And with nary a mention of ANOVA or any other higher level tests
column13: I felt I really had done my students a disservice.  I began to wonder - have I been out of school so long that things have changed this much and I'm not aware of it? But - as I am teaching at a state college
column14: stats texts started trickling in from other publishers. I saw that it was not me. This massive text
column15: costing my students $120
column16: is lacking quite a bit that they should be exposed to - to better prepare them for future statistics studies in the behavioral sciences. This was certainly a bitter lesson for me! I had to waste far too much time putting together information that was missing just so my students would have the course they should have.  I recommend Sally Caldwell's text
column17: "Statistics Unplugged" for beginning students - at least in behavioral sciences programs. It's a third the cost
column18: a third the SIZE
column19: and much more reader-friendly. And it contains the information that I had to supply to my students just so they would get what they paid for.   I do not recommend this book. I'll certainly be much more careful in future when choosing textbooks

column12: charlatans and wankers to be found in the Social Sciences departments of any given University. Anyone who's been to university and didn't know that deserves a clip around the ear and to be sent to the back of the class. Now either Sokal didn't know that ( - ~clip~ -)
column13: or he's spent half his book shooting fish in a barrel. That might seem like good sport
column14: but before long it becomes obvious it's a cheap thrill.  Having said that
column15: I sincerely doubt that the titillation of seeing dumb French Feminists taken apart is what made this book such a splash: I think it's because of Sokal's purported intent: to undermine the notion of cognitive relativism
column16: especially as it associated with modern philosophy of science
column17: in particular the work of Thomas Kuhn and Paul Feyerabend. This is the battle: Sokal aligns with those who say scientists are the exclusive purveyors of a shining light called truth; the Barbarians at the gate are these simpering postmodernists who want to tear the temple down.  While the poseurs cited in this book are certainly (for the most part) phoneys or idiots
column18: I think Thomas Kuhn was neither
column19: and while Paul Feyerabend overplayed the court jester hand
column20: he had some important things to say too.  So
column21: to the first point: Proving that one writer (or a hundred
column22: or a thousand) who purports to adhere to relativism is a charlatan doesn't establish anything about *the idea* of relativism. All you have established is that you have a found yourself a charlatan. Give yourself a star.   But while you're pinning it on
column23: remember that postmodernists do not have a monopoly on illogical
column24: bamboozling
column25: balderdash:  Example: Sir Roger Penrose (Emeritus Rouse Ball professor of mathematics at Oxford University
column26: no less) and his dreadful
column27: lumpen-headed
column28: and deliberately bamboozling anti-AI tract "The Emperor's New Mind". The very point of the (no doubt correct but nonetheless entirely irrelevant) science deluged on the reader in that book is to obscure the fact that the real emperor was Roger Penrose and his arguments on AI really blow the kumara.   Example: Noam Chomsky and Steven Pinker's Linguistic Nativism
column29: which has held sway for a good thirty years in many linguistics departments
column30: and is anything but post-modern: nativism holds that humans have an innate understanding of grammar hard wired into their biology. From my paltry readings in linguistics and the philosophy of language
column31: my impression is that Pinker's and Chomsky's arguments are seriously flawed. (See: Sampson: "The Language Instinct Debate" for a thorough linguistic critique of nativism; see Rorty: "Contingency Irony
column32: and Solidarity" for a philosophical perspective on the contingency of language). Make note of this example
column33: as it becomes relevant later on.  Secondly
column34: Sokal and Bricmont (quite deliberately) refuse to engage on certain topics
column35: in particular on cultural or aesthetic relativism
column36: which they say (without providing a reason) "raise very different issues". Take that star away
column37: for this statement betrays a fundamental misunderstanding about relativism. Actually
column38: ethical
column39: aesthetic and cognitive relativisms raise different manifestations of *exactly* the same issue: Cognitive relativism
column40: in that it relates to "epistemic" truth (as opposed to "moral" truth or "aesthetic" truth - both of which seem intuitively more questionable ideas) is simply a cut closer to the quick: indeed
column41: the aesthetic and moral brands of relativism rely for their plausibility on cognitive relativism anyway (i.e. if the truths we understand about the physical universe are contingent on our language
column42: then it follows that ideals of right and wrong and beauty must be similarly contingent on our language).  Thirdly
column43: Sokal provides the following account of cognitive relativism:   "While scientists ... try to obtain an objective view ... of the world
column44: relativist thinkers tell them that they are wasting their time and that such an enterprise is
column45: in principle
column46: an illusion"  Now that
column47: to put it mildly
column48: is a *very* punchy version of relativism
column49: and not one that any credible relativist philosopher I know of (and certainly not Thomas Kuhn
column50: who spent a whole book explaining how and why the process scientific discovery works) subscribes to.  That is
column51: in the trade
column52: known as a straw-man argument: You set it up to knock it over. Here goes:   P1: Relativists say science is a waste of time P2: Science helps us reliably predict and react coherently to phenomena occurring in the world  P3: Things which help to predict and react to such phenomena have genuine utility  C1: Therefore
column53: science has genuine utility C2: Ergo
column54: science is not a waste of time  Case closed. Is relativism dead? No: the problem is
column55: most relativists I know would completely agree with all of the above argument except for premise 1. The cat is most definitely still out of the bag. (In a nutshell
column56: all reasonably stated relativism says is that you can't know that your theory actually maps onto the actual configuration of the outside world; it may
column57: it may not: logically there will always be some other possible explanation for the same set of data
column58: however implausible or difficult to imagine
column59: and in part that difficulty in imagination may be a function of the historical contingency of our belief in
column60: and description of the world in terms of
column61: the current "paradigm". Relativism simply says the best you can do is to know that
column62: for now
column63: your theory works
column64: not that it is *true*. Though Sokal and Bricmont may disagree
column65: I don't think this is controversial amongst philosophers nor
column68: in criticising an admittedly utterly ludicrous passage bestowed on the world by that splendidly silly feminist philosopher Sylvia Kristeva
column69: Sokal makes the following footnote:  "...Kristeva seems to be appealing ... to the 'Sapir-Whorf thesis' in linguistics that is ...that our language radically conditions our view of the world. This thesis nowadays is sharply criticised by some linguists: see
column70: for example Pinker ..."  Hold the phone. The implication is that the Sapir-Whorf thesis (as to the contingency of language) has been discredited
column71: but by none other than Steven Pinker in his "The Language Instinct" which
column73: is at the very least a controversial piece of writing. This is an extremely important point
column74: since it's utterly central to the credibility of the anti-relativist cause
column75: and if one takes Geoffrey Sampson's book (cited above) at face value the nativist claims themselves are built on very suspect reasoning and scientific research. It seems to me (and to writers like Richard Rorty) that language must radically condition our view of the world
column76: because that's the only basis on which we can even describe it.  At the end of the day
column77: properly stated cognitive relativism is no a threat to modern scientific discourse
column78: except that it relegates the scientist from "truth knower" or "person through whom you may have exclusive access to the truth" (sounds a bit like a grand high pooh-bah or - dare I say it - high priest
column79: doesn't it?) to "person whose theory works the best for now" and who may be in competition for that status with other people in the community whether or not they're scientists.   If science *does* work better than feng shui or healing crystals (and I
column81: think it does) then this shouldn't be a particularly troubling way of looking at the world for a scientist who is at ease with his views and his value to the community. So it makes the knee-jerk reactions against relativism
column82: from the likes of Sokal and elsewhere Richard Dawkins
column83: all the more mystifying.  Olly Buxton

column1: You only have to look at the poor cover design to know you're in for trouble here. I ordered this book just out of curiosity and am terribly disappointed.  The author has a formula for decorating that misses entirely. Good design isn't about formulas. And if it were
column2: she breaks her own rules regarding focal points
column3: balance
column4: traffic lanes
column5: weight on the bottom and much more.  The room layouts have no doors or windows which so affect the placement of furniture. What was she thinking?  She places two works of art completely to one side of the wall when two walls join going perpendicular to each other. So if one views one wall at a time as one would often do
column6: the arrangement is totally off balance.  Huh?  Her teachings on the heights of furniture and matching it up with the height of the wall is a nice try that definitely won't fit many situations. There are too many variables that will conflict.   Her teaching that the art should be equally as wide as the width of the sofa or chair creates an oppressive feeling. The drawings that illustrate this prove my point: the art invariably overpowers the furniture below it which flies in the face of her teaching that the visual weight should be on the bottom
column7: with lighter weighted items on top.  She would have you build a wall grouping from the outside in
column8: rather than the inside out.  What?  She clearly doesn't understand scale and proportion and can't even find where she mentions it
column9: so I guess she doesn't know about the Golden Mean Theory or the Rule of the Golden Thumb.  She tells you never to place matching loveseats across from one another when that is a very effective way to arrange them. And she doesn't want you to ever split apart two matching chairs
column10: for instance
column11: when doing so can open up an arrangement idea that is very stunning and just as cohesive as keeping them together.  I'm sorry but if you want your home to have the "Levitt's" or "department store look" with your neat little furniture "set" and no individuality
column12: then you might like her inconsistent rules and formulaic decorating technique.  But if you want your home to look creative
column13: distinctive
column14: original
column15: personal and just plain "feels good when done"
column16: a rigid formula is not for you

column1: Having read previous works on notions of blackness in America from historical figures W.E.B. DuBois
column2: Booker T. Washington
column3: Frederick Douglas
column4: sociologist William Julius Wilson
column5: and activist Angela Y. Davis
column6: I started from a perspective that Dickerson's work would be at the level of these noted authors.  After getting through the introduction
column7: however
column8: I realized my mistake.  The work is not a scholarly compilation of syllogistic conclusions.  Rather
column9: it is a work that Ms. Dickerson can confidently claim as her own.  Assumptions are based upon false premises that lead readers to conclusive arguments derived from erroneous logic. The thickness in verbage that includes slangy tone is rather demeaning as one sloughs over Ms. Dickerson's opinions that come off first as xenocentric but later are diffused.

Her husband learns of the danger she is in and goes to Boston to be with her and once again she sneaks off from him...this time running to the cabin.  THEN

column7: one of whom is a murderer and is also after her so instead of staying in the cabin where another Texas Ranger is there to keep her safe she decides to go cross-country skiing and surprise
column8: surprise runs into the bad guy who
column9: duh
column10: tries to kill her.  Now there's a surprise!    Okay
column11: call me stupid
column12: but if my husband were a CPA and I had an accounting problem
column13: I probably would ask for his help.  If my husband were a doctor and I had some sort of mystery ailment
column14: I think I would ask for his opinion.  And if my husband were a cop and I had some really bad guys after me
column15: I believe I would see if my husband could help keep me safe!    Like I said
column16: I just didn't GET Susanna. I think Ms. Neggers intended to portray Susanna as being so strong that she didn't need her husband.  Unfortunately
column17: she doesn't seem to understand that being strong sometimes means realizing when you need to turn to someone else for help.  If Jack had been a brain surgeon and Susanna had learned she had a brain tumor
column18: I wonder if she would have insisted on showing how strong she was by operating on herself.  Guess this is a book I won't be keeping.

column1: "The Accidental" by first-time Scottish novelist Ali Smith has to be one of the most irritating books I've read in a very long time.  It's so modern
column2: it's really hard to tell what happened or why you should care about it.  This book won the Whitbread Novel Award.  According to another website
column3: the Whitbread Award lost its sponsor and ceased to exist the same year.  Would it be fair to label this book as the one that killed the Whitbread Award?   The jacket also labels this book as a finalist for the Man Booker Prize whose website says that they award "the very best in contemporary fiction."  For me a requirement of the very best fiction is to be able to affect the reader in a positive way.  My only positive is that I finally got to the end of a dreadful book; & no
column4: it did not get better.  Eve Smart is a novelist.  I usually try to avoid books where writers write about writers.  It's like a movie about movie stars or a song about songwriting -- it seems quintessentially self-indulgent.  Who knows what happens to Eve at the end of the book?  Why is she in some lady's house near the Grand Canyon?  Is it just to present another character as irritatingly self-absorbed as the main character?  Why is Eve unconcerned about her children?  Why does she see her dead mother floating above the Grand Canyon when this wasn't a book about her parents?  Wouldn't it have been more interesting to have her be eaten by a mountain lion?   Michael is Eve's husband.  He's a university professor that sleeps with his students.  His wife Eve knows and doesn't care.  Are they progressive people because they sleep around?  Is this supposed to make us care about them?  What is the effect of their loose behavior on their two children?  Do we care or applaud when Michael gets fired?    Astrid is the youngest child.  She is going through typical adolescent behaviors.  Yes
column5: she is one of the most real of the characters
column6: but she doesn't change throughout the book.  She gets mad at her mother for not being home and refuses to speak to Eve when she calls on the phone.  Astrid was right to be mad at Eve
column7: but so what?  Magnus
column8: the son
column9: was the most interesting character to me simply because he loses his virginity in a church.  It's a bit of a mixed message from author Ali Smith.  What does it say about the church?  Is the message that "The Accidental" is man because there is no God proved because the church is empty?  Who knows?  Amber shows up as the family summers in Suffolk or Norfolk as Eve tries to write.  She buddies up with Astrid smashing her expensive camera.  She has sex with Magnus.  She insults Eve and gives her a knee massage.  She kisses Eve on the lips
column10: right before Eve leaves for the Grand Canyon.  She ignores Michael.  Who is Amber?  Why is she in the book?  Magnus tells Astrid he knows who Amber is after she's disappeared
column11: but Smith fails to let the readers know.  Is this a puzzle?  An illusion?  A nightmare?  Then when the family returns home
column12: their house has been completely stripped.  Who did that?  What's the point?    I did not care for Smith's repetitious use of pages of short sentences.  It doesn't further the story.  It basically just says
column13: "Look at me.  I can write in short sentences."  However
column14: it was enough to have her awarded the Whitbread Novel Award.  I didn't mind the poetry.  I liked it because I could get through the book faster.  To what point it was there
column15: I cannot say.  Perhaps you will be more modern than I and not particularly care if a story makes sense or whether there is anybody about which to care.  For me
column16: this is an award-winning dud.  Taxi!

column1: Butler's Lives of the Saints: New Concise Ed.
column2: edited by Paul Burns
column4: Copyright 2003  Consider another book.  Despite "Butler's" being in the title
column5: it seems to bear no relation to the Butler's Lives of the Saints published in the 1950s and 1800s.   Defects: 1. There is no index or alphabetical list of saints.  If you want to look up a saint by name
column6: you have to scan the list of 366 saints in the table of contents
column7: which is six pages long.  An index would have provided quick access.  2. Saints are not listed under their actual commemoration day. Why?  Because the saints did not "die on conveniently spaced dates" (page xi).  Nothing in the description of the saint alerts you to the date being wrong.  To determine the correct day
column8: you have to closely read a paragraph at the beginning of the month.   3. The book does not bear an imprimatur from a bishop or "nihil obstat" showing that it's free from error.  To illustrate why this is a problem
column9: one-third of the entry for St. Maria Goretti is not about her; it's a critique of her sainthood and of the Church.  Example: in "feminist circles ... Maria has been seen more as a martyr to patriarchal society" (p. 310)

column1: Another unnecessary tome of the "publish or perish" variety. It merely documents that the author has identified and consulted written accounts of the phenomenon from the last 150 years and patched together a narrative that is very much of the cut-and-paste variety. No original research is evidenced; and where the author had the opportunity to correct gross errors of fact in sources quoted
column2: it's just too much bother. To wit: on p. 237
column3: "La Goulue...still there in the 1930s... In the background..stands an old man...Valentin-le-Désossé
column4: her old dancing partner." Well
column5: La Goulue was dead by early 1929 (30 Jan. to be exact)
column6: and her partner Valentin had slipped back into the perfectly bourgeois existence that he emerged from - to die in 1907. On p. 246
column7: Mrs. Wilson gives us two paragraphs on a "certain" Dr. Walter Serner (1889-1942). She appears to know nothing about him as a writer (of brilliantly unique short stories)
column8: but insists that he eventually disappears in the Soviet Union
column9: "perhaps in search of the bohemian's always elusive utopia". This romanticizing nonsense is especially galling
column10: considering that Serner suffered the usual fate the Nazis had in store for Jews: he and his wife were arrested in Prague in 1942 and murdered a few months later
column11: probably in Auschwitz.  The author's website tells us that she has written an autobiography at age 45
column12: and is a feminist
column13: lesbian and social activist. I'd say stick to it

column1: Robert B. Parker is stuck in a rut. That he has a profound and almost pathological hatred of suburbia
column2: the traditional family and conservative Christians should be patently obvious by now to any of his readers this side of raving idiocy. Sadly

column4: and attempt to construct them as real characters instead of laughably absurd cardboard cut-outs

column6: a single and openly  promiscuous career woman

column8: and how she wishes she could "save" her from her Mom and Dad. How nauseating! Spoken like a true social engineer. I guess only the elite who live in chic downtown apartments and drink imported beer should be allowed to raise children.   But seriously
column9: the way Parker not only belittes
column10: but casually writes off
column11: 75% of his fellow citizens (that is
column12: normal people who live in 2 parent homes
column13: go to church
column14: and recognize a moral code outside of themselves) is sometimes quite chilling. He portrays them as being something almost subhuman. It makes you wonder what would Parker and his intellectual ilk do if they were ever put in charge.   Despite these serious shortcomings
column15: Parker's writing is as disciplined as ever. As usual
column16: he does a good of showing rather than telling
column17: and his characters evoke strong emotions in the reader. I always hold out hope that Parker will one day overcome his tragically stunted view of the world
column18: and make full use of the gifts the Good Lord has given him

I admit it: I saw this on a library cart and assumed from the cover that this was some political humorist on the order of P. J. O' Rourke or Jon Stewart who had simply not come to my attention.    How wrong I was.    Greg Palast bills himself as some kind of investigative reporter. He is not. He is a partisan who puts together a tidbit here
column2: a tidbit there and fills in the blanks with left-wing cant taken from the talking point memos of a thousand fringe groups and special interests. What doesn't fit in with his agenda is simply ignored. Where a "fact" is vitally necessary
column3: it is often invented.    Palast doesn't document his "secret" finds. Much like Seymour Hersh
column4: another truth-challenged "investigative reporter"
column5: Palast expect you to accept on his own authority that when he tells you of this or that secret document that has come into his possession
column6: you are to believe simply because he says it is so (ipse dixit
column7: as the Latin goes).    The basic themes are what you would expect to find in any "progressive" screed: the United States is evil
column8: Bush is evil and dumb
column9: big corproations are evil and greedy
column10: there are secret cabals that rule the United States and want to dominate the world and would
column11: were it not for a few "freedom fighters" who blow up innocent women and children and so forth. We've all heard it ten thousand times and its no more rational coming from Palast than it is from someone else.    Two examples will suffice to show the blatant dishonesty of Greg Palast.    First is Palast's defense of Dan Rather's use of forged documents. Palast
column12: without evidence
column13: not only rejects the argument
column14: but attacks the people CBS brought in to examine the entire fiasco. No evidence - just blast.    Next is Palast's attempt to misrepresent the work of M. King Hubbert
column15: a geologist
column16: on oil reserves. Even though he reproduces Hubbert's original chart
column17: Palast simply distorts Hubbert's conclusions.    Overall
column18: Palast simply plays to the crowd: those who share his beliefs. No proof is needed to support his contentions. As long as he casts the United States as evil and so on
column19: all will be well and his books will sell well since the people who read them are not interested in truth

column1: I bought the camera in May of 2006

column1: This book was missing words and had typos 15 years ago. Since then there have been 3 major revisions to the dictionary. The last update alone had over 3200 words removed or added. By including words that have been removed such as DA and not including words that have now come to be accepted such as FE this book leads you far behind. Hook words like these make a huge difference when looking for good plays. This book is too outdated to be of any use to anyone looking to improve their game. Take the advice of the champion player who wrote the first review listed 5 years ago and get your info somewhere else.

column1: I have recently read 5 books about the Trappists/Cistercians and this is the worst book of them all.  I have spent 10 days on retreats at a Trappist abbey and more to come
column2: and I DO NOT recommend this book for several  reasons.  First
column3: the author has approached his subject as a journalist and  has a negative tone.  Secondly
column4: he has included too much autobiographical  information about his own life and spiritual struggles.  Thirdly
column5: he has a  rather arrogant attitude about his desire to invade the privacy of some of  the monks who choose not to be interviewed by him.  Lastly
column6: his tone is  that of one being perched "on-high" and gazing down upon the lives of the  Trappist monks.  For a much better introduction to Trappist/Cistercian  monasticism: The Silent Life
column7: By Thomas Merton; The Cistercian Way
column8: By  Andre Louf; Trappist: Living in the Land of Desire
column9: By Michael Downey; and  The Orchards of Perseverance
column10: By David Perata.  I believe that these other  titles are much more accurate in portraying the spirituality and practice  of Trappist monks

column1: I thought I was going to get a thriller when I first heard of this.  Instead I got a pseudo-sequel to COLD MOUNTAIN set in 1980 Texas
column2: and I have rather low opinions of COLD MOUNTAIN.  It was difficult to follow the story due to McCarthy's decision to not only avoid using quotation marks to identify dialogue (a move I've always considered to be a pretentious affectation)
column3: but also commas
column4: apostrophes
column5: and proper spelling
column6: such as not capitalizing "English" or using "livingroom" instead of "living room" and "mam" instead of "ma'am."  I don't know if this is something McCarthy does in all his books or this was a one-time deal
column7: but it was a major turnoff and made the experience grueling rather than enjoyable.  I also didn't see the relevance of the italicized monologues of Sheriff Bell at the beginning of each chapter/section
column8: as he tended to ramble on about life after  World War Two and how it wasn't uncommon to see 22-year-olds as ordained ministers or 25-year-olds as sheriffs of counties the size of Delaware.  Hopefully its movie adaptation (which I legitimately pity the Coen Brothers for having to wade through) is more accessible

column1: Lee Child is one of the best action-suspense novelists out there.  He is a writer of immense talent.  He normally writes in a very terse
column2: no-nonsense style that really motivates the reader to turn the pages.  His hero Jack Reacher has become an inconic character
column3: kind of an American James Bond.  DIE TRYING
column4: however
column5: is one of Child's lesser efforts.  The plot of this book is
column6: quite simply
column7: ludicrous.  All of Child's stories are admittedly implausable
column8: but this one really strains credibility.  Much of what happens in this novel is statistically impossible
column9: and I found myself rolling my eyes at much of it.  I've seen dumb action movies with better constructed plots than DIE TRYING.  Characterization is also quite weak here.  There are too many characters and Child keeps on shifting the reader's perspective from one secondary character to another.  All the villains in DIE TRYING are silly right-wing militia types.  Many of them are too buffoonish to be truly threatening.  Many of the action scenes lack emotional punch because you don't really care about any of the players.    Child also has an unfortunate tendency to describe every scene in minute detail
column10: so that a straightforward action scene is drawn out to an interminable length.  In this book
column11: this writing style really bogs down the narrative and made it difficult for me to finish this novel.  I skimmed this novel toward the end
column12: which is too bad
column13: because Child is a very smart writer overall.  My advice is to skip this poorly structured effort and devote your time to Child's better books like KILLING FLOOR and ECHO BURNING.

column1: Finally
column2: "Making Love" is released on DVD. For those of you questioning my rating
column3: let me explain. The ratings are supposed to be for the product (the DVD) not the film itself. I give the DVD a 2-star rating simply because it contains no extras. No commentary track
column4: no "making of" featurette
column5: no deleted scenes
column6: no bloopers
column7: no nothing (unless you count the trailer......and I don't count the trailer). The film I give a 3 1/2 to 4 star rating or a 5 star rating simply because Kate Jackson is in it.         Considered controversial and ground breaking for its time
column8: today (as another reviewer mentioned) in the days of "Will and Grace" and "Queer as Folk" it seems rather mild by comparison. Still
column9: that doesn't mean it isn't a good film. Yes
column10: it is riddled with cliches and yes
column11: it goes out of it's way to be as unoffensive as possible
column12: yet "Making Love" tackles it's  subject in a fairly honest
column13: forthright manner (especially when you consider it was filmed in 1982).          Although it's nice to see Jackson on Ontkean together again (since their days on the television series "The Rookies")
column14: I never really bought Ontkean's performance. Even when I watch it today I feel he's too stiff and reserved
column15: never really willing to open up and fully explore his character's conflicts and emotions. Jackson does some of her best work here (okay
column16: so you know I'm a fan and somewhat biased but....hey
column17: whatever). She has some genuinely touching moments
column18: such as when she confesses her crush on her teacher to the camera ("Crepe paper is a [..] to tear")
column19: when she talks on the phone with her father
column20: or her final meeting with Zach. As he walks down the driveway and out of her life
column21: the expression on her face breaks your heart. It's moments like these that make me very curious to see what Jackson could have done with the role of Joanna
column22: the ex-wife of Dustin Hoffman's character in "Kramer Vs. Kramer". (She was originally offered the role but the producers of Charlie's Angels would not give her the time off). Harry Hamlin deserves kudos for taking a basically unlikable character and portraying him as such while showing the audience why he has built up this wall around himself. One reviewer noted that Zach unexplainably falls for Bart. I think it's perfectly understandable why Zach falls for him. Zach is in the middle of an identity crisis. Bart is the ONE gay man he actually knows on a personal level. It's only natural that he'd be drawn to him to learn more about himself
column23: no matter how cocky or flippant Bart is.        So yes
column24: the film has it's flaws (as most do) but I think it holds up pretty well after all these years. I just wish the DVD had some extras darn it!!

column1: Marcuse has long been a favorite of intellectuals and for good reason - his ideas brought about the rise of the Left on college campuses and made acceptable the practice of allowing only acceptable views a hearing.  Dissenting opinions are to be silenced. His idea of societal/cultural Marxism seems slightly nutty and a tad romantic - one of those theories worked out by tenured professors over a second glass of brandy at the local pub. But Marcuse is anything but flippant - he is dead serious.  He is also a contradiction.  At once didactic (he's German)and eccentric
column2: he also (like Freud) played the part of the gifted bourgeoise trapped amid a swill of nonentities. He has never refrained from advocating a dictatorship of the elite who would guide/help/force the stupid masses. For some reason
column3: he thought undisciplined
column4: nomadic students would lead that vanguard. And in a sense they did - by entering politics
column5: academia or the media.  His disciples are classic "NPR" types - highly educated
column6: white
column7: well-heeled and immersed in political ideology.   One cannot underestimate his influence.  His theories led to several current movements (quote unquote): Deconstructionism
column8: the Marxist interpretation of language
column9: Political art
column10: identity politics
column11: group (gender/ethnic) over individual rights
column12: the new Primitivism (radical environmentalism/animal rights) and last but not least
column13: violence as an acceptable political response.    Despite the shrill denunciation of Western culture he chose to remain behind enemy lines
column14: never venturing to Marxist lands for study where critical works of this kind would not be permitted. This is the paradox: Critical writers would not be allowed in a Marcusian society since "wrong" ideas are not permitted. Like Chomsky or Vidal or even the clownish Michael Moore
column15: he walked among the very peoples he denounced.  The thesis of the book - typically Marxist - is the plight of the worker brought up to date by Marcuse.  We learn of the horrors of capitalism and the hope for a brighter future. But would his society of mind-numbing politicalization make individuals richer in spirit and more fulfilled?   One aspect of Marcuse I've always admired is his brutal honesty. Unlike other theorists he openly advocates violence when it is necessary to achieve a political goal.  He embraced the students who rioted in the 60's but unlike other letists he was never fooled by the common worker - they would never willingy accept his societal vision. He says (repeatedly) "They must be taught".  This work is very 1950sh
column16: especially the parts with the outdated Freudian allusions.  It reads like a religious tract that quotes  ancient writings as the best answer for current problems. One must remember that this was written when Marxism was still taken seriously in some quarters.  Its effects remain with us today.

column1: With The Straight Story
column2: Lynch demonstrated none of the recognizable trademarks that transformed him into the director that I love.  This film felt like a "blind date" gone bad.  The Straight Story showed up
column3: David Lynch arrived
column4: but the rest of the date felt muddled
column5: confusing
column6: and utterly disastrous.  Everything in this film seemed wrong.  Lynch's choice for lead actor
column7: the bland Sissy Spacek
column8: the filler of repeat cornfield montages
column9: all the way to the incoherent time spent on the read
column10: I just felt that nobody had control over this picture
column11: yet the randomness (and the possible tear ending) gave critics something to smile about.  This is not a David Lynch film
column12: and for those walking into this with images of Mulholland Drive
column13: Twin Peaks
column14: or even Eraserhead in their mind will be utterly discombobulated.  The Straight Story attempted to show us a slice of Americana via the cornfields of Iowa
column15: but for this boy based in the Flatlands of Illinois
column16: it just seemed repetitive and boring.  What initially pulled me away from this film was the technique that Lynch used to introduce us to Alvin and his daughter Rose.  Alvin lying on the ground because he can't get up
column17: the cliché use of taking him to the doctor letting us know that he is deteriorating
column18: while bringing us the central conflict of his brother falling ill was just too much in such a little time frame.  Spacek's depiction of Rose seemed unbalanced and rather stale.  She brought nothing fresh to this rather emotional character outside of a stutter and some unfunny scenes.  I expected so much more from Spacek with her timeline of cinema
column19: but this felt like something she did on an afternoon instead of providing us with the intensity that she harbors.  Then
column20: to add more fuel to the fire
column21: there was Richard Farnsworth.  Again
column22: he isn't a horrible actor
column23: but it felt like Lynch picked him because he fit the role physically
column24: but alas
column25: couldn't master it mentally.  Farnsworth seemed out in left field for a majority of his time onscreen.  I couldn't tell if he was trying to remember his lines or if he was truly in character.  His eyes seemed watery for everything which brought too much emotion to those little scenes
column26: and seemed to bring not enough by the dramatic ending.  His entire speech about his time overseas at war was pathetic
column27: while some will quote it as being his speech of a lifetime
column28: I saw it as babble (and no
column29: I am not that insensitive - I just felt it could have been handled by a stronger
column30: more professional actor).  The rest of the cast seemed equally as unimportant.  I wanted Lynch to either go 100% for this film or none at all
column31: but alas
column32: it felt as if he just half-ed his way through this heap.  Speaking of David Lynch
column33: where did he go in this film?  There were some scenes that I witnessed that screamed the director that I love
column34: but then there were others that just felt like he took pointers from Ken Burns' "Looking at America" class.  I hated the sweeping cornfields that seem to plague this film.  Instead of keeping us by Alvin's side throughout his journey
column35: Lynch gave us a repetitive view of farming and corn.  There is nothing wrong with this technique when making the epic that one desperately needs to see once in a while
column36: but when the same images were used over and over again
column37: I nearly felt Lynch was humoring us with the dulls of Iowa instead of being the majestic all the critics raved about.  I think he could have been stronger with his filler than what he was with this film.  He needed something to couple with the authenticity of Alvin
column38: but the stock-footage that he chose to show was definitely not the balance one could hope for.  I also felt there was more to be discussed with the friends that he met along the way.  Alvin was a walking storybook
column39: filled with the way that he led his own life instead of listening to those around him and learning from their experiences as well.  Lynch made Alvin very closed minded
column40: which did not create a strong protagonist for the feature.  Alvin was a strong character
column41: but I needed more with this story.  I wanted him to make choices
column42: learn new things
column43: and bring that to his brother's table when they eventually met.  I felt cheated when this never occurred and felt as if Lynch was saying that this journey through Americana was that we could learn from Alvin
column44: and not vice-versa.  Overall
column45: I wasn't stunned by this picture.  I thought Lynch could have been stronger with his choice of direction and cast instead of what seemed like he just "played it safe".  The overplayed stock footage of cornfields infuriated me due to the lack of time that we could have been spending with Alvin.  Speaking of Alvin
column46: why couldn't he have been a stronger
column47: better-rounded character?  I felt after watching this film that Lynch had duped me into believing that he wanted to paint a picture of America
column48: but instead gave us nothing more than soft music
column49: recycled images
column50: and stock characters.  The stories were interesting to listen to
column51: but brought nothing fresh to the table.  I must admit that the brotherly love moment brought a tear to my eye (since I have a brother as well)
column52: but why couldn't we focus on this further.  Lynch made the riff between the two brothers seem like a toss in the pan
column53: when it was the central focus of this film.  The Straight Story could have been a strong tale bringing in a new image for Lynch
column54: but instead it felt jagged and old.  I could suggest one viewing for this film
column55: any further
column56: and you will see how dull those cornfields really claim to be!  Grade: ** out of ****

column1: Rather than write another review here
column2: I will instead include the letter I was compelled to write to REA when I purchased this book:  I am writing to express my deep disappointment in your Physics Subject test GRE study guide. I found its review section inconsistent and incomplete
column3: and the sample tests utterly failed to match the tone or content of the real exam itself.  As for the review section
column4: it was disappointing enough itself. Your Temperature section spends its entirety discussing the different units used to measure the property. THIS IS NOT GRE MATERIAL. If a senior year physics student cannot change between Celsius and Kelvin in his sleep
column5: I assure you
column6: he has no aspirations of continuing study in the field. Frankly
column7: he does not even have any business doing so. The rest of the Thermodynamics section suffers the same failing. The three laws of thermodynamics are the starting point for any college level thermodynamics coarse
column8: yet they close your discussion of the topic. This book fails to purvey any of the complexities of this broad
column9: interesting
column10: and very difficult field. There is no mention at all of statistical physics
column11: which is an entire branch of physics which is on the test. While this thermodynamics section was the worst part
column12: there are many problems in the rest of the book. Optics ray traces are ambiguously and inconsistently labeled. The book does a poor job of differentiating equations that are part of a derivation from those which will be encountered on the test. There is no mention of inductance in the electromagnetism section
column13: though I encountered this topic several times in actual tests (both practice and real). Impedance is also not mentioned in the circuits section. The quantum mechanics section is cut short with no mention of any of the kind of material that would be encountered in a second course
column14: such as spin
column15: angular momentum
column16: and electron transition rules. Again
column17: these are on the test.  Further
column18: your sample tests did not match up well with my experience of the actual content of the test. The GRE is not designed to be a test of student's algebra. Numerical values are very rarely given for the relevant properties in a question. As such
column19: students are tested based on knowledge of equations and unit analysis kinds of rules-of-thumb. However
column20: your sample tests included numerical substitutions in most problems
column21: and thus tested algebra abilities heavily. Students are not allowed calculators at the test
column22: so time spent on calculation is wasted. In fact
column23: I found that ability to test formulaic answer choices by unit analysis was one of the best approaches to novel or difficult problems. Had I relied heavily on your book
column24: I would not have learned this.  I'm sure I could catalogue more important subjects that were missed
column25: and find more confusing notation. Frankly
column26: though
column27: I do not have the time to waste with this book. Please realize that I understand that compiling the entire subject of physics in a single volume is a very difficult task. However
column28: in order for a book to be worthwhile for GRE preparation
column29: it must be much more complete and better organized. I consider this book a waste of my $28.95 and the valuable time I could have been studying more useful resources.  I write not to ridicule or be combative. There are not many physics GRE study guides available
column30: and a good one would be tremendously helpful to those preparing for this difficult and stressful test. The inclusion of practice tests with explained answers is a great idea. This book does have potential
column31: but it is not a good resource as of right now. It most certainly not "The Best Test Preparation for the GRE." I suggest a full review and rewrite of this book. I trust that
column32: with some work
column33: the REA can put out a study guide that is truly helpful to physics students. Please consider my encouragement to do so.  Thank you for your time

column1: I ordered this book through a bookclub and returned it.  It was terrible!  Tanya Holland is a beautiful Black woman
column2: but I feel has gone too far out of the way to create "innovative and different" recipes so much that they are not appealing and certainly should not be categorized as soul food.  The price is outrageous for the handful of recipes that were chosen for this cookbook.  I collect african american/soul food cookbooks among others.  If you are really into soul food cookbooks and what they really represent
column3: your money would be better spent on "Essence Brings you Great Cooking" by Jonell Nash
column4: "The Ebony Cookbook" by Freida DeKnight or "The Black Family Reunion Cookbook" by the The National Council of Negro Women.  If you are interested in healthier soul food try
column5: "The New Ebony Cookbook" by Charlotte Lyons or "The Family Dinner Quilt Cookbook" by The National Council of Negro Women.  If you are interested in diverse
column6: cultural flavors
column7: I would recommend Vertamae Grosvenor's cookbooks or "Iron Pots and Wooden Spoons" by Jessica B. Harris.  I have collected over 50 african american soul food cookbooks.  They cover the gamut.  That is why I can give an honest opinion on Tanya Holland's book.  I just wish that she would publish an african american cookbook that the average African American can relate to.  One that would be useful to families in their everyday cooking.

column1: FROM AMAZON.CA ---------  The Action Replay MAX is more than just a video game enhancer (VGE)....or at least it claims to be. My version is quite old yet but it claims to include a Region-free DVD player and a memory card compression utility (squeeze more saves onto your memory card). I have not used either of these features personally
column2: but I have heard horror stories about the memory manager corrupting gamesaves and whole memory cards; some reusable
column3: some permanently damaged. This and the fact that you must load up the action replay software to access saves that use the memory manager turned me off of using it. However
column4: the real reason I bought the ARMax was for its codes and I'll get to those in a second.  The ARMax
column5: like the newer Gamesharks
column6: loads its software from a CD. This is a major annoyance for me. Every time you load a game you must insert the ARMax memory card (which does I don't know what) and CD
column7: go sit on the couch and wait for the software to load
column8: choose your codes
column9: then get up and put the actual game DVD in and wait for it to load. You can't simply turn on your PS2 and go sit down. In the old days of cartridge gaming you would snap the VGE between the game and the console so you could turn on the console and go sit down. The early generation Gamesharks had a little box that would attach to an expansion slot on the PS1 or N64 and that was it. If you wanted it to load before the game
column10: you turned on its switch. Even if the ARMax was perfect in every other way (and it's not
column11: btw)
column12: it would get a maximum of 4 stars as long as you had to boot it from a CD first. I mean
column13: why can't the memory card part of it at least hold the codes for even just the current game you're playing after the system is shut off or reset so you don't have to load the software EVERY D@MN TIME.  Ok
column14: rant over. On to the codes. The user interface for the ARMax is better than the Gameshark. Functionally
column15: they are very similar of course
column16: but the ARMax just feels cleaner and easier to use. It offers a Beginner interface that includes descriptions of code functions (not for user-entered ones though
column17: if I remember right)
column18: and a more robust Expert Mode. On big advantage
column19: in theory
column20: that the ARMax has over the Gameshark is its ability to update itself using your PS2's broadband connection. The upshot is you can download new codes for your favorite games fairly quickly instead of manually typing them all in using the controller. The dark cloud to go with this silver lining is that you have no control over which codes you download; its all or nothing. And since these updates are stored on your memory card (not the ARMax one)
column21: it will quickly fill up with codes and gamesaves for games 99% of which you will NEVER play! No wonder the ARMax has the option to come with 16 or 32MB of space on its memory card. It's to store all the useless codes! Any entered codes you choose to apply will either work
column22: do nothing
column23: or lock up the game. I have come across all
column24: though to ARMax's credit
column25: mostly the former. The absurd choice forcing you to download and save updates for every game in the PS2 library
column26: when you may want just one
column27: loses the ARMax another star. A note about manually entering codes: The sub-headings and folders for a game have their own codes that must be entered if you want them to show up in the game's code list.  Finally
column28: as mentioned in the reviews by Bret Morris and Glenn Nichols (Amazon.ca)
column29: the ARMax initially did not work with the new revision of the fat PS2 a couple years ago AT ALL. This happened for me as well. I returned three PS2s and two ARMaxes before I realized it was a defect in all current versions (at the time) of ARMax. I had to send away and get a new disc direct from Intec which now works as well as expected. Since the ARMax has been on shelves for several years since I bought mine
column30: I assume any bought today would not have this problem. However
column31: at the time there was no way to find out about this problem without contacting Intec personally. Retailers were not aware of the problem and no notices were posted on the CodeJunkies web site. This inadequate treatment of a widespread problem drops ARMax down to two stars.  In my opinion
column32: if you're in the market for a VGE
column33: both ARMax and Gameshark have their pros and cons. I would assume both have released newer versions with newer features than the ones I have. Looks at the specs
column34: assume nothing
column35: and don't be afraid to e-mail the companies requesting details regarding any features you have questions about.  I apologize for the length of this review
column36: but I find there are very few in-depth reviews of VGEs on the web or in print. Maybe reviewers feel they are above using VGEs
column37: I don't know.

Peter Segal's "Anger Management" is a film with nothing going for it.  It is best described as boring
column2: annoying
column3: and devoid of laughs.  Mild-mannered Dave Buznik (Adam Sandler) is sent to anger management counseling after an unfortunate misunderstanding.  He immediately develops a problematic relationship with Buddy Rydell (Jack Nicholson)
column4: the self-help expert leading the sessions.  As the two men spend more and more time together
column5: Buznik starts to wonder if his counselor is the one who should be undergoing counseling.     "Anger Management" just does not get as much mileage out of its premise as it would like.  It is essentially a one-joke film that wears out its welcome very quickly.  Sandler and Nicholson are saddled with a script that fails to produce even a snicker.  Furthermore
column6: the parade of cameos throughout the film add nothing to the story and just feel like a lame attempt to squeeze in as many recognizable faces as possible into the proceedings.  Truth be told
column7: "Anger Management" is one of those projects that was green-lighted because of the talent involved and not because of its quality.

column6: during both times that I read it I could not put the book down.  This is the bizarre duplicitous nature of The Relic.  I do not like the story or the characters
column7: but still I have been drawn in.  As much as I hate to admit it I consider this book to be a real page-turner.    I don't think i need to go into the plot so I will list the offenses this book commits (once again this is just my opinion).  Predictability - I dont think I was surprised even once while reading this book.  It gives you the kind of cut and pasted characters that are far to overused these days.  From the first time a character is introduced you can pretty much tell whether they are in it for the long haul
column8: or merely here to serve as entree's for the monster.  The outcome of most of the situations presented are easily deciphered if given any thought at all.  Not to spoil any surprises but I'll give you one guess what happens when we are informed that the museum the beast haunts has a security system with solid metal doors that fall into place to cut off a supposed thief's escape route.  Throw in the fact that we are informed of this right before a gala premier of the museums' new attraction in which hundreds of guests will be attending and...well I think you allready know where this is going.  Poor Characters -  All your cliche's are here.  From the overworked
column9: underappreciated heroine
column10: who puts all the pieces together
column11: to the museums management staff who refuse to shut down the museums' premier even after numerous
column12: grisly murders.  Why? do you ask.  Because of revenues of course. I wonder if the museums' head director wears the same suits as the mayor from the movie Jaws.  If the characters arent fulfilling the role as a needed cliche' then they are doing the exact opposite that any sane person would do.  If I heard strange noises in a closed section of the museum I was gaurding
column13: especially after the fact that at least two horrific murders were commited in the vicinity
column14: I would call for backup before I investigated.  Of course I am sane
column15: so reverse what I would have done and you get the basic course of action most of the people in this book take.  UNBELIEVABILITY -  There were many times while reading this book when I had to stop and say
column16: "Give me a break."  I also used the expressions
column17: "Oh
column18: please"
column19: and "That is so STUPID!".  Many times we are expected to deny common sense

column22: this monkey-lizard is shot no less than 5 times and probably a great deal more with no ill effects.  I don't want to give anything more away

column1: One of the above reviewers mentions the "bouncy" and "jaunty" tone of Gardiner's rendition.  This CD is so bouncy it sounds like a Baroque precursor of disco!  "Wachet auf" lacks the grand march quality in its opening and closes with a thin chorale. No full bass harmonies in the chorales. No stirring the heart toward rapture here!  "Jesu..." is similarly thin and too fast.  I regret buying this disk and doubt I will every listen to it again.  Bach chorales and cantatas should tingle the spine and shake the cathedral windows.  Gardiner's "Bach light" doesn't fill my family room
I was pleased to get the DVD as I have been trying to get it for teaching Greek Mythology
column2: but I thought the actual packaging of the DVD rather poor especially for transferring to and from my class. The disc is not properly protected in my opinion

column1: "Creative Retirement
column2: by Rob Kelley.  Review.  This book gets off to a decent start by making the common argument that retirement without a life" is not the way to go.  So
column3: the goal of the book would seem to be to give relatively young retirees a resource of retirement leisure time activities that will lead them to a "life" in retirement.   The argument is made that retirement presents an endless cycle of 24-hour days that can lead to a disaster.  "The activities with which we fill those days will ultimately determine the quality of our lives
column4: says the author, who also, without any attribution, tells us that the current average age of retirement in North America is 57.    The first advice we get from the book is to build structure in our retirement days.   But the advice is simplistic, at best: Go out once a day, make a daily things-to-do-list, plan ahead, exercise, and indulge your favorite hobbies are some, with reduce your food intake" thrown in for some reason for good measure.   At this point
column5: doubt about this book's contribution to the world of retirement advice is increasing
column6: and
column7: for me
column8: things never get much better.  Of interest is an early point where the author makes the argument that there are no right or wrong choices in retirement and that happiness is defined individually.    But in the very next paragraph
column9: he then tells us that we have only one life and if we don't get to all kinds of crazy things
column10: we miss out big time.  Hmmmmm.  All this is followed by some chapters of general advice and information
column11: including a questionnaire we're told is a "personal analysis of your current situation in anticipation of retirement."   We're about one-sixth of the way through the book.  The rest consists of eight chapters each of which describe 10 possible retirement projects for each of the eight personality types
column12: e.g.
column13: organizer
column14: socializer
column15: nature lover or athlete.   In the "Projects for the Organizer" chapter
column16: we get such projects as "Teach a Hobby Course
column17: Have a Garage Sale
column18: and Plan an Extended Vacation."    Projects in other chapters include "Find a Soul Mate
column19: Wrap Gifts for Charity
column20: Become a Golfer
column21: and Join a Dance Group."  While I'm sure that this format can work for some
column22: again
column23: it seems too simplistic and high-level to me.   Missing for me are stories of actual retirees in the project definitions.  But a positive is that there are 80 projects covered
column24: most of which make sense
column25: high-level
column26: and most come with references to organizations
column27: companies and/or websites for further research.         The book's back cover tells us that the book will "broaden your views on which activities are appropriate for retired people."    While that may be true
column28: my feeling is that it won't broaden most folk's view by much
column29: as most of the projects suggested are already very
column30: very well known by just about anyone who already has any kind of a "life."

Many years ago I enjoyed reading Ivins' columns but unforunately her brand of independent liberalism has turned into just another mainstream media voice parroting the Democrats. Her personal hatred of George Bush has become distracting and embarrasing. Strangely enough she reminds me of Rush Limbaugh. When he began doing political commentary on the radio Limbaugh was an independent with a conservative streak and was comfortable attacking Republicans. Similarly Ivins was originally an independent with a liberal streak who was comfortable attacking Democrats. Now Limbaugh is as firmly ensconced in the Republican camp as Ivins is in the Democratic camp.  What a shame

The subject of the book is interesting but the writing style is vague and very circumstantial. What can be said in one sentence is explained in one or several paragraphs and what can be explained in one paragraph is said in a chapter or more. You don't want to put some books down once you piced them up. This book is the opposite; you cannot wait to put it down. It is very boring to read.

column1: THE FOUNTAINHEAD has been described by one of its many followers - yes
column2: followers
column3: not readers
column4: for the book is essentially unreadable -- as a "passionate defense of individualism [that] presents an exalted view of man's creative potential."   This is a fair description
column5: although it points unintentionally to the book's main flaw:  it is not a novel
column6: but a tract posing as a novel.      Traditional progressive novels tend to be suspicious of the exalted
column7: especially of those who occupy exalted positions based on birth or social class. In the case of Ms. Rand
column8: the exalted are those rare individuals who
column9: like herself
column10: must be allowed to work their will upon the world because they believe themselves exalted.  A circular argument at best
column11: a bad faith argument in truth
column12: this tacit nod to the slow ascent of the common man and woman since the Enlightenment spares Ms. Rand from plumping for monarchy which
column13: even by today's repellent neo-conservatives standards
column14: is universally seen to be repellent.  Because her main character
column15: Howard Roark
column16: architect extraordinaire
column17: is an argument and not recognizably a person
column18: he not surprisingly suffers from a lack of inner-animation.  Sensitive readers will chafe against the underlying and predictable framework that ultimately treats characters as props for Ms. Rand's objectivist philosophy
column19: an anti-progressive stew of prejudices posing as a critique of the welfare state and its "leveling effects."    Here's the problem with her "philosophy:"  for every Howard Roark it raises up as Hero
column20: it writes off millions of people as unworthy of our interest
column21: our sympathy and our compassion. Unkindness is not a philosophy most find acceptable.  With THE FOUNTAINHEAD
column22: Rand attempted to make it so and has managed to fool many.  Because she has
column23: she is therefore lauded by her conservative followers because her apologia absolves them of any responsibility for the fate of their fellow men and women.     Regrettably
column24: this book and her other tendentious work
column25: ATLAS SHRUGGED
column26: have found their way into the backpacks of idealistic college students.  One suspects that many
column27: because their relative youth causes them to see themselves as unique individuals
column28: are seduced by the notion that they
column29: too
column30: are slated for Heroic status.  I have nothing against people having heroes; young people especially should have them.  But Howard Roark is no hero.  He's a stick figure that represents a hero.  I suspect too
column31: that because of their general unreadability
column32: students think the books are "deep."   In retrospect
column33: it seems true that those people whom I knew in college who didn't finish this tract-posing-as-a-novel were people who tended to be relatively reasonable in their social and political views.  Those who did finish it
column34: on the other hand

column36: this probably remains true today.

column1: The topic is an interesting one and I give the author credit for trying to pick out key themes across a very broad and complicated landscape.  However
column2: I found the book frustrating and annoying in a number of ways.  Most importantly
column3: the book never manges to find and develop a theme; it seems to meander from topic to topic. In addition
column4: the author is far too enamored of simple computer models and spends too much timing belaboring how they work
column5: their iterations and marveling at how
column6: with the right inputs
column7: they can show outputs similar to what is observed in real life.  In addition
column8: much of what appears to be the point of the book hinges on the assumption that the extinction of a species is a failure similar to a company ceasing to be a separate stand-alone entity.  However
column9: firms disappear for many reasons other than bankruptcy - for example
column10: I don't think the stockholders and employees of Pixar thought it a failure when it was acquired by Disney.   Less significantly
column11: while Macbeth is a great play and Evelyn Waugh a great novelist his attempt to weave his many literary loves into his theory is awkward and clumsy.  He also touches on interesting topics (the collapse of Long Term Capital Management
column12: the pros and cons of monopolies
column13: evolution
column14: the introduction of New Coke
column15: the correct strategy for playing The Price is Right) but only provides superficial commentary that is very unsatisfying.  Finally
column16: he has a habit of stating the obvious as if he has made a great discovery (two car company representatives expressed great confidence in how their product lines would perform but the third said the outcome would depend on how costumers liked the product - could it be possible that companies aren't certain about the outcomes of their actions?  Could it be that companies must make decisions and those decisions could turn out to be bad decisions?  Should Paul Ormerod give his acceptance speech in Swedish
column17: or would English be acceptable?

column1: I got this as both a book and an audio file.  I had waited to read it and was surprised by both the enthusiasm of the content and its author
column2: but also by how he snuck in some odd biblically unsound thoughts (e.g.
column3: I gasped when he suggested Christ went to Hell...what Bible passage evidences this?).  I agree with how he suggests the enemy is out to deceive us and keep us asleep...but wonder if I go further how much more Eldredge will slip in of his own peculiar biblical misintrepretations.  Where were his editors when this was being written?  Why take sensible good sections and mar them with oddities?  I havent read all the reviews here but as one of those "conservatives" frequently mentioned in them I have to admit I may not even finish this book for fear of what else Eldredge has slipped up on.  I did appreciate his story about Daniel and the "delayed" angel...but am left wondering if I need go deeper into researching that as possible misintepretation too.  What a shame this book is turning into such a questionable venture for me.  We are at war as the author suggests and we must guard the source material well..the Bible well.  So far...I may join others and ditch this valiant attempt to energize Christians and return to the Word itself.  I wonder if I can get a refund

column1: This book was rather fun to read but I am not convinced that the authors have as deep an understanding of the phenomena they are writing about as they would like the readers to believe.  The book reads like a narrative
column2: full of assertions that are not backed by rigorous analysis of hard evidence.  The authors do not critically explore causal relationships
column3: nor do they talk about research that has done so.  They present only one particular perspective on the unfolding of events
column4: and they do not defend this perspective against potential criticism.  My experience with economics has always reinforced the idea that causality can be difficult to establish
column5: and can often operate in unexpected ways.  An economist must proceed skeptically
column6: being careful to explore alternative explanations and being prepared to defend assertions with theory and data.  The authors do not seem to share this view
column7: taking instead a more naive approach.  Maybe I was expecting too much; after all this book is meant to be accessible to non-economists.  However
column8: making a book more accessible does not necessitate a lack of rigour or the absence of critical thought; the authors could have removed some of the redundancy in the book (their writing is far from concise!) and replaced it with explorations of alternative perspectives.  The book would be greatly enriched by adding more discussion of research that supports (or opposes) their views

column1: Packwood attempts to create a magical paradigm using memetics as his field of study but unfortunately he abuses the subject matter.  Attempts to mystify and colour the system are lost in juvenile descriptions such as "Root Social Matrix" which he attempts to pass off as "substantial".  Even more scary are his references to meme-atoms and meme-molecules.  Memetics is a science; Packwood attempts to create a magical model using pseudo-science as his framework. He has possibly done more to damage magic's worth in the world of science than anyone else by writing such a poor book.  Pseudoscientific claptrap made worse by the courier new font in large lettering for kids - except I wouldn't let my children read this rubbish! If you want to get into Magical Memetics
column2: read the literature and make it up as you go along
column3: you can only do better than Packwood

column1: Joe Carpenter lost his wife and two daughters when the plane they were traveling in crashed. A year later Joe is still grieving
column2: he quit his job
column3: sold his house and is thinking of suicide.  He visits the graves of his wife and daughters to find a woman taking pictures of the graves. He wants to know what she is doing
column4: she says she was on the plane and survived. Men start shooting at her and then start following Joe. He wonders how anyone could have survived the crash.  Joe goes back to visit some of the people who lost love ones in the crash. The greiving family members are happy now that a woman named Rose has visited them. Joe can't figure why they would be so happy. Then the family members start commiting suicide.   Joe decides to go back to the place where is plane crashed since he has not been able to face it before now. He meets a family at a ranch near the crash site. They tell him a woman and small girl visited them the night of the crash and her name was Rose
column5: and she had a small girl with her named Nina. The same name and description of Joe's youngest dead daughter. Could Rose and his daughter be the sole survivors of the crash?  Joe finally meets Rose and she tells him that his daughter is alive
column6: then she tells him the story behind her surviving.  Enter the twilight zone!!!!    I thought that this was one of the worst books that I have ever read. I started to quit reading so many times
column7: but I figured the story would get better. But instead of better with a ray of hope

column1: I only finished this book out of morbid curiosity.  Was this book even edited???    At least one third of this book could have been scrapped on the first skim reading.  The vast majority of the "sim" development and interaction is completely unnecessary to plot mechanics or understanding of the material presented.  Their characters are WAY overdeveloped to the point of distraction.  The material and philosophy he wants to cover requires either A) vast explanation or B) toss the idea out there and let the reader do their own contemplation.  Asimov was a master at the latter.  Beneford tries the former with disastrous results - pages and pages of superfluous
column2: weird visualizations of mathematical concepts.  Asimov hinted at visualizations without losing narrative focus
column3: Beneford inundates and distracts you with them.  Then there's Panucopia.  Ultimately this entire sequence is completely irrelevant
column4: despite his weak effort to tie it in to the underlying concepts.  You can skip this entire section and actually have a more satisfying experience just wondering what the Author refers to when the "Pans" are mentioned "Oh
column5: so he gained some insight into human society when he observed some primates of rudimentary higher intelligence in their natural habitat.  Gotcha!"    As many other reviewers have pointed out
column6: he changes the characters substantially.  Hari seems to be a master politician by the end.  He's also a great orator and not very reluctant as first minister.  Dors and Yugo only share the same names as the Asimov versions.  I don't think he destroyed Olivaw
column7: but the immortal robot was far less enigmatic and mysterious by the end of it.    The conflict with the aliens in the "mesh" who have this simple desire for revenge is completely unsatisfying.  These beings
column8: capable of higher intelligence
column9: having been completely wiped out by robots under the command of Olivaw
column10: have their simple desire for revenge sated by killing a few of his underlings.  And the author clearly wants us to believe that the great intellectual Hari Seldon bought off on their whole story.    Concerning his philosophies - ultimately he doesn't even do the reader the courtesy of concluding the questions he took several hundred pages to ask and seemingly try to answer.  There is no desire to go looking in a sequel either because he just tires you out.  I can respect the author's approach in not trying to imitate Asimov and to make this a Beneford book in the Foundation universe
column11: but I can't respect his result.

column1: This book by Ron Rhodes and Marian Bodine is nothing short of a series of straw-man argumentation and non sequiturs

column3: he asserts that the hill in New York is THE Hill Cumorah of the Book of Mormon. There are a number of things wrong with this. While some have accepted such to be the case
column4: the internal geography of the Book of Mormon refutes such. The Book of Mormon makes clear that the demise of both the Jaredites and the Nephites took place near the narrow neck of land. Yet New York is thousands of miles away from any plausible configuration that could be described as this narrow neck of land. Thus the scripture itself rules out the idea that the Nephites perished near Palmyra
column5: and that the hill in New York was not known as Cumorah until 1835
column6: becoming a namesake. Furthermore

column10: which would be the source of the Book of Mormon

column1: Despite its' title
column2: this book (wide page margins and large type actually make it a distended pamphlet) is only incidentally about Pope Pius XII.  Its' real purpose is to set Roman Catholics and Muslims at each others throats
column3: and to lead Catholics to support any and all actions taken by the Israeli government against Palestinians living within Israeli-occupied territory.  It tries to accomplish this by tarring all Arabs (and by implication
column4: all Muslims) as subhuman beasts.  Throughout this noisome tract
column5: Arabs--wherever and whenever found--are relentlessly portrayed as the exact equivalent to Nazis and vice-versa.  This technique scarcely differs from that of crude anti-Jewish screeds that go from noting that Karl Marx and the Rosenbergs were Jews
column6: to claiming that Jews and Communists are one and the same.  Pius is used merely as a foil to a contemporary
column7: the notorious Nazi-sympathizer
column8: Haji Amin al-Hussaini
column9: the Grand Mufti of Jerusalem.  Considering what a low basis for comparison this is
column10: one hopes that at least some Catholics will take offense at the Pope being dragged alongside such a grotesque figure.  Not a trace of original research or primary sources besmirch these pristine pages.  Instead
column11: the book deliberately conflates two separate and highly emotive issues which will be untangled here.  1.) Pope Pius XII
column12: the Holocaust
column13: and the Jews:  For whatever it is worth
column14: this reviewer believes Pius was caught in an almost impossible situation.  Not only was there legitimate concern that more forceful denunciations of Nazi genocide might backfire; the Pope himself stood in danger of kidnap
column15: capture or murder.  Hitler certainly would not have had the least compunction about such methods; a head of state such as deposed Austrian Prime Minister Kurt von Schuschnigg was imprisoned in a concentration camp until the end of the war
column16: barely escaping execution at the last.    Questions concerning Pius' precise actions during the war have now been thoroughly muddled and muddied by sloppy research
column17: overstatement
column18: and much venom squirted by both Pius' extreme critics and extreme defenders (this book very definitely included).  A recent scrupulously fair and rigidly factual examination of these matters is "Pius XII and the Holocaust: Understanding the Controversy"  by  historian Jose M. Sanchez (available from Amazon).  Regrettably
column19: it will probably be ignored.  Everyone seems bent on finding another prosecutor's charge sheet or defense attorney's brief to augment their pre-fab opinions.  2.) Israel
column20: the Arab States
column21: and the Palestinians:  By now
column22: the struggle between (and within) these groups has become so poisonous
column23: archangels with Ph.D.'s in International Relations would be hard pressed to come up with a solution to the conflict all sides could accept.  To bitter partisans on either side equipped with guns
column24: bombs
column25: microphones
column26: or pens; no falsehood is too gross
column27: no libel too base
column28: and no tactic too vile.  By contrast
column29: Catholics (as well as Christians generally) have a Just War tradition against which all sides are to be judged.  Hopefully
column30: this ugly attempt to further poison the wells of controversy will be seen for what it is.    Perhaps the author should be congratulated; he has managed to becloud and envenom not just one
column31: but two hotly contested topics in 256 brief pages.  Nazi propagandists called this tactic `zersetzung' (literally: decomposition).  How curious to find a rabbi resorting to it
