column1: For months
column2: my father has been pressuring me to read this book.  So
column3: I finally decided to give it a whirl...  I'm only on page 14
column4: and I must say that this book is the most boring
column5: worst written
column6: biggest waste of my time masquerading as legitimate science
column7: sociology
column8: philosophy
column9: and any number of other respectable disciplines.  It says in the introduction that "instead of conducting laboratory experiments and competing for federal grant dollars
column10: he (Bloom) put his interest in mass behavior to work by playing a key role in the careers of rock stars such as Michael Jackson and John Cougar Mellencamp."  No...he went into the entertainment industry because he obviously couldn't cut it as a legitimate scientist.  So
column11: he resorted instead to the sensationalism
column12: ignorance
column13: misinformation
column14: and general bad writing between the front and back cover of this 334 page grueling read.    I know that I said I have as of yet read only 14 pages
column15: but on only the third page
column16: Bloom makes the false assertion that Saint Paul originated (no pun intended) the doctrine of Original Sin.  It was Saint Augustine!  Those who believe in Original Sin often claim that evidence for it can be found in the writings of Paul
column17: but whether or not the assertion of any such doctrine was actually intended by Paul (or whoever wrote in his name--as writing in the name of a famous person was commonplace in the ancient world
column18: and it is believed by the most reputable theologians that many of the books of the New Testament
column19: including the four currently accepted Gospels
column20: were not actually written by those persons whose names they bear) can be neither proven nor disproven.  And to assert that Paul was indeed the originator of said doctrine is irresponsible if this book is in fact not supposed to be a profession of Bloom's personal religious beliefs.    I suppose I could say the he simply didn't know any better
column21: but he should have known enough to check his facts before bringing his manuscript to publication.  Especially since this is not a first edition! He's had many many chances to edit since initial publication to sweep his errors under the rug and he hasn't!  Anyway
column22: as any good philosopher (which Bloom obiviously fancies himself) would tell you
column23: if a person gets his or her facts wrong once
column24: how do we know whether he or she is not wrong all the time?    I have skimmed through the rest of the book and have found some very unfortunate things in addition to what I have mentioned so far.  The chapter entitled "Women - Not the Peaceful Creatures that You Think" is nothing more than the musings of an antifeminist
column25: antiwoman carmudgeon who obviously has been burned and spurned one too many times.  In fact
column26: he states such nonsense as "Females are as much a part of the apparatus that triggers male violence as the men themselves" and "Women encourage killers.  They do it by falling in love with warriors and heroes.  Men know it and respond with enthusiasm."  The first part could be stretched to justify violence against women (including domestic violence and rape) by saying that regardless of whether or not women consciously "want it"
column27: they are somehow genetically programmed to "ask for it" anyway.  The second part--I don't have anything to say about that.  I think the utter stupidity of it says it all.  Don't waste your money on this inflammatory
column28: yet boring as hell
column29: garbage.  Buy an issue of Mad Magazine instead.  It's more informative
column30: more intelligent
column31: and a hell of a lot cheaper.  I can't help but wonder though whether the great misogynists of our time (e.g. radio personality R.L. and constitutional lawyer/bad author A.C.) are fans of this book..

column1: It can indeed be extremely stressful for a Japanese speaking foreigner working at a Japanese company in Japan. I say this from direct personal experience. But my impression is that the author's only skill was the ability to speak Japanese. She had no basic office skills e.g. she was unable to perform simple calculations. And she had neither business training nor business experience. Amelie Nouthomb's degree was in philology not business or economics or finance. This being the case she was unqualified to perform any complex tasks. Little wonder that her brief experience of working in Japan was such a disaster.

column1: I can't find anything good to say about this book. I used to be a huge fan of Block's work but now a lot of it makes me cringe. This is her newest book and I received it as a Christmas gift. The plot sounded good in theory (Greek Myths modernized) but I should have known better. There's barely any book here. It's a very slim 116 pages and it's written in a "poetic" style that means each page of text barely has any text on it. It took me less than an hour to read it and I was confused for a lot of it. Half the time I didn't know which character was telling the story - what little story there was to be told. The little blurb describing the book is almost longer than the book itself. I know that I probably would have loved this back in high school (or at the very least pretended to love it) when I was obsessed with Block's work but now? I can honestly say that I threw it down in disgust when I was finished and wished I could have gotten that hour back. I really don't recommend this book to anyone who isn't a teenage girl obsessed with Block's work.

column1: Edward Hirsch has written a meticulous analysis of the art of poetry

column4: their craft transcending the mortal. Their words are golden strands of virtue more appropriately whispered into the ears of gods.  But
column5: but...  For those of us uneducated in the art of poetry there is a much more basic level of understanding that has to be achieved first: Why no punctuation? Why do sentences break in mid-breath? How does one find the meter in a poem? How does one read poetry without the stops and starts from line to line? Perhaps we should have learned this in school

column7: so we bought this book.  This is a good book
column8: really

column13: the basics

column1: Is the United States a Christian country?  Well
column2: not if you believe our Founding Fathers
column3: including George Washington
column4: John Adams
column5: Thomas Jefferson
column6: James Madison
column7: Thomas Paine
column8: and Benjamin Franklin.  They argued for complete separation of church and state.   And Wills is actually quite good at telling us what Madison
column9: the most important of them in this regard
column10: said.    But America does have plenty of Christians.  And Wills claims (in 1990) that polls show nine out of ten Americans believe in god.  As a Polytheist who regards such a belief atheistic
column11: I find that a discouraging statistic
column12: but that does not mean it is untrue.  Wills also argues that an atheist (who does not believe in any Goddesses or Gods
column13: not even the monotheist one) would have no chance of being elected President (presumably being a candidate without a prayer).  Given what Adams and Jefferson said about Christianity in their letters to each other
column14: I doubt that either of their positions would get them elected today.  Wills discusses the issue of the words in our Pledge of Allegiance
column15: including the reference to the monotheist god.  I do think symbols are important.  Our flag does not have a Christian Cross on it
column16: and that's intentional.  And I do not understand either side in this dispute.  Do the Christians really want to be on the wrong side of Madison's arguments and demand that Polytheists refer to the monotheist god?  Do non-monotheists really want to appear unpatriotic by refusing to salute their own flag because of these words?  The author then moves into the debate over Darwinian evolution.  And he contrasts William Jennings Bryan at the Scopes trial not so much with Clarence Darrow as with H. L. Mencken.  Willis is quick to criticize Mencken's completely politically incorrect attacks on Women
column17: Jews
column18: and Blacks.  Well
column19: maybe I am just too tolerant.  I agree that Mencken's style was like Nietzsche's.  But I find their works thought-provoking rather than parts of a demonic theology!    Wills then claims that the real winners of the Scopes trial were not the Darwinians.  He is right about that.  After the trial
column20: the quality of American biology textbooks went way down.  Wills says "it was not Scopes that put evolution in the schools
column21: but Sputnik."  That is true.  The author then argues in favor of putting creationism into the science classroom.  I am disappointed with Wills for wanting to do this.  We're not talking about a ritual Pledge to our Flag here.  We're talking about teaching falsehoods in science classes.  Shame on him!    There is also a discussion of Jesus
column22: including the virgin birth
column23: miracles
column24: and resurrection.  By the way
column25: I have always thought these made Jesus less heroic and more attackable.  After all
column26: without any of this
column27: who would dream of comparing Jesus with powerful people such as Stalin or Mohammed or Julius Caesar?  Jesus would be a simple hero and no one would find cause to demonize him.    Wills is not afraid to talk about abortions and a Woman's Right to Choose.  My only comment on this is to say that I can't see an argument for an embryo being sacred in the first few hours after fertilization
column28: before we even know if it will be twins or not.  It is an interesting book
column29: but the comments about creationist arguments are simply wrong.  Even if Wills is being sincere and merely in error here (rather than being reckless or dishonest)
column30: I can't give him more than one star for this book after that

column1: After reading five of her novels
column2: I have become a fan of Jodi Picoult. I will admit (and this probably proves that I am a sucker for marketing rather than letting the literature speak for itself) that I've deliberately read all of her best sellers before reading the books that didn't make it on the list.   Initially I liked the book and it kept me reading
column3: though maybe just out of habit. I enjoyed reading about the Amish way of life and the Amish traditions - though it did make me think of that Harrison Ford movie
column4: Witness (circa 1989 or something). I like that she used one first person voice as well as the third person narrative in a well crafted and varied way.  I like that her main character has a powerful job that challenges gender stereotypes by being the morally questionable lawyer. That being said
column5: she doesn't explore this as well as she could. We sort of forget that Ellie has blatantly suppressed evidence and watched as little girls saw their rapist acquitted. Rape
column6: she can defend
column7: but infanticide creates some problems for the notorious defense attorney.   Something about the book bothered me. Maybe I am reading too many of her books too fast but I am seeing a formula here.  - Many of her plots include a court room drama.  - All of her plots feature romance or end with the obvious potential for one.  - Mothers and their powerful (all encompassing
column8: self-sacrificing) love for their children are a theme in all of her books I've read.  - There is usually a "twist" at the end. She's becoming Koontz like in her formulaic predictability and I stopped reading his novels as a teenager.  Most of her books left me content
column9: like I'd eaten a good
column10: hearty meal. However
column11: this book left me hungry and searching for critical reviews to see if others shared my dissatisfaction.   So: - I was unimpressed with the "twist" at the end of this one - I knew "whodunit" about 1/2 of the way through. I was getting bored with that part of the story. The red herrings are too obvious and her suggestions that Katie didn't do it were there from the beginning. She should've stopped the heavy handed attempt to make us question that and just made it known through the 3 person narrative exactly who did the killing or hiding. Then she could have explored that character in depth instead of hiding her and others she wanted you to be suspicious about. Just because we
column12: the readers knew
column13: didn't mean that Ellie had to know - or anyone else for that matter.   - The characters in this novel were a tad generic. I am sorry
column14: I like her

column17: I knew they were going to get together after a little drama from Ellie through which Coop - being the quintessential "sensitive ponytail guy" - would wait
column18: albeit in pain. It was just too predictable.  Hannah's ghost; she has a ghost hunter in a later novel and I was a disappointed to see another one. But other than that

column20: Katie
column21: might be crazy and a murderer? Is it to explain why she was so drawn to Adam? Katie being the good Amish girl could only fall for someone who could share her secret ability to see her sister... In a book that is so Amishly pragmatic and logical in every other way makes it so the supernatural element clashes with the rest of the novel. Maybe Hannah's ghost killed Katie's baby or hid it.  I liked the details. The Amish and their daily lives

column1: If you've never heard of Mark Halperin I'm not surprised.  None of us had until 2004 when a certain internal ABC News memo came to light during the Presidential campaign.  Oh yeah.  He's now known to people who were paying attention; he even coined a term:  "Halperinization" which along with "Ratherization" because hallmarks of Liberal bias posing as journalism in the 2004 campaign.  Here's the memo
column2: Dated Friday October 8
column3: 2004  "It goes without saying that the stakes are getting very high for the country and the campaigns - and our responsibilities become quite grave  I do not want to set off (sp?) and endless colloquy that none of us have time for today - nor do I want to stifle one. Please respond if you feel you can advance the discussion.  The New York Times (Nagourney/Stevenson) and Howard Fineman on the web both make the same point today: the current Bush attacks on Kerry involve distortions and taking things out of context in a way that goes beyond what Kerry has done.  Kerry distorts
column4: takes out of context
column5: and mistakes all the time
column6: but these are not central to his efforts to win.  We have a responsibility to hold both sides accountable to the public interest
column7: but that doesn't mean we reflexively and artificially hold both sides "equally" accountable when the facts don't warrant that.  I'm sure many of you have this week felt the stepped up Bush efforts to complain about our coverage. This is all part of their efforts to get away with as much as possible with the stepped up
column8: renewed efforts to win the election by destroying Senator Kerry at least partly through distortions.  It's up to Kerry to defend himself
column9: of course. But as one of the few news organizations with the skill and strength to help voters evaluate what the candidates are saying to serve the public interest. Now is the time for all of us to step up and do that right. "  Now
column10: isn't this cute?   Doesn't it explain much about how ABC presents the "news."   It is almost surreal
column11: and he still maintains that he's unbiased.   It's like a visit to Alice's wonderland to hear this man defend this memo; but it explains much about how ABC presents the news.  They are hopeless.  Yes.  He actually thinks and talks this way.    And OF COURSE he hates the news media; it's the new media which has exposed him.  They did in 2004; and with Hugh Hewitt's help this week he's being exposed to more people.    Don't bother with the book.  It's a suck-in for Liberal propaganda. THIS MAN SPECIALIZES IN DOUBLE-SPEAK.  ABC News is losing viewers and losing money; and they deserve it.

 this is not a book on *SYSTEMS* architecture.  Like that book on Enterprise (SIC) architecture that was all about LANs and not the entire enterprise ,  this book has too narrow a viewpoint.    The title should be changed so it is not misleading. The author's perspective may be *his* system but to most of us this stuff is at best a  subsystem, or merely a component, or otehr lower level item.  if you want to know about SYSTEMS architecture the key book is rechtin and maier.  there may be a recent handbook of SA that covers a number of topics but eb and mark have the only real systems architecture book that I have verified.   this book is not the book the title claims.  
 If you have read ANYTHING about shamanism or animal totems before this, this book won't add anything. If you have read NOTHING about shamanism or animal totems before this, this book will give you very little, except an oversimplified, surface, meandering view of a very deep and powerful process.  Steiger bounces around on the surface of a lot of things, including numerology, chinese zodiac, and animal collections, but never goes into depth with anything. The idea of animal totems is a loosely held theme holding the book together, but isn't looked at with any depth. It is a typical American beginner's book (a la any subject). Cheerleading - you can do it!! Making it sound easy and trivial. At one point Steiger iterates that finding your animal totems and learning to work with them might even takes weeks or months, pandering to the current tendency toward quick and easy. This type of activity is a lifelong process with serious consequences, not a parlor game to be indulged in lightly.  Steiger's book encourages people to dabble irresponsibly and expect quick results, which usually leads to inconclusive or unsatisfactory results, and often even interferes with a person's later pursuing a subject with sincerity by giving them a false sense of having gained knowledge about the subject. He also makes it easy for anyone to instantly claim any animal as her or his totem without any real inner work and connection to the process, which trivializes a deep spiritual practice.  If you are serious about pursuing working with animal totems, don't bother with this book.  If you only want a watered-down, simplistic explanation of animal totems, then maybe this is the book for you. However, it was a total waste of my money and my time

column1: I found this book extremely disappointing. The author takes a narrow view of how an individual firm can improve its competitive position by 'playing the environmental card'. Although he cites von Weisäcker et al: Factor Four
column2: he does not seem to be aware of the literature that takes a much more systemic view of how to reconcile ecological sustainability
column3: economic efficiency and commercial success. The book is perhaps useful in that it vividly demonstrates the limitations of a perspective that is centered on the individual corporation and its immediate competitive advantage with a rather blinkered view both of the scope for innovation and the wider macroeconomic framework within which business operates

column1: If "Havoc" was Anne Hathaway's "all grown-up" vehicle
column2: she needs to check the engine.  Hathaway heads up a cast of almost starlets such as Bijou Phillips and Joseph Gordon-Levitt in this drivel.  Hathaway and her friends
column3: the "PLC" as they call themselves
column4: are products of upper-class Palisades in California.  Bored with their seemingly bland lives
column5: they adopt the "gangsta" mentality of the rappers they listen to and idolize.  In truth
column6: they're nothing but a bunch of unlikeable
column7: snot-nosed posers.  We've all encountered this type before.  You see them at the mall wearing the most expensive "Rocca" wear and and "FUBU" even though they have no clue as to who or what they are actually idolizing.  They think that they have no identity of their own
column8: so they latch on to the nearest cultural group that they can find in hopes to be something that they are not and never will be.  In this tale
column9: Hathaway's group has a run-in with a Latino gang.  Drawn to these outlaws
column10: Hathaway and a few of her female friends join the gang for an all-night party.  Hathaway then returns with one of her friends (Bijou Phillips)
column11: and the two take the downward  spiral into supposed gang life.  In the end
column12: however
column13: something happens to them when they decide to actually join the gang.  Their actions cause a number of things to occur.  The results of those actions are status quo for their social status.  Although the film is pulled down by a lot of over-acting (Gordon-Levitt seems to have channeled Jamie Kennedy's "Malibu's Most Wanted" character
column14: B-Rad)
column15: the real deal killer is the actions of the supposed street-tough Latino gang headed up by Freddy Rodriguez.  First of all
column16: I'd think that a real gang would have taken out the "PLC" without flinching.  Secondly
column17: had four "innocent" little girls actually made it into the gang's party
column18: I'd think that they would have ended up either raped and dead or strung out on some sort of illegal substance.  Instead
column19: Rodriguez backs off on the posers of the "PLC" and seemingly falls for Hathaway's character enough to let her and her friends live out their fantasies of being in a real gang.  Full of characters that warrant no sympathy and an overly nice street gang who allows little girls to live out a lie
column20: "Havoc" is a dud.  Unbelievable
column21: uneventful and definitely a rental

column1: This book focuses on Amanda Starkey
column2: a young nurse who has suffered a breakdown and was sent home by her boss so she could get her act together. Amanda returns to her family home in Wisconsin to live with her sister
column3: Mattie
column4: and Mattie's daughter
column5: Ruth. Mattie's husband
column6: Carl
column7: is off fighting in France during WWI.  The sisters are very close
column8: and so Mattie is of course thrilled to have her sister back in her life on a daily basis again. They begin to embark on a new aspect of their life together
column9: while Mattie anxiously waits for her husband's return from the war.  Then
column10: one winter night
column11: tragedy strikes
column12: and Mattie ends up drowning in the nearby lake. Her young daughter
column13: Ruth
column14: almost ends up drowning as well
column15: but is rescued in the nick of time.   Not long after Mattie's death
column16: Carl returns from the war
column17: wounded. He is eager to see his wife
column18: not realizing that she has died.   Amanda
column19: who has never liked Carl
column20: hopes that he will decide to leave again almost as soon as he'd returned home. She figures him for the sort to not want to raise a child alone
column21: and each day waits for him to leave
column22: thereby making her Ruth's sole caretaker. Yet much to her annoyance
column23: he manages to get his bearings again and remains a fixture in both hers and Ruth's life.  At the same time
column24: Amanda struggles with inner demons
column25: both because of what happened to her sister
column26: and because of what happened in her life prior to returning home
column27: which you eventually learn about. She is then sent to a sanatorium and Carl is left to care for his daughter on his own. However
column28: he founders
column29: and ends up relying on a second cousin (Hilda) for her grudging help.   This new upheaval causes Ruth to regress a great deal
column30: and she stops talking and acts out by breaking things in the house and being impossible to toilet train and deal with overall. In a funny turn of events
column31: Ruth manages to embarrass Hilda enough so that she leaves. Carl
column32: in an act of desperation
column33: takes Ruth with him on one of his many visits to see Amanda
column34: in the hope that it will spark a desire in her to get well once and for all. It works
column35: and a year after having been committed
column36: Amanda returns home.  The rest of the story vacillates between what really happened the night Mattie drowned
column37: and what is happening in Amanda and Ruth's life afterwards. In the first part of the book
column38: Ruth ages from about 3-5. When the second part begins
column39: she is already 11. I felt that was somewhat abrupt
column40: and it took me a few pages to realize how much time had passed
column41: as there wasn't anything to indicate that this had happened.   The book continued to bounce around a lot from this point on
column42: between reminiscences of the past and what was actually happening to the characters months or years down the line. It got a little annoying at times to have to figure out where exactly the next installation was starting out. Also
column43: the book jacket said the story was told from several of the main character's points of view
column44: but the only ones you really hear from are Ruth and Amanda.   I was pretty disappointed by the end of the story. The book starts out intriguing and makes you wonder if Amanda literally went off the deep end after all and killed her sister
column45: or if it was in fact an accidental drowning. But by about halfway through
column46: the facts become clear and are easy to interpret. Still
column47: I hoped maybe I was wrong and the ending would surprise me after all. It didn't.  Carl also disappears about halfway through the book. It's due to a job he takes
column48: but it felt like he was written out of the story because the author ran out of use for him
column49: or wasn't sure what to do with him after a certain point. She spent a lot of time focusing on Carl's desire to learn about the truth of his wife's death.   As it was
column50: he only found out part of the truth
column51: and that was according to what Amanda got him to believe. Nevertheless
column52: Carl accepted it at face value and after that he accepted his wife's fate. He was then written out of the story. I didn't really like that aspect of things and didn't think it meshed with everything else that was happening. Even though he wasn't a strong character in general
column53: he's one of the characters I actually liked. Amanda wasn't that likeable at all
column54: and was a pretty cold person who was obsessed with Ruth and still obsessed with the past. Ruth was somewhat pliable and easily molded to her aunt's bidding
column55: even though she made some feeble attempts to be her own person.  I don't know if I'd read this author again. But I managed to find this book for $1.. and would say it was worth it and I'm glad I didn't pay full price for it
column56: either on here or in a bookstore

column2: known for his Easy Rawlins stories. Blue Light is a diversion into a genre that would fall somewhere between science fiction and new age. Various people in northern California are zapped with a blue light that makes them weird. According to the book's cover flap
column3: the light brings out the potential of any person it strikes. However in the book it simply magnifies their existing personality. A smart girl becomes really smart
column4: a young girl with quick reflexes becomes something of a ninja
column5: and a promiscuous wife becomes a sex goddess. Mr Mosley is a talented writer. His prose and some of his action sequences makes this book readable. Unfortunately there's little balance between good and evil
column6: which is problematic since the whole second half of the book is one long buildup of suspense towards a final apocalyptic encounter. Even more unfortunate is the fact the long awaited encounter is tedious and uninteresting. There's a few great and captivating scenes in this book
column7: but otherwise extremely little to recommend itself

column1: The advice Rand gives writers in this transcription of a series of living room lectures is sound in places: anchor your abstractions in the concrete; remember that art is selectivity; show

column3: etc
column4: etc
column5: etc. All good advice
column6: to be sure
column7: but to say that Rand is proposing anything new or different from what is taught in writing seminars across the country is a little disingenuous. Add to this her refusal to praise the work of any author besides herself and Victor Hugo
column8: her casual dismissal of prominent writers without convincing evidence (and
column9: even more interesting
column10: the relative paucity of authors she even brings up) and a few didactic guidelines (her ban on profanity
column11: slang
column12: and references less than one century old)
column13: and there's rather too much extraneous stuff here to be worth the effort of wading in to try to get to the good bits.  If it's advice you're looking for

The film documents Morgan Spurlock embarking on a perilous quest to eat three meals of McDonalds per day.  This diet has rules too.  Whenever he is asked if he wants a meal to be Super-Sized
column5: he must do it.  He also much try each item on the menu at least once.  He is only allowed to consume items that are in fact on the menu.  The thing is though

column4: doesn't do debate
column5: preferring mockery
column6: innuendo
column7: myth and wilfully distorted facts. It's the superior sneer of the self-styled intellectual who doesn't know what he's talking about. His unwavering belief in doctrinal socialism brings to mind a line from Emerson: "Foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds."  His defence of Marx
column8: beginning with religion being the opium rather than the opiate of the masses demonstrates his willingness to distort language. That he then manages to blend the benefits of Marxist ideology with the evils of slavery left me moderately bemused. (The American Indian
column9: who cause he champions
column10: was something of a proto-Marxist and quite happily used slaves.) His obsession with slavery and the inference that the United States was uniquely guilty of it is symptomatic of historical revisionism at its most banal. Slavery is a millennia-old
column11: worldwide phenomenon
column12: with a reasonable chance that most of us have distant ancestors who suffered it. But during the period he's most exercised about villainous white slavers didn't mount raids into the interior of Africa
column13: they purchased stock from coastal chieftains who enjoyed vast profits from the sale of fellow Africans. And who
column14: after parliament made not just the trade but the ownership of slaves illegal in Britain
column15: wrote letters of howling protest to the crown that the new law was going to ruin them. Just as Vonnegut ignores the complicity of Africans in the trade
column16: he also omits that it was white European stock that lobbied against and eventually outlawed what had existed in Africa long before the arrival of the first Portuguese explorers
column17: and continued long after it was banned by European and North American governments (or that it still exists amongst the Arabs and West Africans today). Unsurprisingly
column18: he overlooks the enslavement of over a million white Europeans by Barbary corsairs between 1500 and the mid-1800s. Spain and the Italian city states suffered the greatest depredations
column19: but the North African raiders seized thousands of Irish
column20: Cornish and Welsh and not an insignificant number of colonial American seamen. (See Christian slaves
column21: Muslim Masters
column22: Robert Davis
column23: Palgrave MacMillan
column24: 2003)  Vonnegut decries the "135
column25: 000" deaths in the bombing of Dresden
column26: deliberately ignoring that German academics now put the figure at closer to 30
column27: 000. Which is bad enough
column28: but ol' Kurt not only prefers the discredited number
column29: but makes no mention of the 60
column30: 000 British civilians killed between 1940 and 1945 by German bombs
column31: V1s and V2s.  His horror over the deaths of some 200
column32: 000 in Hiroshima and Nagasaki doesn't include the 300
column33: 000 deaths in Nanking to Japanese bullet
column34: bayonet
column35: gang rape
column36: and burning or burying alive
column37: or the three million Chinese who died during the invasion and occupation of their country by Imperial troops. Or that Allied soldiers
column38: PoWs
column39: and enslaved Asian labourers were dying at the hands of the Japanese right up to the day after that big flash over Nagasaki. Balance is not one of Kurt's strengths.  Comparing Americans with Nazis ("And with good reason.") is simply fatuous. Not even the most virulently anti-Bush liberal leftie hyperventilates at the prospect of the USA invading Luxembourg or Andorra.  "Our president is a Christian?" Kurt asks. "So was Adolf Hitler." In fact
column40: Hitler had the same disdain for religion as Marx had. The future Greater Germany was to be religion-free.  His many references to the evil of oil might have at least a hint of resonance if I knew this great sage hasn't driven a car
column41: used the subway
column42: boarded a commercial flight
column43: or used an electrical appliance that wasn't powered by his own wind-driven generator in the last 30 years.   And then...oh hell
column44: there are so many more examples of the woe-is-me-a-lone-voice-in-the-wilderness-that-knows-how-evil-America is. Vonnegut belongs to that genre of Western self-loathers who have benefited enormously from the capitalist system they hate. You'd think he might have considered settling in Sweden. Maybe he was put off by the socialist tax rate he'd have to pay.

column1: "Rules of Engagement" tells the story of an heroic fighter-driver flying Phantom jets during the Vuetnam air war.  Brad Austin
column2: an Annapolis grad and the latest in a long line of loyal US servicemen broke with tradition when he joined the Marines instead of following his fathers into the Navy.  Over Vietnam
column3: he chafes at the politically-initiated
column4: and overly restrictive rules of engagement ("ROE")
column5: watching enemy pilots pick off US fliers while shielding themselves behind the ROE.  One of the best aviators in the Marines
column6: he flies his way and barely stays within the ROE as he targets an enemy ace responsible for the deaths of many US fliers.  Soon fed up
column7: he plots one illegal flight which will clearly go over the line.  WHY THIS IS THE WORST BOOK ON THE VN AIR WAR: I gave this novel the benefit of the doubt
column8: even though it quickly proved itself to be no better than an over-glorified and under-inspired rip-off of the far superior "Flight of the Intruder".  The more enjoyable characters and irony of that other book made it the best novel of its genre.  "Rules" drops the ball where "Intruder" got it right
column9: taking a heavy-handed stand on the ROE (they deserve their bad rap
column10: but Steve Coonts wasn't afraid to see the issue from both sides)
column11: while not going into great depth about the mechanics of his hero's machine of choice - the F-4.  Next to Jake Grafton
column12: Brad Austin is as lively as an action figure - Weber unwilling to give him any of the flaws or introspection  that made Jake Grafton so believable; Austin's back-seater remains a captive passenger and nowhere near the equal of "Tiger" Cole.  Even the promising idea of having Austin romance the daughter of an anti-war fixture goes nowhere. (I kept waiting for the unhappy dad to tell Austin how he disapproves of his daughter's dating a guy who may get shot down
column13: leaving the poor girl to wonder for years whether he was dead or rotting in a tiger-cage.)  Instead
column14: Weber loads us down with details that don't do anything to substantiate the plot. Austin is a maverick of his family because he chose to fly for the Marines instead of the Navy
column15: a plot twist that's supposed to establish him as a rebel
column16: even though it has him flying the same planes from Navy ships like a Naval Aviator
column17: and facing much of the same challenges.  Even the climactic flight
column18: the one that will break the rules
column19: is a cheat.  While books like these don't mind chiding wartime planners for choosing a strategy that has nothing to do with winning the war
column20: "Rules" easily settles on an epic dogfight against the shadowy Communist ace
column21: one whose result won't have the least effect down on the ground where the war was grinding its way through an entire generation of 19 year olders.  Coonts at least chose a target his characters felt was attached to the war's larger purpose (the Communist party HQ)
column22: didn't mind using a plane a whole lot less sexy than the F-4's in "Rules"
column23: and granted his characters sufficient self-doubt to question the wisdom of their actions.  Also
column24: there's something a tad dishonest about a book that fights against the insane restrictions of ROE
column25: yet never has its main character get anywhere near having to answer for breaking them.  If you must read a Weber novel
column26: read the sequel: "Target of Opportunity"
column27: also an uninspired novel
column28: but one with amore original plot

column1: This review is more about the "SuperBit" transfer of the movie to DVD than the movie itself.  The movie itself is great and I highly recommend it.  However
column2: the transfer on to this 2002 "SuperBit" version is very lacking in several areas.  The SUPERBIT idea is a good one that is poorly executed on this transfer.  The original intent was to maximize video and audio quality by limiting or even eliminating extra features (like trailers
column3: documentaries
column4: featurettes
column5: and "Making-Of" snippets) to reserve space such that the movie can be presented in the highest quality.  They have failed to do that here.  The video and audio quality are not what they could be.  First
column6: the movie is encoded onto a DVD-9 RSDL disc.  This means the DVD is capable of storing 9.5 GB of data.  However
column7: not even 6 GB is used. As a result
column8: the video and audio quality is not what it could be.  "Panic Room" is a 112 minute movie.  Any movie that is 2 hours long or less should be able to easily fit on a DVD-9 disc at maximum encoding rate
column9: provided no extra features are placed on the disc. The maximum video encoding rate to fit a 2 hour (or less) movie onto a DVD-9 disc is 9.8 Mbps.  However
column10: this SuperBit version averages only 6.5 Mbps.  This SuperBit version offers audio encoding in 3 types: Dolby 2.0 Surround 192kbps
column11: Dolby Digital 5.1
column12: and DTS 5.1.  At first glance this is great news
column13: until you discover that the DTS encoding isn't as high quality as it could be.  The DD 2.0 Surround is presented at a bitrate of 192bkps as expected.  So is the DD 5.1 at the expected 384kbps rate.  DTS 5.1 can go as high as 1536 kbps
column14: but on this disc is presented at only 768 kbps.  This is unsatisfactory given the fact that one-third of the available disc space of the DVD-9 isn't even used.  The DTS encoding rate should be at least 1024 kbps for a movie like this.  This would represent a 33% increase in filespace for the audio portion
column15: but a much larger increase in audio quality to the human ear.  The filespace increase would be only about 256 MB
column16: which is very reasonable when you have over 3 GB of space not even being used.   If they had encoded "Panic Room" on this SuperBit disc at an average video bitrate of 9.5 Mbps
column17: and removed the trailers and features
column18: they would have had enough space to present all three audio encodings above
column19: especially the DTS 5.1 encoding at the 1024 kbps rate I stated.    Such an encoding process would have used 9.4 GB of the 9.5 GB of available space.  A much better way to fill up the DVD-9 disc and adhere to the spirit of the SuperBit ideal.  The result would have been a movie encoded to DVD-9 at a much higher video and audio quality than what was presented on this disc.  I notice that they will be offering a repackaged SuperBit version in October 2006.  Hopefully that version will fix the flaws I just mentioned and present the movie in the highest encoding rate both video-wise and audio-wise.  It might even offer the better DD-EX 6.1 and DTS-ES 6.1 audio encodings for that extra rear center channel that many A/V receivers can process now.  Another thing I am noticing is that many times
column20: for popular movies
column21: they are released them in 2-disc editions.  The first disc contains only the movie and the second disc is all the extra stuff.  If the movie contains both DD and DTS encodings on the first disc
column22: with a very high video bitrate of 9.0 Mbps or greater
column23: it is already in the SuperBit mold.

column1: Sojourn is the conclusion of the Dark Elf Trilogy which began with Homeland
column2: continued in Exile and ends here. If you've not read the first two books then I suggest you do so now because the third book is a direct continuation of the other books and you'll be missing out quite a lot by starting here.  Exile was a notch below Homeland. It suffered from poor characters and a very predictable storyline and Sojourn isn't much different. None of the characters from the first two books remain(besides Drizzt of course) so the reader has to deal with a whole new cast. For the most part
column3: these new characters are very one dimensional and similar to the characters in Exile in that there's no attachment to the characters. They're just stage props that Drizzt interacts with before moving on to yet another part of his journey. Characters leave or die out of the blue and they're not very fleshed out. The only decent character Montolio receives almost no development besides a page or two about his past. The author could have spent more time on the characters instead of writing overly long
column4: 10 page battles that go nowhere.   The action returns here in quantity as in the books before. Again
column5: it feels that more of the book is spent in fights than anything else and the battles themselves are completely too long and are littered with many unnecessary descriptions.   The writing too is the worst yet. There are many sentences that just don't read well at all and show a very amateur style. The book itself is very simplisticly written so it will appeal to the younger crowd but if you're looking for some deep
column6: well written fantasy then look elsewhere.   The poor writing
column7: weak and boring characters
column8: and overly long battles are the main downfalls of the book. The world still remains rather interesting with interesting creatures and a lush
column9: although not fully developed world. The story is rather weak too as it just continues on the course exile took. The story is uninspired and nothing much really happens throughout; Drizzt just moves from one place to another with a few small stops and adventures. It's probably the worst part of the Dark Elf Trilogy although the ending does introduce some new characters that may bode well for the Icewind Dale trilogy.

Were you ever in love? Apart from Ambrose? -Yeah.   If you want to read a truly talented Canadian author who really does have a lyrical sensibility

column1: Normally
column2: I like film noir and Clive Owen so I thought the two together would be an unbeatable combination. The premise was provoking enough--the son of a compulsive gambler takes a job as a croupier in a casino to make ends meet. Will the addiction that ruined his father and his family drag him in as well? Is Jack stronger than the siren call of the roulette wheel or does he simply have a different kind of addiction? Unfortunately
column3: these themes of fathers and sons and coming to terms with family history are not well-developed and the story kind of peters out. I was on the verge of turning off the DVD at several points because I was both bored and depressed
column4: but hung in there hoping that it would improve. It didn't. The film makers seemed to think that unnecessary female nudity would make up for the main character failing to have an epiphany. It doesn't. The ending was also confusing. Was Jack's girlfriend killed as payback for the botched robbery or was her death completely unrelated? Bottom line: a lot of good actors are wasted in what is a very unsatisfactory film

column4: all of the new material sounded alike and completely lacked the life of previous material.  I think it's safe to say

I am sad to say that I wasted precious summer leisure reading to this book
column2: suggested to me by my wife.  She was not sure what to think of it
column3: and I was to confirm what she couldn't say.  She picked it up because of its "National Book Award Finalist" stamp on the cover and the novelty of the back cover abstract.  The novel begins with so much potential and the writing is especially competent that I couldn't help but feel let down when the whole thing begins to fall apart.  When Egan throws in a wild internet scheme and a mysterious possible terrorist
column4: it is easy to see that she has let the book wander away from its premise.  What could have been an intelligent book about identity gives way to a cheap thriller. 	It makes one wonder about the books chosen for book awards. While this book was only a finalist
column5: I still have to wonder why it would have been in contention.  I certainly don't expect my personal tastes to match those of these committees given the task of choosing the best books
column6: but I do expect to be able to understand the merits of a chosen book
column7: to see what others might see in it.  Did the National Book Award folks decide on ambition alone?  I certainly think Egan began with a topic challenging to author and reader
column8: but doesn't the fact that she fails in her task weigh in the decision?  I suppose I hadn't been let down more by a book in a long time and much of the reason was because of that silver stamp on the cover

column1: No idea why this little nothing of a book is earning such positive recommendations. (Well
column2: I note that one five star review below is by one of the book's co-authors!) It is not really anything more than a one prayer
column3: one page instruction book for the rosary
column4: with the prayer on the right page
column5: a small illustration on the facing page. Do you know the little blue "Pray the Rosary" books by Rev. Lelan
column6: printed since the 1950s by the Catholic Book Co.? Exactly the same idea here
column7: but in a little hardcover
column8: with Medieval icons as the illustrations. Actually it's not even as good as those little give-aways
column9: since they offer memorable little thoughts to help focus the prayer: "I desire forgiveness for my sins
column10: I desire the virtue of patience
column11: etc. This book does offer brief scriptural readings to accompany each prayer, its true--but then so does a rosary pamphlet I picked up for 50 cents.   Sorry to be so grumpy about it; I was just expecting more. There's nothing wrong with this book per se. It just doesn't offer anything that you can't get elsewhere in free or nearly free Catholic publications.   Additional Gripe: Notice how glorious and grand the illustrations seem if you preview this book with the Search Inside feature. But this book is about 3 by 5"
column12: so the pictures are around 2" by 3"
column13: about the size of a wallet photograph

column1: My first review of this book is the Customer Review dated June 6
column2: 2000. Without retracting anything I wrote in that review or my rating of the book
column3: I would like to supplement my first review by suggesting three "entry-points" into the book for serious-minded readers:  (1) Mr. Fogel writes on page 10 - 'Technological advances in distilling reduced the costs of spirits and made it possible for the urban poor to afford immoderate amounts of alcohol. Reductions in the cost of ocean transportation brought huge waves of immigrants into American labor markets
column4: lowering wages and promoting urban unemployment.' (From roughly 1875 through 1914.)  Consider the perspective of a social scientist who acknowledges the massive destitution of the early twentieth century's workers and their families in America (see next paragraph)
column5: but who finds remarkable causally the cheap ocean transportation rates paid by immigrants and their immoderate alcohol consumption in America; and who nowhere mentions either the industrial magnates who benefited -- not coincidentally -- from those two phenomenon
column6: or the American labor movement which was fought most effectively for years by those magnates using those immigrants as scabs and strikebreakers. Maybe it's time to stop thinking of Robert Fogel as a historian
column7: and consider him simply a practitioner of the world's greatest pseudo-science
column8: economics.  (2) Mr. Fogel writes on page 177 - 'The new equity issues in the United States do not arise from the shocks of rapid urbanization
column9: the destruction of small businesses by competition from industrial giants
column10: the massive destitution created by the prolonged unemployment of up to one-quarter of prime-aged workers
column11: the disappearance of the frontier as a safety valve for urban unemployment and poverty
column12: or the undernutrition and premature death of the great majority of urban workers and their family members. Quite the contrary
column13: the new issues are to a large extent the product of the solutions to these problems achieved by a combination of economic growth and the success of the reforms advocated by the Social Gospelers
column14: their allies
column15: and their successors.'  Imagine what Mr. Fogel means by the word 'solutions.' And in light of the facts described in the book American Apartheid
column16: for example
column17: consider which population(s) suffering "urban unemployment and poverty" Mr. Fogel thinks have had their problems solved by economic growth and the reforms advocated by the Social Gospelers
column18: etc.  (3) Mr. Fogel writes on page 180 - '....the reform agenda spelled out by the religious Right......more fully addresses the new issues of egalitarianism than does the Agenda of the Third Great Awakening.' (The T.G.A. being the widespread reforms in America beginning at the end of the nineteenth century which led to the rise of the welfare state and policies to promote diversity.)  Imagine what Mr. Fogel means by the word 'egalitarianism.

I love historical fiction and found the premise behind this book compelling enough to want to read it. The plot was easy enough to follow: an exiled queen befriends a recently freed slave (once a prince in his own country) and the two secretly marry and have a child together. This part of the story was interesting and compelling enough to make me want to read on
column2: but the long religious dissertations and never-ending references to upcoming war and the complexities of European politics at the time often left me confused and bored. A geneology chart and a short explanation of the time's politics at the beginning of the book would have been extremely helpful. In addition
column3: the author seems to have a strong preference to elaborate details and conversations with huge
column4: fancy words. I can't imagine that these people would actually use them in daily conversations and it only added to the tediousness of trying to get through the story. Simpler wording and language would have made for an easier and more pleasant read and would not have taken anything away from the storyline.  This book was immediately sold to a used bookstore when I finished it. I would have loved to continue on reading the rest of the trilogy
column5: but don't have the time to be so taxed in my reading efforts

Jane Smiley's _A_Thousand_Acres_ had a great deal of potential.  It had a powerful plot (King Lear) that has been little-adapted in modern times.  Smiley chose an interesting and rich setting in her modern day heartland farm.  However
column2: the actual execution of the book leaves much to be desired.  First and foremost
column3: Smiley writes exactly like a writer who has just completed a college writing program.  She uses smart and subtle humor (one may say wit)
column4: metaphors and similes.  The problem is that one is conscious at each and every juncture that she is using a simile
column5: a metaphor
column6: or a quip.  While more seasoned writers might have woven beauty into readable text or else have chosen to complexify and engage a reader
column7: instead she chose a middleground that is neither challenging nor readable.  The reader constantly is forced to swallow some rather ridiculous metaphors
column8: all the while conscious that they are swallowing a textbook
column9: but ridiculous
column10: metaphor.  And while the plot taken from Shakespeare had a lot of potential
column11: it was handled quite inexpertly.  Yes
column12: Smiley chose the intelligent path and abandoned Lear about 3/4 of the way through (so that everyone doesn't die).  However
column13: once again
column14: she writes in a way that makes every reader -conscious- that she is adapting Shakespeare
column15: and at times the plot seems ridiculous in its current setting.  Yes
column16: she sheds new light (the protagonist is the Goneril-character
column17: who was a Shakespearean antagonist) in a very intriguing way.  Yes
column18: she invents new excuses for her behavior (former child abuse)... however
column19: had she not tried so hard to make the reader conscious that she was adapting Shakespeare
column20: these plausable interpretations might not have seemed -in-plausable.  All in all
column21: a book with many potent seeds that were not sown to anything near their full value

Despite its lofty status as a revered icon of English literature
column2: one only has to fight through a dozen or so pages to reach the painfully obivious conclusion that Ulysses is
column3: in fact
column4: unreadable gibberish.      The book has no plot
column5: no dramatic arc
column6: no message
column7: a (literally) pedestrian structure
column8: and sentences constructed by means of a random walk through the dictionary as well as through Dublin
column9: Ireland.  It has no discernable central thought.  No one can tell you what the book is about
column10: for it is about nothing.  But wait
column11: perhaps there is an underlying theme
column12: albeit one well hidden.      Remember the fable of the Emperor's new clothes?  Guillible courtiers were induced to beleive that a charlatan tailor had sewn garments for the Emperor that only suitably refined folk could see.  In reality
column13: there was nothing there at all.  Jame Joyce and generations of literary sycophants have convinced impressionable students that Ulysses is a worthy read.      When the uninitiaed find the text incoherent
column14: this failure is chalked up to insufficient literary maturity.  It can't be the fault of the book's alcohol-addled author.      "Press on
column15: the professors say, Ulysses' gloss will be revealed if only one perseveres past the many opaque chapters
column16: thus developing the right sensitivities."      However
column17: looking longer at this nonsense only reveals the glaring absense of rational content and the transparent emptiness.  The self-indulgent Emperor Joyce has no clothes.      The most damming indictment of this over-wrought tome is the fact that it is impossible to find ten people who have actually finished it.  Ulysses is one of those books that everyone has heard of
column18: but no one has read.  Hence the market for Ulysses crib cards for use at cocktail parties by poseurs with literary pretensions or by guys with dates with English Lit chicks whom they are trying to bed.  Perhaps Ulysses has some tactical utility after all
column19: as an example of inverse Chick Lit.      One supposes that the stream-of-consciousness descriptions of nose picking
column20: masturbation
column21: and sex broke ground for serious literature when published in the 1920's.  Joyce deserves some credit for expanding the gross horizons of writing
column22: but today's target audiences find those subjects ordinary and routine.  This taboo-breaking history is hardly sufficient reason to examine Ulysses now.  To be timeless literature
column23: a book must speak to fundamental truths about ourselves.      But what
column24: if anything
column25: does Ulysses tell us about the human condition?  I suggest its plot-free message is one Joyce didn't
column26: or couldn't
column27: intend.  That is; to trust one's educated common sense.  If
column28: to you
column29: a book walks like a duck
column30: looks like a duck
column31: and sounds like a duck
column32: then it was most likely written by a quack.      If this stream-of-consciousness genre appeals to you
column33: for a much better read get anything by Hunter S. Thompson.  Dr. Gonzo's book will be more coherent
column34: make more sense
column35: and will be better crafted.  And
column36: your eyes won't glaze over after ten pages
column37: as they will with Ulysses.

column1: "Good morning class.  Today we are going to learn about a trillion different kinds of rocks.  Now the softest rock on the Mohs scale is talc...  The hardest rock is diamond."  At this point in time I am snoring really loudly on my desk and dreaming about the second I get out of the class.  Annie Dillard
column2: you have just been the teacher of that class.  You taught me all about rocks
column3: jokes
column4: dancing
column5: and rebellion.  All of this stuff I either know about or don't care about.    This book provokes a lot of emotions in me - emotions that can otherwise only be felt when a family member has died.  Just to look at this book brings my eyes so much pain that
column6: if I look at it again
column7: I will most definitely go blind.  Writing this review has really made me learn to appreciate good books
column8: and to never take books at face value.  I have read some reviews on this book and many of them hailed it as "amazing".  Never in the course of my life will I ever believe a review on anything to do with culture.  This book gave me a prophetic epiphany and
column9: seeing as I am an atheist
column10: I do not normally get those.  During my sleep a demon came to me and shoved this book into my face.  In the night
column11: I woke up with a searing pain in my head that would not go away for hours and my vision has been slightly impaired since.  This is no joke.  I am sure there is a psychological explanation for this
column12: but whenever I pick up the book I get a feeling of nausea.  The book lacks cohesion
column13: but many other reviewers have already commented on this (so I don't have to).  There is
column14: however
column15: one cohesive element to this book
column16: and that is the title "An American Childhood".  If you do not get a sense that this is a boring book just from the title then you have some incurable issues.  The title describes a childhood in America
column17: and since this book is mostly published in America
column18: many people can relate to it too closely
column19: which takes away the purpose of this book.  Annie Dillard was a normal child so she wrote a normal book.  However

column1: I was expecting accurate information regarding the history of Christmas songs and carols. Instead
column2: Ace Collins has taken some facts about the carols and woven fairytales around them. In some cases he has taken a few facts and assumed results that are erroneous.   Having personally researched "Silent Night" in Austria
column3: I can say for certain that Collins has presented another fanciful story based on some facts and some misconceptions about the world's best-loved carol.   The tale about "The Twelve Days of Christmas" being a secret catechism for Catholics in the period when they were oppressed in England doesn't make any sense. The "secret" Catholic beliefs it supposedly hides are identical to the Protestant beliefs of that era. Therefore there was no reason to keep them secret from Protestants -- 1 =  one God
column4: 2 = Old and New Testament
column5: 3 = gold
column6: frankincense
column7: and myrrh -- and so on.   Sadly
column8: it's just another feel-good Christmas book when it could have been a valuable resource for people wanting accurate information.

column1: Back in his day Heinlein was the greatest writer of science fiction for adolescent boys. Unfortunately

column4: sexual coupling of old men and young girls is a recurring theme. Examples: The two female lead characters brag to one another how they had their first sexual experience at ages 12 and 14 and with men 4 times their age.  The male lead goes back in time and has sex with his sister
column5: then a young teen
column6: and he
column7: at this point
column8: the oldest man in human history.  To make all this go down easier
column9: the young females are the sexual aggressors and the old men are pursued
column10: and said to be 'tripped' if she has her way with him.  There is a lot more of this 'weird sex'
column11: but I will move on.  This is not really a science fiction story per se
column12: but there are a few trappings of science fiction used to decorate the story.  Most of it takes place in the first half of the 20th century in mid America.  There isn't really a plot.  The book is a series of anecdotes occuring in the life of this unlikely heroine
column13: seemingly Heinlein's feminine ideal.  It is obvious that the author has run out of ideas at this late point in his career.  This book would not have been published if it was the work of an unknown author.

column1: Wittgenstein said that the purpose of a popularization is to make people think they understand something they don't understand. Einstein's book on relativity is a case in point
column2: as is this book in which the candid reader is informed that "Objects at rest tend to remain at rest

column5: I know something about Physics.  Back in the seventies I built a particle accelerator out of a blow drier and a box of Mike and Ikes.

This book was such a huge disappointment. Having experienced the good and bad sides of mommy cliques
column2: I thought the idea of this book was so great and I was really looking forward to reading it.  Unfortunately
column3: this wasn't a funny and inspired take on the "insanity of motherhood" at all.  It was a judgmental and mean-spirited attack on what seemed to be as many women as the author could think of.  I had to force myself to finish it
column4: and only did so in the hopes that it would somehow redeem itself in the end (it didn't).  Each "character" in the book is an extreme caricature of a real person
column5: snarkily drawn around whatever characteristic they might have that offends the author (ie is different from her beliefs about mothering).  This is especially ironic because her main complaint about many of these women is that they are not accepting of those who are different from themselves.  Yet
column6: that is exactly how the author appears to the reader - as completely unwilling to look for the good in people who might not be exactly the same type of mother as she is.  All of the mothers in my moms club and playgroups share some of the traits the author scorns in this book
column7: but none of them are such cartoonish people as the characters in her books.  And none of them are so quick to judge and find others lacking as are her denizens of Mommy Land (and as she appears to be herself
column8: based on her scathing portrayals of the women in her book).  It's so sad to think of everyone being labeled
column9: categorized
column10: and marked off as unworthy of friendship or respect just because they happen to feel differently than you do about breastfeeding
column11: Bugaboos
column12: or bedtime crying.    As a side note
column13: I was astonished to see so many typographical errors in such a short book.  Although the book is barely 1/4" thick and only took an hour to read
column14: I lost count of all the errors and mistakes; it seems as if there was no editor or proofreader at all.    If you really want to give this book a chance
column15: check it out from the library so you can put your money towards a higher quality title.  Hopefully that way you won't feel as cheated as I did!

column1: Am I the *ONLY* person who thinks Thoreau was an arrogant snob who did nothing but whine? Maybe it's because I'm an Englishman in America but all I hear is American educational institutions praising Thoreau's "Civil Disobedience". I don't deny that he has made some points worth considering in his book but many people have made the same points without whining and railing at humanity.  I would dearly like to say I had the patience to read this book all the way through but it is perhaps the only book I've ever read that I couldn't finish. I found it hard to separate Thoreau's genuine
column2: honest observations from his juvenile complaining.   The phrase that I found mose running through my head (shortly before I deleted the book) was "o'erweening arrogance". The man's arrogance is astounding. He supposes himself so far superior to his peers in EVERY way.  I found his writing to be confused and self-serving. He could barely hold a topic for one page at a time before veering off on to another
column3: entirely unrelated one. He skips from subject to subject and often contradicts himself within the same chapter.  I got the electronic version of this book and
column4: to date
column5: it is the only book I have actually deleted. So
column6: I'd love to pepper my "critique" with quotes that I found completely offensive and juvenile but that would mean getting the book again and I *really* don't want to do that

column1: This HGW novel is not as satisfying as his more famous  sci fi pieces
column2: but it is representative of turn-of-the-century interest in galactic exploration.  Related in the first person by an impoverished would-be playwright
column3: Mr. Bedford (for whom no first name is given)
column4: the story opens as he makes the acquaintance of an eccentric scientist named Cavor in a coastal area of England.  Gradually persuaded by the latter's dreams of conquering gravity by means of a substance he will eventually invent
column5: Bedford soon becomes an enthusiastic convert to theoretical astronomy; he injects some practical ideas-as well as his private dreams of avarice and proprietary empire.  Ah
column6: the temptation of creating one's little sphere of power.       Embarking on an odyssey in a sphere made of Cavorite the partners in adventure land in a crater on the moon
column7: where they encounter odd vegetation which flourishes during the two-week lunar day.  But even more amazing is their discovery of a species of intelligent beings (described by Cavor as ant-men) who dwell in the moon's interior.  When captured the two men fight their way back to the surface
column8: but become separated.  Assuming that Cavor has been killed by the native Selenites (Cavor;s term for them)
column9: Bedford manages to return to Earth
column10: but the story does not quite end there.  What is the source of mysterious transmissions from the moon and--equally curious--what causes them to cease?  Wells' protagonists express the author's commentary on man's propensity for warfare and injudicious zeal to modulate alien civilizations due to our anthropomorphic egocentrism.  Nevertheless
column11: this book offers great sci fi lore which will appeal to kids of all ages!

I like the way other authors develop their characters by showing us how they behave
column7: react and what they say in different situations.  I think having a character kick a dog (3 words) tells you a whole lot more about them than 50 pages of superficial drivel

column1: Barber's trenchant jargon updates slogans for class-warfare and utopian proletarian dictatorships. The rhetoric relies on emotion to bridge logical leaps
column2: hides a distain for cause and effect relationships and sidesteps questions about human nature.  Instead
column3: Barber carelessly brews a mix of hip buzzwords and mass marketing clich. If you read this tome
column4: be prepared for endless repetition of 'the capitalist is dangerous
column5: but united the people cannot be defeated':  Repeat the following 5 or 10 times and you have the book in a nutshell: "Jihad pursues a bloody politics of identity
column6: McWorld a bloodless economics of profit. Belonging by default to McWorld
column7: everyone is a consumer; seeking a repository for identity everyone belongs to some tribe. But no one is a citizen. Without citizens
column8: how can there be ..." {fill in the blank with any utopian quality: justice
column9: happiness
column10: equality
column11: etc.}  The central problem for 21st century Marxists is updating the logic of class struggle.  In the first half of the 19th century Marx taught a strict evolutionary progression from noble-savage to slavery
column12: from slavery to feudalism
column13: and from feudalism to capitalism.  Within a few years
column14: Marx predicted
column15: capitalism would collapse and the unavoidable socialist utopia would emerge.  Of course
column16: the collapse didn't happen and Marxist have been rationalizing ever since.  Lenin had to add the Imperialist phase.  21st century Marxist need to show imperialism mutating into  global consumerism.   Towards this end
column17: Barbour argues: 1. Capitalists have shed their 'nationalist' identity
column18: finding it easier to enslave the proletariat via media manipulation. 2. Media manipulation (global consumerism) seeks to replace indigenous cultural identities with slavish loyalty to global products.   3. 'Wild Capitalism' promoting global products causes criminal damage to indigenous communities
column19: and threatens environmental catastrophe.  4. Protecting these indigenous communities (victims) will require violence (socialist revolution).  Hidden beneath this victim-oppressor dualism lies the traditional Marxist faith in central planning or 'government by intellectuals.' Democracy can be dismissed because the 'means of communication' are held by the multinational capitalist elite.  And
column20: Marxist don't need an elections
column21: as intellectuals they already know what is best for everyone else. Thus
column22: Barber spends the second half of the book describing the failures of democracy. Barber asserts that "the epoch on whose threshold we stand -- post communist
column23: postindustrial
column24: post national
column25: yet sectarian
column26: fearful
column27: and bigoted -- is likely also to be terminally post democratic."   Time has not been kind to Barber. His 1995 predictions of post-democratic cultures has failed to materialize.  The 90s were not a decade of American decline.  Despite his attempts to be hip and techno-savvy
column28: he entirely misses the dot com craze and  blogosphere. Further
column29: failed to address the rise of Islamofascism.  He calls commercialism all sham
column30: but relies entirely upon its rhetoric.  Consider the cover photo
column31: why is the girl wearing so much makeup behind a chador?  How is she getting the Pepsi through the chador to here lips? The book has nothing to do with Islam
column32: it is just a marketing sham about marketing shams.  In the end
column33: it sell 'Barber
column34: the hip international intellectual' and little else

column1: Prof. Gardner's book is disappointing. He tries to be all things to all people saying both that he believes in basic competencies but wants to put inquiry first. Also
column2: his language is inflated
column3: and lacking in philosopical specificity. For example
column4: he believes in building up the inner world of "mental representations" [unexplained term] yet insists on "performances of understanding" [another unexplained term].   Also
column5: he has respect for the individual learner and individual differences
column6: yet he is concerned about the "position" or "situation" or social class dynamics in which the learning takes place. Thus
column7: he fails to do justice either to the individual or to class
column8: race
column9: or gender.  The role of leadership in learning is wholly ignored; and responsibility is not explored.  In short
column10: it is extremely difficult to pin down Prof. Gardner. It would be kind to say he is eclectic. I hope it's just not fuzzy thinking.  However
column11: we can discern that he has a romantic obsession with beauty
column12: truth
column13: and goodness. Imagine -- the Holocaust is reduced to being an illustration of what goodness is or is not! His treatment of these ideas is superficial and banal. I don't like to be so judgmental
column14: but his writing about them does not deserve a detailed analysis.  When attacking E.D. Hirsch whom he calls the main speaker for "cultural literacy
column15: he sets up a straw man. He says that Hirsch's school of thought has an underlying belief in the Lockeian tabula rasa." Yet
column16: I find nothing in Hirsch's writings to indicate that he believes in a tabula rasa.   Further
column17: is Prof. Gardner really less elitist than Hirsch as some have claimed? I have found that the Harvard elite spend their entire lives trying to achieve and learn everything
column18: and be on top. Their lives are marked by ambition to the Nth degree; yet
column19: he debunks time-honored and experience-honored content areas that traditionally have defined literacy at its best. Thus
column20: I find a certain inherent dishonesty in Gardner's presentation.    Believe me
column21: friends
column22: I have taught students who have many ideals
column23: Greek ideals and other ideals
column24: but know very little
column25: nor do they aspire to learn. If they have those ideals
column26: and if they are facile and glib
column27: will they be the leaders of tomorrow who are embraced by Prof. Gardner?  I find a tendency on Prof. Gardner's part to oversimplify certain issues like the Holocaust
column28: and to overcomplicate certain others like the nature of intelligence.   The world is not waiting for the concept of intelligence to be re-written.  Am I oversimplifying when I think that there is something very awkward about saying that there is no fundamental difference in intelligence between Einstein and the custodian of my school? Is this awkwardness because I am an elitist putting down the custodian?  Is it because of lack of intelligence that I am still in the grip of a univocal definition of intelligence? I don't think so. Rather
column29: we all know we are dependent on each other
column30: and that everybody has some unique aptitudes or gifts they can express and be respected for
column31: but trying to elevate this understanding to a higher level of truth or intellectual significance seems to me to be illegitimate.   Lastly
column32: his writing style is a bit too fond of adjectives
column33: and the book reads as a whole like It Takes A Village by Mrs. Clinton. The Disciplined Mind has a mellifluous style that presents itself as being highly sophisticated and
column34: at the same time
column35: as down-to-earth
column36: with balanced common sense. Yet
column37: ultimately
column38: the book is boring.  As one Amazon reviewer states
column39: Prof. Gardner is full of himself.    In this book
column40: there is no straightforward discussion or emphasis placed on knowledge
column41: justice
column42: Judeo-Christian values
column43: persistence
column44: responsibility
column45: or character development...words which I find essential for a true philosophy of education.
