column1: Interesting premise
column2: but the plot is like swiss cheese.  This review will just be a point by point of all the major things that I found so implausable that I couldn't just suspend disbelief and enjoy the ride. Spoilers alert.  I wasn't able to make the leap to believing Sarah's sudden turn towards malicious opportunism as soon as she saw the cash. When questioned about what she would do if she found some hypothetical millions
column3: she insists with chirpy disinterest that she would certainly turn it in. Just one scene of her looking longingly at a brochure for a holiday she couldn't afford would have established some repressed dissatisfation with her life situation
column4: but her general demeanor seemed to suggest not only comfort
column5: but satisfaction.  Why did Hank decide he would burn the money instead of return it if it turned out someone legitimately owned it? Surely it wouldn't be too difficult to anonymously return it without being implicated in it's disappearance. The first murder
column6: after the old guy regained consciousness
column7: why did Hank not try to negotiate with or threaten the old guy to keep quiet about his brother assaulting him? For Hank
column8: finishing the job his brother started didn't seem like an absolute last resort
column9: it seemed like he took the murder lightly.  When Hank got home apparently he volunteered information to his wife about what he'd just done. What? Like he knew she'd be understanding about it or something? Hi honey
column10: I'm home
column11: by the way I just killed a man to protect the money. Wtf? When Jacob shot Lou to protect Hank
column12: why didn't Hank just give the tape back before it got to that point?  The shotgun impact on Lou's wife was cartoonishly ridiculous
column13: sending her flying three feet into the air when the blast didn't even hit her at an upward trajectory.  And the final ridiculous flaw. Jacob taking the fake FBI agent's gun
column14: and instead of just shooting himself before his brother had time to react
column15: he hands it to his brother
column16: and charges him with the responsibility of killing him
column17: setting up the final emotional crescendo of the film. Supposedly the explanation was that it wouldn't look like the fake FBI agent shot Jacob if the shot was fired at point blank range
column18: but why not? Why couldn't forensic investigators at the scene believe an altercation could have transpired where Jacob charged at the gunman from behind when he was about to shoot the sheriff
column19: wrestled with him
column20: and wound up taking a point blank shot to the head? It really makes no sense.  One inspiredly believable moment I will give them film credit for is Hank's difficulty in finding the bullets in the sheriff's office and loading the gun. A lazier writer would have just had him find the gun loaded. If the major plot developments were fleshed out in more detail to be made believable this could have been a great film. As it is
column21: it's a frustratingly flaw-ridden glimpse of what could have been and a waste of time to watch.

column1: This particular edition of Sun Tzu's "The Art of War" is a bare literal translation prefaced by a rather wordy introduction that pads the book up to a total of 96 pages.  While the translation is not bad
column2: the book contains no explanations or notes to enlighten the readers on some of the more obscure points
column3: such as the modern equivalents of ancient Chinese distance measures.   The one sentence review
column4: pronouncing this to be the best translation
column5: was perhaps a bit generous.  Among both military and history buffs
column6: the prevailing view is that the translation by Lionel Giles
column7: of the British Museum
column8: is the definitive translation.  Of the various available editions of the Giles translation
column9: the Special Edition that contains two complete copies of the English text - one with and one without extensive notes and commentary - in addition to the complete text in Chinese characters - is far and away the best.  The $4.95 price for this book (or for the matchbox size miniature edition from Running Press) is a bargain only for those who are more concerned with price than with value.  Choosing a better edition of "The Art of War"
column10: rather than this rather skimpy edition
column11: will be money well spent.  It is far better to own a book you can be proud of and which does a better job of informing you than this merely passable edition.

column1: Don't believe the hype.  This book is not a masterpiece

column1: Having been famous all over eastern Europe for its beauty and splendor
column2: the amber room's unsolved disappearance in 1945 caused a true flood of unbridled speculations. The mystery proved itself extremely fertile for all sorts of fantasy-stories
column3: mystery-novels
column4: faked history reviews and other nonsense.  What is known & proven: after having been conquered by Adolf Hitler's soldiers in 1941
column5: the room was transported from its palace outside Leningrad (= nowadays' St.-Petersburg) to the German city of Konigsberg (= nowadays' Russian Kaliningrad). On its way some of its items were stolen by German soldiers. Having arrived at Konigsberg
column6: the room was exhibited in the local castle. In the second half of worldwar 2
column7: when the danger of Allied bombing steadily increased
column8: the amber room was stored for safety in the castle's cellars.   From this point knowledge stops and speculation sets in. In August 1944 Konigsberg was bombed twice. Its castle
column9: right in the city centre
column10: was hit and burned out completely. In April 1945 Konigsberg was captured by the Soviet army in savage streetfighting. In other words
column11: from the moment of its storage opportunities for destruction had been plenty. The more so
column12: while amber burns very well from itself.  Destruction of works of art surely was quite common in those terrible days in eastern Europe. Many of them vanished without trace. The difference with the amber room is only made by the latter's huge reputation
column13: promptly turning its unrecorded disappearance into a legend.  I think it makes more sense to turn to the reality of our days. Sponsored by 'Ruhrgas AG'
column14: a German firm dealing in Russian gas
column15: the amber room has been rebuilt with great Russian craftsmanship. In May 2003 Russian president Putin and German chancellor Schroder officially re-opened it.   The truly magnificent replica has been enrichened by one of its authentic panels. Presenting us with an Italian landscape made from colored stone
column16: this panel was one of the items stolen in 1941. After having decorated an ordinary German living room for many years
column17: it was traced by the police and returned to the Russians.  Purchasing a book or DVD on the replica surely is worth your money. You'll find them on many a German site. It makes more sense than losing yourself in all sorts of idle speculation.

column1: "If a nut on the wall is a walnut
column2: what is a nut in the bathroom?  A pee can."  "Why did the baby cross the road?  She was stapled to the chicken."  Billing itself as "the mother of all joke books"
column3: The Jokelopedia has the apparent goal of turning your child (or grandchild
column4: etc.) into a comedian.  Categorized by subject matter such as a monster jokes
column5: classroom distractions
column6: family funnies
column7: etc.
column8: the book contains riddles
column9: jokes
column10: cartoons
column11: and tips from famous comedians.  Many of the riddles have pun-ch lines consisting of puns:  some that I consider funny
column12: and many of which adults will consider groaners
column13: but will get a lot of giggles from 8 year-olds.    Although I tend to like puns more than the average person
column14: as a practitioner of non-violent communication
column15: I don't recommend giving this book to children.  I am concerned that roughly up to 10 to 20% of the laughs come at the expense of becoming desensitized to the suffering of animals and humans.  For example
column16: there's a joke about a woman who buys a parrot
column17: and to get the bird to talk
column18: she buys a mirror
column19: a ladder
column20: a bell
column21: etc.  She goes back to the store and reports that the parrot died.  The clerk expresses his sorrow over her loss and asks if the parrot ever said anything to her.  The woman replied that just prior to dying
column22: the parrot said
column23: "Doesn't that store carry any food?"  So the joke is that the parrot starved to death because the woman was too stupid to buy food in addition to all the accessories.  There are riddles that have punch lines at the expense of animal suffering
column24: for example
column25: "What's black and white and flat? A panda that's been run over."  And the tacky frog in a blender joke
column26: mentioned by a previous reviewer
column27: could give a child the idea to actually try this (likely very few children but it's possible).  Although much of the egregiously tacky material is in the "Snot funny" section
column28: there is some in other sections of the book.  Another reason I don't recommend the Jokelopedia is because of the practical joke recommendations.  The child who tries out these suggestions will probably think he or she is being funny
column29: but those laughs come at the expense of being rude and crude to other people
column30: and insensitive to their feelings.  For example
column31: one of their slumber-party jokes is to pour cold water over the shower curtain rod on someone using the shower.  Another is to put another child's hand in a glass of warm water to get him or her to wet the bed.  Yet another is to put some fake plastic vomit in the sink.  One of the elevator practical jokes is to bet the other passengers that you can fit a quarter in your nose.  Yuck.  Another joke encourages lying:  "Tell [your big sister] that one of her friends called (for this to work
column32: be specific--use the real name of someone your sibling is close to and say one of the coolest kids in school is having a party tonight
column33: but you can't remember all the details."  In case your budding comedian runs out of practical ideas to play on siblings and parents (yes
column34: a parental practical joke idea involving the kitchen sink sprayer is provided--don't say you weren't warned!)
column35: there are five suggestions for tormenting the pizza guy.  One could
column36: as another reviewer did
column37: rip out some of the pages prior to giving the book to a child
column38: or perhaps cross out portions with a thick dark marker like it's a government document.  (But if you rip out the page of slumber party practical jokes
column39: the blurb on Lucille Ball is on the other side.)   Had I received this book as a child with pages ripped out
column40: I would have been extremely curious about what was missing and sought out another copy!  Unless the authors write a new edition that takes out the practical and insensitive to suffering jokes
column41: I don't recommend rewarding them by purchasing this book.  That's unfortunate
column42: because I think some of the puns are very clever
column43: and encourage children to have fun with the language.

column1: I got this book for my son when we got to the point that he had so many questions (technical in nature) that I couldn't remember the exact answer to (or don't know
column2: not being a boy). I turned to my male friends for help
column3: and one recommended "The Guy Book
column4:
which he had given to his  5 boys and they liked a lot. My son loved  it. It has a lot of info on boys, their bodies, their issues with friends,  and such necessary details as how to buy a corsage and tie a tie. My son asked intelligent questions, sparked by the book, and has read bits of it over and over.  The book is laid out in a non-threatening way, with fun illustrations and enough silly entries that it draws the reader in so that when they get to potentially embarassing material they just keep on going. It's also divided up so that, like the car repair manual it emulates, you can dip in to the one specific piece of info you need and then put it down until later.  Because of his interest, I've given this book to my nephews and recommended it to friends with pre-teens. Some of my nieces found it really useful, too, because it explains a lot about how and why boys do certain things.   I recommend this especially to parents who have trouble talking to their kids beyond a certain age, or single moms who, like me, just don't know the right answer. (If you don't know the answers, I recommend you read it. Then you'll know what you need to know to answer the next set of questions.)  The only thing wrong with this book is that I didn't write it. ;- 
 You have got to be kidding me. This stuff was tacky when it ran in magazines...  so now a book of it? Whatev... not to mention the horribly CHEAPO paper and way crummy binding. What was the guy thinking? Filthy lucre, I suppose. Three to six months until it hits the remainder table. A better subtitle might have been, How I Stopped Worrying About What a Decent Book Should Be". Save  yourself the bread

What I do not like about this book is that it starts off with bad things happening to folks and it just goes downhill for these folks all the way

column6: thrown in jail

column8: pregnant woman can't get enough food

column11: river floods

The author fancies himself a Copernicus
column2: by
column3: similarly to the reversal of the notion that the sun revolves around the earth
column4: rendering the notion of consciousness an "illusion" (last word
column5: p.178). His ego is indeed enormous
column6: my knowing of no other author quoting (p.45) and incessantly citing his own writing.  The notion of the sun revolving is an inference
column7: from observing its change of position relative to the earth
column8: and motion indeed is considered relative. But consciousness is not an inference. It is the most immediate phenomenon by which everything we know
column9: or imagine
column10: is manifested. Dennett persistently investigates distinctions in our brains
column11: from dispositions to memories
column12: often couching them in esoteric or otherwise unfamiliar terms
column13: while sidestepping the simple fact that whatever the detailed particulars
column14: all is presented to us through the medium of consciousness.  He puts great emphasis on the third-person approach
column15: like questioning a subject about his perceptions
column16: so as to discover misunderstandings about the inner workings of the mind
column17: forgetting that all of these
column18: whether actual perceptions or beliefs or else
column19: are ingredients of consciousness. This his "scientific method"
column20: compared to first-person introspection
column21: is the only approved one.  It is shared by others. Like Patricia Churchland
column22: he has contempt for "folk" psychology
column23: pitting it against favored "academic" (p.35). They also share a derogatory attitude toward dissenters
column24: regarding them as reactionaries (p.8) or naysayers. The views are admittedly materialist
column25: holding Cartesian dualism of mind and body "bankrupt" or a "disaster"
column26: as does John Searle.  Why? Descartes is not in line with their assumed all-inclusive scientific method
column27: embraced also by philosophers
column28: who traditionally delved deeper into issues of knowledge. I do so newly in my book and here wish to note that however physical inquiry progresses
column29: consciousness
column30: via which the inquiry is made
column31: remains a distinct phenomenon.

column1: Seemed Like a Good Idea at the Time

column4: and one who lived there before and during the author's coming-of-age in the Big City novel
column5: I usually am biased and get a kick out of these types of reads.  New York is like no other place - that is clearly true.  But one cannot help but sense that Goodwillie was reaching for a McInerney-type of novel
column6: or perhaps even a shorter Tom Wolfe's style of New Journalism.  Sadly
column7: Goodwillie
column8: who at times in this book is clearly brilliant
column9: falls short.  When writing in a more reflective and less journalistic manner is when the author is at his best.  And there was plenty of that.  Unfortunately
column10: just when he grabbed my attention with his own style
column11: his editor seemingly either allowed
column12: or even encouraged
column13: some unrelated drivel to waste several pages
column14: if not chapters.  If he had cut out about 50 to 75 pages and focused more on the personal and societal implications of an individual trying to cut it in New York in the Age of the Internet (and its conflict with his desires as a writer) this book could have been very good.  It was not.

 I was attracted to this novel after reading a non-fiction article on stem cell research written by the author that was anthologized in Best American Science and Nature Writing. McManus' daughter has had diabetes since childhood, and when I discovered that he had written a novel about a 29-year-old woman with diabetes who takes a cross-country bike trip to lay her personal demons I hoped for a tale of overcoming great obstacles. I was taken with the character and kept reading to hear more about her even as the unlikely events piled one on top of the other. I gave the author a LOT of slack hoping for a thoughtful, enlightening denouement from someone who clearly is an accomplished writer as well as the parent of a diabetic. I will not spoil the book in case someone wants to read it, but suffice it to say that I felt betrayed and disgusted by the ending.  My thought as I closed the book was, With all the books on my shelf to be read
column8: why did I waste time on this?" My advice
column9: "Don't.

column1: Reagan's campaign autobiography is titled _Where's the Rest of Me?_
column2: based on a line from one of his movies.  Unfortunately
column3: Cannon has amputated a lot of Reagan in the second volume of his biography.  (The other volume is Governor Reagan
column4: and it is much
column5: much better.)  Much of the book is based on leaks
column6: kiss-and-tell interviews
column7: and the various Iran-Contra reports.  As a result
column8: the book is not a fair picture of Reagan but is really the revenge of administration officials.  As a result
column9: the book has a lot of inside information
column10: but Cannon has not put it in context.  Even worse
column11: there is very little of Reagan in the book.  Most of the material describes what Reagan's staff is doing to each other
column12: and there is plenty of in-fighting.  There's very little of Reagan's thoughts or actions.  For example
column13: you get David Stockman's understandably bitter view of economic policy
column14: but there is almost no discussion of the longest postwar economic boom
column15: except an attempt to debunk it.  Mostly he portrays Reagan as asleep and uncomprehending.  It is highly telling that Cannon has not cited in his bibliography any documents from the Reagan library.  He only seems to quote Reagan's diary when it was used by the Tower Board during its investigation of Iran-Contra.  So this is a book about Reagan's chiefs of staff
column16: counselors
column17: and a few cabinet secretaries.  They are interesting people
column18: but it's not a Reagan bio.  My final complaint is that the book is written in stream-of-consciousness.  Cannon describes whatever events he thinks of next
column19: so there is little overall organization to the book.  He jumps years between paragraphs.  For instance
column20: he doesn't mention the air-traffic controller's strike until he is discussing the re-election campaign
column21: when it has only a tenuous connection to the matter at hand.  Major events are hardly covered at all
column22: such as the assassination attempt.  So I still have no overall understanding of the themes and organization of Reagan's presidency.  Nonetheless
column23: the book does have some strengths.  Cannon is an interesting writer
column24: so you'll enjoy his prose.  He also has a lot of interesting inside information gained by his years as a reporter for the Washington Post and many years reporting on Reagan in California.  For example
column25: he seems to have a good understanding of Nancy Reagan
column26: probably because Michael Deaver was a key source.  Also
column27: he provides insightfuly analysis about Iran-Contra
column28: the MX missile deployment
column29: the 1984 re-election
column30: and the first budget.  His discussion of the different types of intelligence and the ones that were strengths for Reagan is very useful.  Note that even the revised version of the book ends with Reagan leaving the presidency in 1989.  It also begins with him taking office in 1981.  Overall
column31: I CANNOT recommend the book.  It might be a good supplement if you already understand Reagan's presidency well.  But if this is the only book you read about him
column32: you'll be left in confusion and with a biased portrait by a reporter who mostly seems to disparage Reagan

column1: Walpola Rahula's book is simply put
column2: Theravada dogma which pushes the belief that the Buddha taught natthatta
column3: namely
column4: there is no self.  Rahula makes a number of claims about what the Buddha taught which have no basis in original Buddhism.  For example
column5: Rahula gives a confusing account of the Five Aggregates (Pali
column6: khandhas).  He omits any serious discussion of why the Buddha does not identify his own self with the Five Aggregates or why the Buddha always deprecates the Five Aggregates declaring them
column7: for example
column8: to be the Buddhist devil
column9: Mara the Evil One.  It never seems to dawn on Rahula that the Buddha
column10: in his many discourses
column11: is deploying the via negativa (Grk. apophasis) with regard to the Five Aggregates.  The Buddha is really saying that our true self is other than these illusory Five Aggregates; and that we should have a revulsion towards them instead of the self!  This book deserves careful scrutiny.  And let the beginner beware
column12: this book draws a terribly nihilistic conclusion about Buddhism.  It is ironic to note that three months before the Buddha dies he said the following: "My life is fully ripe
column13: my life is at an end
column14: I shall depart from you
column15: I have made a refuge for the self.

column3: the second part that really bothered me: The title of the book is "Cave in the Snow" not "Small cottage in the mountains".  I had to put the book down when I read the sentence about the DOUBLE GLAZED WINDOWS that were installed in her "cave"  COME ON!  It is amazing what she did

column5: repaved

column7: there was a patio out front
column8: and a terraced garden.   I'm not saying that Tenzin Palmo doesn't deserve all the credit that she has received - she has truly blazed a trail for all women in buddhism
column9: however the author's attempts to create interest border on melodrama and significant inaccuracy.

column1: Peter Lynch's book held me back about 10 years in my investing success.  I used to believe things I read in books because a good publisher like Simon and Schuster would publish it.  I counted cars in parking lots of companies with due dilligence and questioned managers on how things were selling.  I also avoided "reading tealeaves" like drawing trendlines on what I was actually concerned about THE PRICE of the stock!  Now I make a living "reading tealeaves" and leave the parking lot duty to those who think counting cars makes the price go up.      My suggestion is to learn basic technical analysis from a book like John murphys Technical Analysis of the financial markets.  Start there then go on to learn more advanced TA.  I also like Investor's Business Daily-BUT it is very specialized and takes reading several times and probably help from a more advanced user to understand IBD.  I also swingtrade - hold stocks for 2-5 days sometimes longer.

column3: the title is definately misleading
column4: and many of the goals and events received highly biased coverage.  Ms. Zia begins with a survey of history of how Asians were treated in America.  While I agree that the treatement was not ideal and certainly horrific by today's standards
column5: there is absolutely no historical context here.  Unfortunately
column6: Blacks were treated MUCH worse.  Catholics were vilified far before Asians were
column7: and for much longer.  The way she presents things
column8: you would only think that Asians were getting the short end of the stick.  She also harps on the lack of positive images of Asians in the media.  She self selects a small sampling
column9: while there has been an increasingly large number of positive Asian role models in American culture.  Do the Italians whine when most Italian characters in media culture are mobsters?  She even imagines slights where they don't exist - for example
column10: Sulu in Star Trek.  He was hard working to be sure (not that there is anything wrong with that)
column11: but as any fan of the series will tell you
column12: he DID have a swashbuckling side to him.  If there is anyone who was emotionless and hard working
column13: that would have been Spock
column14: played by a white.  Besides
column15: Sulu eventually made captain of the best vessel in the fleet.  So much for a negative image.  She gets into the issue of ethnic casting
column16: focusing on Miss Saigon.  Well
column17: it works both ways.  If only Asians can portray Asians
column18: then Asians shouldn't portray whites either.  Too bad Lucy Liu.  Her character in Charlie's Angels was WHITE in the series
column19: but was made half-Asian in the movies.  Opps
column20: Lucy isn't even half Asian.  I would like to see Helen come over here to Asia to complain about the negative images of foreigners.  How many negative images of foreigners exist in Hong Kong and Japanese movies?  There was an advertising campaign here in Taiwan where a company had three white men in jail costumes after being arrested.  Foreigners are constantly portrayed by media outlets in several Asian countries in a negative light.  Why can't you get on your soapbox about that?  She comments on how many Asians are complemented on their English even if they have been in the U.S. their whole life.  Well
column21: how many people who look white in Asia have been here their whole lives
column22: but are still referred to as foreigners?  It works both ways Ms. Zia.   She also gets into her homosexuality.  What does THAT have to do with Asian American Dreams?  Like most Americans
column23: those of Asian descent are opposed to homosexuality.    Finally
column24: there is the notion of hyphenated Americanism (though she technically doesn't succomb to it because the omits the hyphen.)  She wants Asians to be treated as equals in America.  I have no problem with that.  I would like to see the same thing.  However
column25: when you put your ethnic homeland BEFORE American in what you call yourself
column26: how do you think you will ever be accepted as truly American

column3: contusions
column4: probably cracked ribs and bones and chunks of flesh and muscle to hang off of his body.  This type of torture was used to weaken the victim into total submission thus making crucifixtion easy for the Romans.  2)After that they placed thorns on his head and pressed them into his skull causing bleeding and terrible pain to add to what he had already gone through. 3)Next he had to carry a piece of his cross weighing approximately 75-125 pounds through the streets until he could no longer do it himself after his brutal torture.  4) Then he was laid on the ground and had his hands and feet nailed to a cross and had his body stretched so far on the cross that ligaments and bones were stretched until they popped out of place. column1: I was looking for a real thriller
column2: and thought I would try one by David Baldacci. I had read a very favourable review a while back
column3: and I have also seen and enjoyed the movie version of Absolute Power.  After reading reviews at Amazon
column4: I picked Last Man Standing. However
column5: I was really disappointed. For me it wasn't thrilling at all. Several times I had to force myself to pick it up again to continue reading. For me
column6: a good thriller is a book you can't stop reading
column7: even if it's getting late and you really
column8: really should try to get some sleep instead of continue reading.  Examples of great thrillers I have read are: The Firm by John Grisham
column9: The Day After Tomorrow by Allan Folsom (nothing to do with the weather-related movie of the same name) and Angels and Demons by Dan Brown.  But Last Man Standing was quite the opposite. Sure it had its moments where it got exciting for a while (the final shoot-out for example)
column10: but those times were quite rare.  I've been trying to figure out why I didn't like it
column11: but I can't say I know why. I do think that a lot of what happens in the book is quite far-fetched (especially the reason the hero Web London froze during the ambush) and that the characters are pretty one-dimensional
column12: but that's not enough of a reason. Both The Day After Tomorrow and Angels and Demons have plenty of far-fetch twists and one-dimensional characters
column13: but they were still exciting reads. I can't come up with a definite answer as to why I didn't like Last Man Standing - I simply just didn't care for it.  Writing a negative review like this will probably earn me a few unhelpful votes
column14: but I think it is important to also review books you didn't like. Otherwise you risk getting an unbalanced view. However
column15: I do admit that it is much more fun to review books you really liked.  But to finish
column16: if you are looking for a good thriller
column17: skip this one and try one of the other three I mentioned above.

column1: ...out quickly within the first 100 pages.  I was very intrigued with the premise of the novel--poor little rich girl has to learn to make it on her own.  I thought
column2: this one could be really fun!  However
column3: what I found instead was a story about a walking doormat
column4: who let everyone and their family up to the 6th cousins take advantage of her.  With this statement
column5: I have in mind visions of MYRON floating through my head.  At one point
column6: Rachel has a box of macaroni and something else left in her fridge
column7: with no money to get more food to make it through a whole week
column8: but she blithely shrugs off Myron's raid on her pantry.  Her attitude is
column9: "Who cares if he eats all my food and clutters up my house?  He's my FRIEND".  This attitude safely does fall under the TSTL category
column10: which I was relieved to see another reader point out.  Furthermore
column11: Rachel teaches a weaving class OUT OF POCKET...and we're all expected to believe she does it out of the goodness of her little heart
column12: and for sheer love of weaving?  Please!  I could understand Rachel waiving the wee for a student or two
column13: or bringing weaving materials for a student or two
column14: but PAYING HERSELF for the class to take weaving?  Come on!  No one is that desperate and lonely that they need to PAY for other people to enjoy their company!  And if they are
column15: I certainly don't want to read about them!  One of the worst and most annoying things about this book was the horrid slang Julia London had Flynn speak in.  I could understand a few slang comments thrown in
column16: but his entire character spoke in dialect.  (Most people
column17: when taking beginning writing courses
column18: are warned to use "dialect" SPARINGLY.  So what does Julia London do?  She writes a whole character who speaks in nothing BUT dialect.  Help me rip out all the hairs on my head one by one for each "nancy boy" and "bit of all right" and "I rather suspect..." and "lucky chaps"!)  Two of my best friends are British
column19: and do they speak like that?  NO!  They have a few expressions we don't use in America
column20: but they still speak ENGLISH!  Instead of being charmed
column21: I was desperately annoyed.  One more thing that bothered me was the way Rachel's dad was painted as a horrible villain who
column22: although dying
column23: didn't deserve to see his daughter for Thanksgiving.  No matter how awful your parents are
column24: if they're dying
column25: you could at least agree to go spend the holidays with your family!  This coming from a girl who pays for other people to take her classes
column26: who rescues kittens from cruel owners
column27: and who buys groceries for a vilely grouchy widower.  But yet we're expected to believe she won't go see her dying father for the holidays?  Whaaaat?  Oh no
column28: he tells her she needs to finish school--she's THIRTY!  What does she expect?  Yet of course
column29: once she starts having a relationship with a man and falls in love
column30: she suddenly is able to finish her long-stagnant thesis.  Gag me!  Now
column31: after all my ranting
column32: were there any redeeming qualities to this novel?  I'll admit
column33: there was quite a lot wrong with this novel.  However
column34: I did enjoy the way Rachel's character tried to take her life into her own hands by doing things she'd never been good at before.  She stopped whining about being overweight and went to the gym
column35: she stopped saying she could never get a date and started flirting with a nice
column36: normal seeming guy.  Also
column37: the tone of the novel was mostly light and humorous
column38: especially throughout Rachel's first encounters with Flynn.  It made the novel more appealing and comedic
column39: which I enjoyed.  However
column40: all in all
column41: I found Rachel's repeated put-downs of herself to be too much of a hindrance to the story
column42: and her newfound self-confidence blossomed much too late in the story for me.  Sorry guys
column43: but I give this one a miss.

column1: I have to strongly disagree with the editorial and reader reviews on this essay
column2: even though it was a national bestseller. The book is touted as possibly the most rational description of a descent into morbid
column3: clinical depression and suicidal despair. I didn't find it so. Styron was descriptive but rather than probing and baring the depths of his mind and emotions during his depression
column4: I felt he only hinted at the tip of the iceberg. I didn't find any riveting
column5: palpable tracing of his depression. It was rather moribund for a subject with such potential. There is a detachment throughout that many attribute to Styron's calculating dismantling of his own emotions to throw light into the abyss. I found the detachment sort of hovering over the pond
column6: unwilling to dive in
column7: which robs the reader. Candor
column8: yes in some aspects. Precision
column9: somewhat missing.  He quotes Dante "In the middle of the journey of our life
column10: I found myself in a dark wood
column11: for I had lost the right path." Styron was in the melancholia described by Dante but he never succeeds at identifying why or even how he managed to eventually recover.  From what most reviewers have said
column12: this book should have been the definitive treatise on deep depression
column13: written by a survivor. It is not that impressive at all

column1: I am in complete agreement with reviewer "zmusicman" in absolutely panning this book.  I found The Sacred Romance to be so poorly written that at many times I could absolutely not understand what the point was at which the authors were clumsily trying to arrive.  Okay
column2: one thing was clear:  God is courting us and trying to get us to enter into a "romantic" relationship with Him
column3: which promises to enter us into the whirlwind adventure of our lifetime.  Hmmm
column4: I have to wonder if the authors were somehow referring to the theological concept of Divine Eros
column5: which has been expounded upon by the Church Fathers and in Orthodox Christian (and perhaps Roman Catholic?) theology.  However
column6: their arguments and illustrations show that even if they have heard of Divine Eros their understanding of it is faulty and extremely shallow
column7: resulting in a self-centered
column8: thirsty for self-esteem sort of "I'm OK
column9: You're OK" relationship with the almighty God.  This is not surprising in light of the fact that this book was written by "evangelical" counselors (not respected theologians) more bent on emotions and warm fuzzies than on the Truth in relation to God's relationship with man
column10: man's fallen nature and sinfulness
column11: the Eros of the Holy Trinity
column12: Christ's Incarnation
column13: etc.  The next big problem that I found lay not in the idea of "romantic" adventures in the Christian life (for if you read the lives of the saints you will find this
column14: as this concept is not new
column15: much to its credit.)
column16: but in the so-called messages of the heart and messages of the arrows.  Basically these are the things that either help or hinder our relationship with God.  However
column17: according to Curtis and Eldredge
column18: all of the wonderfully happy and pleasant things occurring in our lives are helpful and all of the not so pleasant
column19: mean
column20: and traumatic things that others have inflicted upon us are arrows from Satan to keep us away from God.  This is
column21: of course
column22: ludicrous and completely unscriptural as the Bible teaches that all things are under God's providence and
column23: although the Devil can harm us
column24: not every unpleasant and uncomfortable occurrence is necessarily from the Evil One or even to his temporary victory.  Many "arrows" are allowed to occur and are even blessed by God for our spiritual growth and health (obviously the cultivation of humility is not a big priority for these guys as it might make someone uncomfortable).  The result: humans remain a bunch of "whiny spiritual babies" who can't take the pain required to gain the Kingdom!  This is obviously dangerous to our souls and I fear that all of the earnest but misinformed readers and workbook filler-outers who buy into this pseudo-psychology (as tempting as it may sound) are placing themselves in spiritual danger.  Finally
column25: I must return to my original critique in once again stating that this book is terribly written.  The authors rarely finish a coherent thought.  Entire chapters are presented without a lucid conclusion.  The quotes from scripture are taken out of context (such as the rambling on Job) and
column26: worst of all
column27: they use literature and film in an attempt to prove their theological assertions as being true.  I am not saying that fiction and the arts cannot contain glimpses of the truth
column28: illustrate a point
column29: or even be biblically based- of course they can.  However
column30: they are not the Canon of Scripture or Church Tradition.  The last time I checked my Bible there was not a Gospel according to Forest Gump or an Epistle to the Last of the Mohicans (of which the authors referred only to the movie
column31: not the novel).  Thus although these films most definitely contain Christian themes they cannot possibly prove theological precepts as being true or false!  On a different note
column32: after reading about 145 pages of nonsense and boo-hoo heartstring tugs disguised as personal accounts on the spiritual life
column33: the authors finally caught my attention with a rudimentary introduction to spiritual warfare.  "Alas"
column34: I thought to myself
column35: "They are starting to speak my language!"  My excitement soon waned when two or three short pages later they made an offhanded and clumsy reference to the concept of spiritual "detachment" without even citing it as the drowning of the passions or crediting it to St. John Climacus' Ladder of Divine Ascent and the monastic tradition of the Orthodox Christian Church.  Why would they
column36: after all?  Why not just make the public think that you've reinvented the wheel by making the spiritual life easy
column37: carefree
column38: and painless?  Self-denial
column39: discipline
column40: and obedience just don't sell books.  So Curtis and Eldredge apparently decided to merely borrow the term
column41: clean it up
column42: polish it and paint it
column43: and present it to the unsuspecting masses in a spiritual "get rich quick/miraculous diet pill" sort of way: It might work
column44: but it will most likely destroy you.  Come on Christians
column45: its time to go back to your roots and seek the Truth of Christ.  He may ask you to change your ways
column46: it may sometimes be unpleasant
column47: but the pay off is eternal.

column1: I first read the Dance Hall of the Dead in high school.  Being a member of the Zuni Tribe
column2: and a resident of the town of Zuni
column3: it was quite interesting to see how much of the information concerning Zuni could be changed to fit the "theme" and plot of the book.  While these may seem like little details to most people
column4: it is quite disturbing to see how often Hillermans work is seen as accurate
column5: because of a reputation he has somehow gained as an "expert" on Native Cultures of the American Southwest.  Apparently
column6: he thought that all pueblo people are the same.  This is evident in the use of the last name of Cata
column7: which is not even seen in Zuni
column8: and is actually a last name seen only in the Rio Grande Pueblos.  In addition
column9: his interpretation or portrayal of the Sha'la'k'o ceremony as a "Dance Hall of the Dead" is simplistic at best.  While he may be an "expert" in Navajo culture
column10: it does not qualify him to comment on a COMPLETELY different society
column11: much less its sacred and complex kachina ceremonies.  Finally
column12: many native people
column13: such as the Navajo
column14: the Zuni and the Hopi (who have all been "featured" in Hillerman's books) feel that Hillerman's descriptions of ceremonies and rituals is just plain wrong.  As an outsider
column15: he has no business delving into or exposing the nature of such things as kachinas
column16: which we consider sacred yet dangerous.  Furthermore
column17: by exploiting our cultures for the sake of adding interest to a plot
column18: he seems to show a lack of respect for our cultures
column19: our religions
column20: and our tribes in general.   This in itself is bad enough
column21: but the worst thing is that people actually consider his novels definitive descriptions of Native culture.  There are many ethnological works out there that are available
column22: and they are NOT hard to find.  After all Zuni is one of
column23: if not THE most complex
column24: and most studied society on earth.  While I don't agree with people wanting to know "everything there is to know" about Zuni culture
column25: there are much better places to find out about "us" than a Tony Hillerman book

column14: and we manage to maintain healthy human relationships. And there are many artists

column17: there are some good tips for parenting. But if you are a spouse or child recovering from a disastrous relationship with someone with undiagnosed or untreated ADD
column18: or if you are currently in a relationship with an adult with untreated ADD this book won't help you a bit.  There is no doubt that our society has been bad at helping those with ADD and our attitudes toward the behavior of ADD have caused self-esteem problems. However
column19: the same is true of the overweight issue.  The bottom line is that ADD and ADHD has caused an untold amount of unhappiness for the person with ADD and the family. The behaviors of risk taking
column20: the communication problems that manifest in relationship problems
column21: and the impulsiveness and lack of self control that can lead to emotional or physical abuse are far too serious to be ignored. The exercises in the book are fine
column22: but for anyone facing serious issues because of ADD behavior

column1: As is generally the case
column2: Dr. Laura directs her criticism/suggestions directly at her readers/listeners: "get your own act together and your life will fall into place."  There is
column3: of course
column4: a lot of wisdom in this.  Before making a laundry list of complaints about how other people are letting you down in your life
column5: you probably should examine your own shortcomings.  This can definitely help put things into perspective (i.e.
column6: "yes my husband is insensitive and aloof
column7: but maybe my constantly criticizing him isn't helping").  Dr. Laura goes on to give some decent advice on how women can improve their marriages: be friendly and cheerful with your hubby rather than bitchy and resentful
column8: don't let yourself go to pot (keep your weight down and dress nicely)
column9: don't withhold sex.  Yes
column10: your spouse will probably will be in a better mood if you are cheerful
column11: look nice and eagerly welcome his sexual advances.  According to "the doctor" men are "simple creatures" (give them food and sex and they are happy)
column12: it's women who are chronically dissatisfied
column13: constantly complaining and impossible to please.  She claims that the situation is made worse by the feminists who are always telling women falsehoods like: "men oppress women
column14: women who are housewives are unhappy
column15: women should seek
column16: and expect sexual equality with men."  Of course
column17: Dr. Laura isn't very clear about who "these feminists" are and she talks about "women's magazines" as if they were the voice of  "the feminists
column18: even though most feminists would probably argue that magazines like Cosmo are more part of the problem than the solution.  There are a lot of women who call themselves feminists and very few see eye to eye on all issues.  However, I think most would agree that feminism is about giving women the opportunity to realize themselves in whatever capacity they choose.  This can mean as a wife and mother, as a professional or as both.  There may be feminists who look down on women who've chosen to be housewives, but there are at least just as many feminist haters" who impugn women who have sacrificed motherhood in order to pursue dreams that were more important to them.  What's the difference?  Both are guilty of criticizing women who make choices different from their own in order to feel better about their own decisions.  Dr. Laura clearly errs is in her assertion that all women are happier being wives and stay-at-home moms and having a husband who provides for the family.  If this were the case
column19: why did the 1950's (the epitome of traditional family-life) bring on the feminist movement in the first place?  Rather than becoming addicted to Valium or clamoring for more equality
column20: why weren't women simply singing the praises of their wonderfully fulfilling domestic lives?  I think the answer is clear: a lot of women were extremely bored and unfulfilled without the intellectual and social stimulation that a life outside the home can provide.  Also
column21: being economically dependent on another person puts you in a very vulnerable position if you are in a physically and/or emotionally abusive relationship.  It is very true that women today who are juggling careers and family are feeling their own dissatisfactions: they are overworked and feel robbed of time with their families and they feel like the do a disproportionate share of the work in the home. However
column22: I don't think the answer lies in sending ALL women back to the traditional role of housewife.  At least now women have options.  If they decide staying at home and caring for children is the #1 priority in their lives
column23: or that they simply cannot "do it all
column24: then everyone should respect their decision.  If they prefer to juggle work and family or remain childless and free to pursue other ambitions, those are also decisions that should be respected.   Life is complicated and there are no one-size-fits-all answers to life's most important choices.  Dr. Laura tries to support her claim that ALL women REALLY WANT to be stay-at-home moms and cared for by a man with some study that demonstrates" that partners in marriages that don't follow these traditional roles have higher rates of heart disease.  Rubbish!  You can always dig up some obsolete study to prove any argument you are trying to make.  There are A LOT MORE studies that show that single women are happier than married women (I'm not saying this so
column25: I'm just saying that such studies say nothing about whether or not YOU will be happy in any given situation).  Particularly offensive is what Dr. Laura says about sex.  Essentially she argues that it is women's duty to provide their husbands with sex whenever they want it.  I agree that discrepancies in desire can be a problem in a marriage and that women should not make a habit of casually dismissing their husbands' sexual attentions.  However
column26: there are "reasons" why many women are not as interested in sex as their husbands
column27: the biggest one being that they are not getting the kind of sexual stimulation they need in the bedroom.  But
column28: "the doctor" makes no mention of this.  She advices women to service their husbands and act like they are loving it ("men like to think that they are good lovers").  What about a little more communication?  What about telling your partner what you like?  What about some compromise?  No
column29: according to the Dr. Laura
column30: sex is what you give your husband in exchange for his ultimate sacrifice: his marrying you.  She even goes so far as to remind women that in some states we are legally obliged to do so (does she want to put women who don't behind bars?).  I guess on this issue I am "idealistic": sex should be something that is mutually satisfying for both men and women.  Life is probably more complicated for the modern woman
column31: but this does not mean that it is worse.  In fact
column32: I would argue that women have it better now than they have at any time in history.  Turning back the clock to a "simpler time" may seem like an appealing solution to today's overworked and highly-stressed women
column33: but I sincerely doubt that it would provide any lasting satisfaction in most women's lives.  Women
column34: as individuals
column35: must decide for themselves what lifestyle is most gratifying.  The path Dr. Laura suggests is only one of many that "can" lead to a healthy
column36: rewarding life

column3: tortured
column4: and poorly fed before his trial. Afterwards Rawics is imprisoned in Lubyanka in Moscow where the torture continued.  Rawics
column5: convinced that a confession would mean certain death

column7: a train car where men are packed so tightly that one cannot sit

Pg 80+ or so  At this point I put the book down.  I could not longer suspend my disbelief. column1: I purchased this book to read on a scuba diving trip in eastern Indonesia over Christmas and was very disappointed (I should have read the online reviews before I did).  While the subject matter is fascinating
column2: and a large part of the narrative engaging
column3: much too much time is spent by the author digressing into his often unrelated personal experiences during his travels around the world
column4: name dropping those in his profession
column5: inserting strained literary references and generally telling the reader endless amounts of useless information.  Admittedly
column6: in Chapter 1 the Author tells the readers that "where my own experiences with people or places will serve to bring the process of investigation alive then I shall make diversions
column7: the better to illuminate the way forward."  This sounds great in theory and a valid alternative to dry
column8: impersonal prose.  The problem is that these many
column9: many diversions provide no illumination at all on the subject matter (or the way forward)
column10: and they make much of the book read like a bad travelogue
column11: with the author telling us he's in London or Oman or China or somewhere else and how fascinating or wonderful his trip is
column12: such as a conference in Wales where we are told during a dinner he "sat next to a jolly professor of Celtic languages who explained the bardic tradition to me."  How does this possibly illuminate anything remotely related to natural history?  A few such diversions are tolerable or even folksy
column13: but unfortunately they are never ending in this book.  In addition
column14: the work suffers from an appalling lack of tables
column15: maps
column16: charts
column17: diagrams and similar visual information that would help the reader better understand the subject matter.  Instead
column18: the book contains pictures of such things as (and I'm not making this up) a row of slot machines in a Las Vegas casino and the tablecloth used during teatime by Lady Smith Woodward.  If you want a good book on the natural history of the Earth
column19: keep shopping.

 A few words to describe this book: vulgar, crude, and boring. I was truly excited to read this book when it was suggested to me. The idea of reading a sexual autobiography that was praised for not being another watered down censored bore, excited me. It only took me a totally of 50 pages to realize that I was stuck in the middle of someone's sexual nightmare.   The book is exactly what it is, a blurred recollection of someone's sexual history from roughly about 20 years prior to writing the book. So what's so amazing about a women's sex life that it should be an entire book? Well Catherine M. was not interested in conventional sex, she was involved in countless acts of group sex, orgies and sex clubs. Interesting right? Sadly, No. Catherine explains that her remembrances of these encounters are vague due to her ability to block out what is going on. Her memory is a blur of sexual activity. Parties, men, women, sex, sweat, faces, [...]is, kissing...it's all a confusing mess of events. The entire book is paragraph after paragraph of vulgar/crude descriptions of her involvement during each sexual act she tries to remember. It's not sexy/steamy or interesting. Then we're told Darhel can go a week sans rest without too much trouble but he's so worn out after three days he can't take the opportunity of the bad guy falling asleep to move? He exposes himself to fire to begin some great plan then two pages later is again wondering what to do next?   Don't hold your breath waiting for him to do anything to justify the book's title.  You'll be horribly disappointed. Then we find jarring contradictory details like "the hero" still being tracked several pages after he's discovered and ditched the tracking device. etc. etc. etc... The final fate of the bad guy is straight "god out of the box". Come on! I won't reveal what it was in case some masochist wants to slog through the long tedium for it but it made me want to hurl the book across the room. Or just hurl.  And the denoument is laughable. column1: The Contortionist's Handbook
column2: Craig Clevenger's first novel
column3: is a weird
column4: complicated
column5: seemingly pointless exercise in futility.  The novel follows John Dolan
column6: who is known by many other names throughout the book
column7: because that is what he does
column8: he changes his identity
column9: and others
column10: with great expertise and perfection.  We are introduced to John when he wakes up from a headache that he refers to as a "godsplitter" in a hospital
column11: and he is forced to undergo a psychiatric evaluation to determine if he is suicidal or depressed.  From that point
column12: the novel divides its time between the interview between John and the Evaluator and giving us John's life story
column13: which is remarkably uninteresting for such a weird tale.  The thing that gets me about this book is that it seemingly has no point.  I guess one could say its point to be "anti-psychiatry
column14: but forgive me for asking that the author also include somewhat of a plot to at least make the story interesting.  The only interesting and entertaining part of the novel is the interaction between John and the Evaluator.  But, for some reason, Clevenger decides that John's life story is more important, even though we are only given a brief, fleeting glimpse into a life that seems to be much more complicated than the author wanted to put into the novel.  Don't get me wrong, I am not complaining about the novel's length, because I don't think I would have finished it if it was longer than it already is.    I also read Clevenger's second novel, Dermaphoria, a while ago, and while I didn't really enjoy it, the novel at least had some semblance of a story that made it worth reading.  As this novel grew closer and closer to ending, I slowly realized that there was no way that any meaning was going to be given to the convoluted story within the last 20 pages.  Clevenger tries to inject some suspense into the story near the end, but he ends up just using underdeveloped characters to do things that we have no idea what their motivation is for doing.  I think that Clevenger could be a good writer, but, dear Lord, he needs to try writing a normal" novel
column15: until I read about one of his novels
column16: and it isn't about a drugged out freak or a mentally unstable counterfeiter
column17: I think that I am pretty much done giving his novels the benefit of the doubt

In the first line of his 1971 work
column2: Eduardo Galeano clearly states
column3: "the division of labor among nations is that some specialize in winning and others in losing." (Page 1)  For Galeano
column4: the economic well being of the United States and Europe rested on the back of Latin America.  First pillaged for its gold and silver
column5: then for it's human resources
column6: Latin America served as the foundation for capitalist interests.  This is the thesis for the book
column7: and the author spends over 300 pages expounding on the "horrors" and "injustices" that the western world has plagued on Latin America.  "Latin America's industry
column8: the author writes, lies at the bottom of the Imperium's digestive apparatus.  Our union makes their strength to the extent that our countries
column9: not having broken from the molds of underdevelopment and dependence
column10: integrate their own respective serfdoms." (Page 254)  This
column11: according to Galeano
column12: resulted in the dividing up of Latin America's population into disjointed nation states
column13: as each section of the countryside was developed to capitalize on one resource.  "Today
column14: Galeano writes, any of the multinational corporations operate with more coherence and sense of unity than the congeries of islands that is Latin America." (Page 260)      In presenting his argument Galeano divides his book into three parts.  Mankind's Poverty as a Consequence of the Wealth of the Land
column15: Development Is A Voyage With More Shipwrecks Than Navigators
column16: and an update to the original work added in 1977 simply titled
column17: Seven Years After.  Unfortunately Galeano provides a very one-sided overview of Latin American history from the time of Columbus to the late 1960s.  Within the first section's three chapters
column18: the author paints a greed driven picture of Spanish explorers bent on finding gold at all cost
column19: followed by European
column20: and then American exploiters
column21: manipulating the sugar and coffee industry for their own gains at the cost of the native peoples.  While spending a large amount of text in describing the first Spanish expeditions
column22: Galeano neglects to mention the then current situation among the Native American Indians.  He never mentions the ambiguous relationships that certain Indian cultures had with their own neighbors
column23: or the fact that the Aztecs were oppressing their own people.  No mention is given at all to the fact that Cortes had help from neighboring tribes in the overthrow of the Aztec Empire. The Indians are portrayed as simple peace loving people.      Galeano also seems to make assumptions that do not stand the test of time.  In writing about the Spanish-American War and the acquisition of Puerto Rico the author states
column24: "at the same time the Philippines and Puerto Rico dropped into the United States' lap." (Page 71)  He then goes on to expound
column25: in a footnote almost half the page long
column26: the horrors the people of Puerto Rico have faced (no say in Congress
column27: trade controlled
column28: Puerto Ricans drafted to fight in Vietnam) as a "colony" of the United States.  He fails to point out
column29: and as time has shown
column30: that since the late 1970s Puerto Rico has been given the choice of either remaining the way they are
column31: becoming independent
column32: or becoming the 51st state.  Although the margin is narrowing with every election they have always chosen to remain a commonwealth (My second wife was of Puerto Rican decent with family still living on the island.  A heated debate over this issue always ensued as most of her family did not want to see Puerto Rico gain independence or statehood because it would affect their property holdings on the island.  This
column33: I later discovered
column34: was the position most Puerto Ricans living in the U.S. but owning property on the island held).  In Galeano's defense one can argue that this was not the case in 1970 when he had written the book
column35: but as the work had been updated in 1977
column36: and a 25th Anniversary Edition was published in 1997
column37: this fact could have easily been added.      Another case-in-point is the author's examination of Cuba
column38: and the effects that the sugar industry has had on that nation.  While one is not arguing with his take that the "fate of the `sugar islands' to be incorporated one by one into the world market...condemned [them to produce] sugar until our day
column39: (Page 65) has had an adverse affect on the economies of these nations, his ideological look towards the Castro revolution seems a little off base.  Cuba
column40: Galeano writes, continues to depend on the sale of sugar
column41: although the agrarian reforms of 1959 sparked an intensive diversification of the economy." (Page 65)  For Galeano
column42: the throwing off of American interests has allowed the Cuban economy to expand
column43: thus ending seasonal unemployment and allowing Cubans to work beyond the "five or so months of the sugar harvest
column44: but for twelve months in the continuous job of building a new society." (Page 65)  What Galeano fails to have foreseen
column45: is that in the 30 odds years since he penned this work
column46: Cuba
column47: which has had no influence from the United States
column48: and trades freely with most of the outside world (a source of Cuban cigars from Canada flows steadily into the United States)
column49: is still one of the poorest nations in Latin America.  Castro's great social revolution
column50: even with billions of Soviet dollars poured into the country
column51: has failed to raise the living standard of the average person
column52: and Cuba remains one of the poorest nations in the region.      It is clear that Galeano failed to look at both sides of the issue
column53: and fell into the trap many who study history fall into: judging historical events by late 20th century standards.  The Spanish did not leave their shores with the expressed intent of destroying Latin American culture
column54: nor did the concept of accepting native religions even occur to them.  The view of the world of 1500 was a very narrow one
column55: where the Church ruled and if you did not follow their example then you were a pagan
column56: ripe for conversion. To the Spanish
column57: and later British and Americans
column58: Latin America was a resource to exploit while bringing "civilization" to this region of the world.  Yes
column59: it is true that imposing European ideals and customs on the natives destroyed their culture
column60: just as it is true that imposing the Requerimiento
column61: the telling of native peoples that if they did not accept Christ as their savior
column62: then the Church would sanction the enslavement and exploitation of their cultures
column63: was calculated and brutal. These acts however
column64: were not a distinctly European invention
column65: although reading Galeano would make one think it was.  While raking-over-the-coals European and American involvement in the region
column66: the author fails to mention the same conditions embarked upon by non-whites
column67: like West African nation's participation in the slave trade
column68: the Japanese slaughter of Chinese nationals
column69: and in our own part of the world
column71: the Aztec civilization being an oppressive culture
column72: whose empire was built on the labor of conquered peoples also.  John Rocco Roberto Chair
column73: History Department The Nelson A. Rockefeller Schoo

column1: Speaking clearly from experience
column2: and perhaps even from a wearied condition
column3: Gordon MacDonald does a thorough job of identifying various kinds of habits
column4: individuals
column5: attitudes
column6: and situations which are prone to drain us of spiritual passion
column7: or quite likely of any passion whatsoever.  In fact he does so thorough a job that the men in my Bible study class began to question whether the book would do much more than define the problem.  MacDonald does offer some wise counsel after a clear transition from "problem" to "solution" is made on page 119:  "After all of this discussion about weariness and passionlessness
column8: is there anything positive to say?  Are there principles and truths that
column9: when properly applied
column10: permit one to put the inner
column11: and even the outer
column12: life back into form in much the same way as we realign the pool balls at the beginning of a game?"  At this point the book does begin to outline the sorts of practices and relationships that help a person recharge.  Reservations expressed in class had to do with labeling people as "the very draining people"
column13: "the very important people"
column14: "the very nice people"
column15: etc. and advocating the need to recognize people as such so we can appropriately tailor our responses.  Students questioned the wisdom here and doubted whether the "normal Christian life" is truly intended to always exhibit passion.  Several cited examples of people like Paul
column16: Elijah
column17: Job
column18: Jonah
column19: etc. who seemed utterly despondent at times.  Another reservation had to do with the relative lack of scripture references as the foundation for the specific points being made and for the book as a whole.  Some of MacDonald's other works come highly recommended and may be better starting points for those who are not familiar with his writing

column1: Beginning in 1984 in a series of articles
column2: Richard P. Saller
column3: joined a bit later by his ally Brent D. Shaw
column4: mistakenly contended that the ancient Romans married late - males on average at age twenty-eight
column5: females at nineteen.  They cited hundreds of Latin epitaphs from the late Republic into the Christian empire which proved beyond reasonable doubt that fathers normally commemorated their sons who died before age twenty-eight and their daughters who died before age nineteen; after those ages spouses became the predominant commemorators of each other.  From this solid base they erroneously concluded that those were the average ages of marriage.  Although otherwise erudite
column6: much of Saller's Patriarchy
column7: Property and Death is based on these miscalculations. His corollary about marriage ages
column8: upon which most all of his other conclusions were based
column9: was deduced from a faulty axiom. That is
column10: he claimed that the patria potestas was really rather insignificant because most Romans married for the first time after the deaths of their fathers.  In fact very
column11: very few of the specific references collected to date corroborate such a late age for first marriage.    Regardless
column12: the text has been praised to the skies in numerous reviews and gained a seemingly widespread acceptance
column13: most notably in Debating Roman Demography (Brill
column15: authored in part and edited by Walter Scheidel
column16: the dean of Roman demography
column17: and containing a long article by Shaw.  No one has yet seriously criticized this gross mistake

column1: I've just finished this book and found it rather annoying. Though I have enjoyed the Pitt series along the way
column2: it seems that Anne Perry plays fast and loose with historical facts and
column3: in this story
column4: contrives an entirely unlikely key to resolve the plot.  Although no date for the story is given it appears to be set about 1880. The fact that Pitt and other characters have telephones at home
column5: when the telephone was first invented in 1876 and not in general use until much later
column6: is one problem. Another is a reference to someone's having seen another character's photograph in the newspaper
column7: when photos were not used in newspapers until considerably later.  The chief bad guy in this story
column8: police inspector Wetron
column9: supposedly knows that one of his underlings is trying to catch him in illegal acts. So Perry has him leave a clue in his office that will lead the underling to his home
column10: where apparently Wetron is planning on catching him. But the clue he leaves in his office is the real thing - a link to his criminal activity. How dumb can that be? And then he allows the underling to spirit him off on a wild goose chase in the middle of the night while his house is searched. The ridiculousness of this ruined the story for me.

column1: I must confess I have never read Nora Roberts in my life
column2: so I hate to judge her by just one book.  My mother read this
column3: and kept telling me about it while she was reading it
column4: and couldn't wait for me to read it.  Not being a fan of romance novels
column5: I just totally skipped the blossoming romance between Stella and Logan
column6: because it just seemed typical "romance" stuff.  The rest of the novel just never went anywhere for me.  I never really developed a love for the characters
column7: and the description of Memphis never made me feel that I was there.  Come on - mentioning Graceland and the Peabody - were they supposed to be the token landmarks that make a reader say "o.k. I'm in Memphis".  The author could have just as easily had them visit the Sears Tower and Field Museum
column8: and "poof" they're in Chicago! The ghost aspect had so much potential that never went anywhere either.  I'm a big fan of historical fiction
column9: and if the author had delved into the research the characters did to discover who the ghost was
column10: maybe even adding a few flashbacks of the period when Amelia lived
column11: that would have helped.  The prologue introducing Amelia just didn't flesh her out enough for the reader to invest much in her.  I know that Nora Roberts is a best-selling author
column12: but after reading this
column13: I'm wondering who reads all those books
column14: and keeps buying more?  I have NO interest in getting the next two books in this trilogy.  Haven't had the heart to tell my Mom how much I didn't enjoy it though.  Sorry

column1: I had a series of bad experiences with Amen Clinics. But I will just mention one
column2: the latest. After they got my $3000
column3: they were frankly uncooperative in dealing with the insurance companies. What they wanted to send to the insurance company included speculation that I had brain trauma (nearly everyone has brain trauma
column4: in the Amen view.)
column5: that I had an alcohol problem (I mentioned it once.)
column6: and many other things. No psychiatrist worth anything would turn over that kind of information to an insurance company. It just isn't done
column7: because the details of the session are considered priveleged
column8: not public information. That Amen Clinics did not respect that common boundary should tell you volumes about whether to go there. My advice: Go to a reputable prescribing psychiatrist for 1/10 the cost
